title: 2013 Cadillac ATS Premium
subTitle: Should you buy this car?
promoTeaserSmall: I think this car could actually appeal to younger buyers. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
promoTeaser: I think this car could actually appeal to younger buyers. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?
metaDescription: 2013 Cadillac ATS Premium: should you buy it? See what the staff has to say about Cadillac's smallest sedan on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $49,735 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.6-liter DOHC V-6, 321 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic 
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Leather seating surfaces, head-up display
Options I can’t live without: Cold Weather package, including heated front seats and heated steering wheel ($600)
You might also be considering: Audi A4, BMW 3-series, Infiniti G37, Mercedes-Benz C-Class
See more specs in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

The Cadillac ATS is an all-new model for 2013, but it’s already the best-selling car in Cadillac’s lineup (although it still trails behind the SRX crossover in overall sales). The ATS is a luxury performance sedan at heart, with standard rear-wheel drive and an available 321-horsepower V-6 engine. Cadillac is hoping that the ATS will draw new, younger buyers to the brand, which suffers from an aging demographic. I’m normally turned off by Cadillac’s boxy, angular design language, but the ATS caught my attention, so I took one for a drive to see if it would change my mind.

The ATS I tested was a Premium model, with standard leather seats, an eight-inch touchscreen with Cadillac’s CUE infotainment interface, and magnesium paddle shifters. Our test car also included a $1,050 power sunroof; the Driver Awareness package, which includes lane departure warning and front collision alert; and the $600 Cold Weather package, which gets you heated front seats and a heated steering wheel.

The ATS’s striking exterior, with its long, teardrop-shaped headlights and tight angles, is a perfect companion to the sleek, luxurious interior. The ATS is the smallest Cadillac, so it’s not exactly spacious, but it’s not unacceptably cramped, either. The ATS I tested had a Morello Red interior, a pleasant burgundy shade reminiscent of red wine, contrasted with black trim.

The standard CUE infotainment system was somewhat less pleasing. I appreciated the clear, legible display, but found the system drawing my attention away from the road for tasks as simple as changing the radio station. The physical buttons for climate and volume control weren’t as consistently responsive as one might hope. The standard head-up display, which projects vehicle speed and navigation information onto the windshield, was an interesting and helpful touch that helped make up for CUE’s shortcomings.

The 3.6-liter, 321-horsepower V-6 engine makes the ATS genuinely enjoyable to drive. Our test car’s performance suspension, brakes, and precise steering gave the car a sporty feel. The V-6 isn’t available with a manual transmission, but the automatic transmission has a manual shift mode and optional paddle shifters that can give you a measure of control over the driving experience. When shifting manually, the transmission automatically rev matches on downshifts, producing an exhaust burp that is strangely gratifying despite the risk of making other drivers roll their eyes.

The Verdict:

I’m still not totally sold on Cadillac’s design language, but I am attracted to the ATS’s dynamic exterior and slightly softer lines in spite of myself. The interior is attractive and luxurious without losing its sporty attitude. I think Cadillac has accomplished its goal of creating a car that will catch the eye of a younger buyer. To me, the V-6 engine and performance features are what make this car. I’m not sure how I would feel about the significantly less powerful 2.5-liter, 202-horsepower base engine, for instance.

Yes, $49,735 seems like a lot of money to spend on a small sedan, even one as loaded as this. But if you have the money and are looking for performance and style in a package that's not quite as predictable as, say, a BMW 3-series, this Cadillac could hit the spot.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: My short time in the ATS was not long enough to familiarize myself with the CUE system, but it was long enough to frustrate me. I found it difficult to even turn up the volume on the stereo. I finally resorted to using the button on the steering wheel. The silver toned bars and buttons are aesthetically beautiful, but I would need much more time to really explore and understand all of the capabilities. Once I returned to the office, I found a plethora of videos that would have really helped.

Christina: The interior of this car is beautiful! I love the two-tone leather in the car and the way the cockpit wraps around the driver and the passenger. I was most excited about the head-up display; it was nice not having to look down at the speedometer all the time. The only thing that would keep me from buying this car (besides the price) is the way it rides on rough roads. Performance suspension just isn't for me.

Scott: The head-up display is awesome. I love that feature. It makes me feel like RoboCop or Terminator. For me, navigating around a city, I don’t want to be looking around at the GPS. You don’t have to tilt your head; all you have to do is glance. As for the looks and the driving experience, I felt like I was inside a delicious red velvet cake. I like that it doesn’t look or feel like a boat anymore, which is how I remember my grandfather’s Cadillacs.

Laura: I recall running down the street as a kid to marvel at a brand-new Cadillac that somebody's dad or grandpa had just brought home, and watching in fascination as gewgaws and gadgets were explained and tried out. "You just push THIS, and THIS happens!" "Wowwww!" Commercials that show the ATS performing on the mountain roads of North Africa notwithstanding, I still see Cadillacs that way: a treat somebody gets for him- or herself later in life. Nothing wrong with that. What a pleasant experience, then, to see that this ATS has an interior color scheme, instrument panel trim, and display that are just as wild and different from the routine as ever. Because we're Americans! And that's what we do. Somewhere in middle Ohio, a new ATS owner is showing it off to the neighborhood kids. I hope their mouths are dropping open. They ought to be.

Jean: If you like luxury, if you like a bit of edge and performance with your luxury, and if you like to buy American, then you should look at the ATS. The steering is a precise, finely tuned weapon, and the engine adds a little dramatic background noise. Shifts are better in manual mode, though still a tad lazy. Brakes are the best—Brembos—and the suspension damping is very refined, although it’s best at high speeds than lower. The space age interior controls, high-gloss carbon fiber trim, and iPad-like CUE navigation screen give the ATS a dash of techno that blends surprisingly well with the luxe leather. (I didn’t say I liked CUE, did I?) Altogether, it’s a cozy place to be, especially if you’re single.

relatedArticles.title: LA Show: 115 MPGe? Honda Accord Plug-In

pageElements.text: Honda was the first automaker to bring a hybrid to the United States, giving us the Insight hybrid in 1999. Since then, the company has offered a slew of hybrid vehicles and one fully electric offering, the Honda Fit EV. The newest addition to Honda’s lineup of green cars is the 2014 Accord Plug-in, on sale now in California and New York.

Like other plug-in hybrids, the Accord Plug-in aims to provide the efficiency of an electric vehicle without making you give up the convenience of a gasoline engine. The Accord Plug-in's roughly thirteen miles of electric range aren't nearly as useful as the Chevrolet Volt's thirty-eight miles of range. However, the Accord makes up for its short range with a very short charge time: Plugged into a 240-volt charger, the Accord can recoup its battery life in less than an hour. That makes recharges during shopping trips a real possibility, so those thirteen miles of range could—theoretically—be replenished multiple times per day.

How It Is to Drive

I recently drove the Accord Plug-in and was surprised at how useful I found the car's electric range. Since I have a short commute and access to a charging station at work, I could eke out twenty or more miles of zero-emissions driving in a typical day.

The Accord Plug-in has two selectable driving modes. The default mode, which I used most often, allows you to drive the car in EV mode until the battery charge is depleted and then switches to hybrid mode, in which the car operates like a normal gas/electric hybrid. If you would prefer to save your electric range (say, if you're spending two hours on the highway before you end up in a city), you can press the HV (for Hybrid Vehicle) button on the dash, and the car will maintain its battery charge until you opt to run on the battery again.

image.caption: Honda Accord Plug-in's Eco Assist feature

pageElements.text: Driving the car feels a little like a chore, but not because it's slow or unresponsive. In fact, the car has perfectly respectable acceleration, direct steering, and a fairly nimble feel on the road. But anything other than very modest acceleration causes the dashboard, usually backlit in bright green, to glow blue. It's as if the car is telling you that driving a hybrid shouldn't be fun, an idea manufacturers will have to get over if they want EVs to go mainstream.

How Much?

As we’ve come to expect for hybrid and electric vehicles, the Accord Plug-in carries a hefty price premium over its gasoline counterpart. The Plug-in starts at $40,570, compared with $34,220 for the Accord Touring model it’s based on (prices include destination). The Plug-in qualifies for up to $3,334 in federal tax credits and earns 47 mpg in the city, quite a difference from the Accord Touring’s 21 mpg, which should help ease the pain for buyers.

What won’t help? The Plug-in sacrifices a lot of trunk space to the battery pack, making it impractical for even the most modest weekend trips, and the eco-friendly fabric seats are cheesy and feel wrong in a car that tops $40,000.

The Plug-in's Future

Honda hasn't announced plans to add EVs or PHEVs to its overall vehicle lineup, though the automaker is preparing for the release of the Accord Hybrid this fall. It’s expected that the Hybrid will fall between the Touring V-6 model and the Plug-in in price. The Accord Plug-in and the Fit EV (right) are both available only to limited markets. The Plug-in is only for sale in California and New York, where emissions regulations mandate the sales of zero-emissions vehicles. The Fit EV has slightly wider availability, with cars available in Oregon and several East Coast states. The company hasn’t announced plans to expand sales beyond those markets. Honda has given the Fit EV aggressive lease pricing to encourage buyers to adopt the technology but so far hasn't reduced prices on the Accord Plug-in as a similar incentive.

Honda has said that it aims to sell 1,100 Fit EVs over two years, and the automaker has the same goal for the Accord Plug-in. So far, about 200 of the Plug-ins have been sold since they went on sale in January, according to a company spokesperson. Careful readers will notice that this puts Honda on track to sell just under 600 of the Plug-ins per year, but, of course, there’s no telling what the future may hold.

Next: Hydrogen?

Honda's next big EV project could be something completely different. The company has announced that it hopes to bring hydrogen fuel cell technology into the mainstream by 2020. To that end, Honda and General Motors are joining forces in the race to manufacture an affordable fuel cell vehicle, hoping their combined efforts will hasten the development of such a car.

title: 2013 Chevrolet Tahoe LTZ
promoTeaserSmall: Too much SUV for me. Perfect for those who haul a trailer. But what does the Peanut Gallery think?

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $61,505 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 5.3-liter SFI V-8, 320 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic 
Fuel economy: 15 mpg city/21 mpg highway
My favorite standard features: Rear-vision camera, heated and cooled front seats, power liftgate
Options I can’t live without: Rear entertainment system (part of $2,435 Sun & Entertainment package)
You might also be considering: Ford Expedition, Nissan Armada, Toyota Sequoia

What I Think:

As a single person living and working in a college town, I don’t often find myself wishing I drove a full-size SUV. Most weeks of the year, a Chevrolet Tahoe would be a poor match for my lifestyle and needs. It just so happens that the recent weekend I spent with a 2013 Tahoe LTZ was the same weekend that the lease on my apartment ended. And was I ever glad to have the Tahoe in my corner.

The optioned-out Tahoe I tested was packed with luxurious features like heated and cooled leather seats, a rear entertainment system, and a touchscreen infotainment system, but the only thing I really cared about comes standard in all Tahoes: 108.9 cubic feet of cargo space behind the front seats.

Making use of all that space wasn’t as easy as it should have been, since the Tahoe’s third-row seats don’t fold flat and must be removed and stored separately if you need a flat load floor. Luckily, once you’ve hauled the back seats away, a power-folding second row makes freeing up the rest of the space a breeze. If you’re still worried about space, don’t be. The all-wheel-drive Tahoe is rated to tow 7,300 pounds (the rear-wheel-drive version is rated to tow 7,100 pounds), so you can hook up a trailer to fit whatever doesn’t make it in the car itself.

At 5,694 pounds, you can hardly blame the Tahoe for feeling large on the road. It is neither quick nor nimble, but that isn't a deficiency so much as it is a fact of driving something this large. A rearview camera makes parking a breeze, and the side blind zone alert takes the drama out of lane changes.

The Tahoe has standard active fuel management to shut down cylinders that aren’t needed during light driving, helping it earn 17 mpg combined. That’s not bad for a car this size, and a twenty-six-gallon fuel tank means you can make it more than 400 miles between fill-ups. But that doesn’t stop the $80-plus trips to the gas station from feeling like a punch to the wallet—a big change from the $35 fill-ups I’ve grown accustomed to in my hatchback.

The Verdict:

The Chevrolet Tahoe is not a car for city dwellers or people who need a big car for two weeks out of the year. It’s fairly expensive, a little unwieldy, and not efficient enough to make sense if you don’t genuinely need the hauling space. But if you do find yourself carting around a passel of kids (the Tahoe can be configured to seat nine) and their stuff frequently, it’s hard to imagine a car that would do it more comfortably than a nicely equipped Tahoe. The leather seats, infotainment and entertainment systems, and acres of space make it perfect for families, while the hefty tow rating gives it credibility as a utility vehicle. True, cargo space is lacking behind the third row, but then, what are trailers for?

Peanut Gallery:

Molly: The Tahoe is a difficult vehicle for me to wrap my head around. Why not spend a few thousand more and get the Suburban? You only gain a couple of miles per gallon with the Tahoe, but you lose cargo space behind the third row. In order to make the Tahoe usable as a hauler, you really need to take the third row out. That being said, it is a solid vehicle that would be great for a road trip, but the interior is very bland and utilitarian. The Suburban holds five more gallons of gas to offset the couple of miles per gallon you forfeit. Count me out on this one!

Laura: I can feel the traditional values when I sit inside this Tahoe. It does not look like a modern 2013 vehicle. However, it has many fine qualities that big, outdated vehicles possess, such as a big wide rectangle of spreading-out room in the front passenger’s seat, a simple dashboard area, and a set of wheels and tires that can handle a dirt road. In fact, a dirt road is the first place I wanted to drive it, and I was pleased with how comfortably it handled every bump. My dislikes were in the rear. I didn’t appreciate the high load-in height in back or the removable, but not stow-in-the-floor, third row of seats. I’d either buy a Chevrolet Suburban or a minivan if I wanted a vehicle this size. The Tahoe has qualities of both but achieves the perfection of neither, at least for people like me who don't tow.

Christina: I'm not a lover of big gas guzzlers, but I must say that I loved this car. Sitting up high so that I could see the road in front of me was a novelty, and the same can be said for the cooled seats (especially since I drove this during what may have been the hottest week of July). It's true that the interior isn't anything special, but it makes for a comfortable ride on long drives. I doubt that I would ever buy anything this size for myself, but if you're the type of person who needs a big vehicle to put fishing boats in the water every spring and haul them out again in the fall, this is for you.

Jean: I have never been in a Tahoe that I didn't like. Never, and I have driven many over the years. I have a one-mile unpaved driveway, and I'm forever driving the dirt roads and two-tracks on hunting and fishing expeditions. I've towed boat trailers and my old 1961 Boles Aero camper around on a Tahoe. My husband and I even towed that precious vintage aluminum egg of a camper from Michigan to North Dakota, near the border with Canada, where we bought a farm that we sold a month later. The new and improved Tahoe has cylinders that shut off to improve the V-8's fuel economy—one more reason to love it.

Who should buy a Tahoe? If you have horses, if you are an outdoors kind of person, or if you have a trailer you want to tow somewhere, this is a really rational choice that has been tried and true. Not everyone needs a Suburban. You can put all your stuff and friends in the Tahoe, and it's much more efficient and more maneuverable than the Suburban. It's the off-road minivan.

pageElements.text: Choosing a color for your new car might be one of the best parts of the buying process. You’ve done all the research; decided on a powertrain, an interior color scheme, and a technology package; and now you get to decide what your vehicle is going to look like going down the road.

When my parents were shopping for my first car, I agreed to a Chevrolet HHR instead of one of the sporty death traps I really wanted on the condition it would wear Sunburst Orange Metallic paint. Chevrolet and I have both said goodbye to the HHR since then, but neither of us has lost our love of atypical paint colors.

Sonic Goes from Inferno Orange to Deep Magenta Metallic

Chevrolet has recently been using its smallest cars, the Spark and the Sonic, to showcase interesting and unusual paint colors. It’s not just for fun, either. The funky colors are a serious factor for some car shoppers. Chevrolet reports that roughly a third of Sonic buyers say color is an “extremely important” part of their buying process. The 2012 and 2013 Sonics each had a full complement of the expected paint colors, as well as an eye-catching shade dubbed Inferno Orange (right).

The Sonic is losing Inferno Orange for 2014, but fear not! General Motors is adding three new colors to the Sonic’s color palette. The first of these colors, making its appearance in August, is seen at the top of the page: Deep Magenta Metallic, a purplish hue that GM hopes will make a statement on showroom floors. That color will be only be available through October, so if you’ve always wanted a purple car, you’ll have to act quickly.

Or Maybe a Nice Dirty Blue or Dragon Green?

If magenta isn’t really your thing, November will bring Cool Blue to the Sonic’s palette. Chevrolet describes the color as “a greyish, dirty blue.” That color will be available through March 2014.

If those unique colors still aren’t tempting you, the first quarter of 2014 will bring a new permanent paint color to Sonics near you: Dragon Green. Chevrolet hasn’t relayed details about that color yet, but I’m hoping for something vibrant and metallic, like what you might see on a child’s Halloween costume. Don’t let me down, Chevy!

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: There’s a ritual about car buying that can look a little frightening when viewed from the outside. If you read enough online advice and talk to enough people at the water cooler, you can start feeling downright paranoid about the intentions of the sales staff. Are they looking to trick you? I asked successful saleswoman Beth Bashert from Dunning Toyota in Ann Arbor, Michigan, some questions about finding a comfortable shopper-salesperson relationship. I think you'll find her insights interesting.

title: The New Indispensable: Heated Seats
promoTeaserSmall: Warm steering wheel and seats? Ventilated seating? Don't rule any of that out till you've tried it.
promoTeaser: Warm steering wheel and seats? Ventilated seating? Don't rule any of that out till you've tried it.
metaTitle: The New Indispensable: Heated Seats - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The New Indispensable: Heated Seats: Once you've experienced heated and cooled seats, you won't want to live without them. Read an appreciation on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: On the long list of things we once had never heard of and now can’t live without: heated and cooled seating in our cars. Return with me to the days of vinyl bench seats, on which Mom would spread white towels so it would be slightly less burning hot to sit down in the summer. Not anymore. Now our cosseted heinies get perforated leather seating areas with built-in heating and cooling. Roasting your nether regions is now much more under your own control these days.

No longer a feature only of top-end luxury cars, the heaters and, to a lesser extent, coolers can be found in vehicles from the Subaru Forester to the Ford Escape Titanium to the Dodge Durango—even the tiny Chevrolet Sonic and Nissan Versa Note (right). Sometimes even the second-row passengers get heaters.
If you are shopping for a new car, you really want to put these items on your shopping list.

But Are They Safe?

The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has fielded a few hundred complaints about overzealous bun warmers and has passed the concern along to SAE International (the organization formerly known as the Society of Automotive Engineers). SAE’s Heated Seats Standards Committee is working on recommending an “acceptable operating condition” for heated seats in cars.

The committee is studying top temperatures and lengths of heating time, what kinds of warnings or indicators cars might be required to have, and a possible disabling function for use by people who are sensitive to heat, including people such as paraplegics who are unable to feel how hot their seat is getting. The committee has not yet issued an official statement.

For most people, of course, common sense can dictate when to turn the heat on and off. And once you’ve felt the comfy sensation of sitting on a warm car seat in the winter, it’s a hard luxury to do without.

Have You Tried a Heated Steering Wheel Yet?

The same will soon be true of another, more recent addition to the comfort-options list: heated steering wheels. Ford first put a heated steering wheel into the 2011 Lincoln MKX, noting at the time a good scientific reason for that: “The body’s initial response to cold is to preserve heat by reducing the blood flow to the hands and feet,” causing “reduced dexterity in the fingers and hands.” Not to mention the need to wear bulky gloves while driving. This feature is trickling down from luxury cars to such 2013 models as the Dodge Dart and the Kia Optima (right), and if you haven’t tried it, you have no idea how wonderful it is.

Is Active Ventilation Something You Yearn For?

Okay, heated steering wheels and seats make sense to just about anybody who has gotten into a cold car on a chilly morning. What about cooling seats?

This feature is still most likely to be found on luxury models, and even then is usually an option—for example, it’s part of the Premium 1 package on the 2014 Mercedes-Benz S-Class, where it’s known as “active ventilated front seats.” BMW also offers ventilated seats (right), calling them a means of “removing moisture and helping prevent discomfort or driving fatigue.” The cooling works through fans integrated into the seat padding; these fans draw in fresh cabin air and then channel it through the seat. BMW’s setup has three speeds. Having tried these, I feel that the chilly hindquarters is a bit of an acquired taste, but I’m willing to bet it’s only a matter of time before this, too, feels like a luxury you can’t live without.

title: 5 Simple Rules for Field Trips
promoTeaserSmall: Here's my philosophy to make the best of time spent driving kids to the zoo, the museum, wherever.
promoTeaser: Here's my philosophy to make the best of time spent driving kids to the zoo, the museum, wherever.
metaTitle: 5 Simple Rules for Field Trips - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: driving school children on field trips
metaDescription: 5 Simple Rules for Field Trips: If you are the driver on your own, or the school's, field trips and excursions, here's my philosophy on making it a success after years of being a field trip driver. Read my rules on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In my dreams, they are still coming down the sidewalk from school, their pigtails bobbing, their sneakers bouncing off the pavement as they half skip and half run to the curb. I, of course, am standing in a beam of sunlight, keys in hand, minivan door open, healthy snacks neatly packed in a cooler. It's my field trip group of third graders, about to line up next to my van for a trip to…. Where haven't I been with a carload of kids?

Sure, as those days retreat into my rear-view mirror, I recall them as more perfect than they were, but one thing I know is, those field trips were some of the best days of my children’s childhoods, both for me and for them. They’re all teenagers now, and their friends drive up to the house in their Toyota Matrixes or Honda Civics to take them wherever they feel like going. At school, the bus takes them on their out-of-school trips these days, and it has been a long time since I’ve been asked to drive on a field trip. But while it lasted, it is one of the great accomplishments I look back on, that I made room in my life to be a field trip driver.

Some of the regular trips I recall were to the natural history museum (a.k.a. the “Dinosaur Museum"), the assisted living facility where the students each had a "senior friend” to visit, the water treatment plant, the library for research projects and storytimes, the zoo, the nature center, and the Ann Arbor Art Association for snowflake projects. Some of the field trips involved a ten-minute drive and some a weekend. Some just involved me and my own kids, plus a friend or two. Some were formal trips where I was assigned to a group of classmates and given a route to follow.

From those many drives, I’ve created a list of Five Simple Rules for anybody else who dares to fill up his or her car, SUV, or minivan, and head off to youthful adventure with all the noise and craziness that entails. For those of you who have to take time off work to drive on a field trip, I have two words for you: Do it.

1. Adjust your expectations.

If you are taking a school group, the teacher will probably assign you to drive a set group of kids. If your own kid is a boy, you’ll get him and three or four other boys, depending on your capacity. Same thing if your own kid is a girl: you’ll get a girl group. No matter which gender you’re driving, one of the kids will be rude and bossy, one will be the jokester, and one will be needy the whole time. Maybe some particularly gifted kid will combine two or more of those traits. (Maybe it will be your kid!) I so looked forward to the day I’d get a carload of girls with my daughter, after a few years of driving cars full of boys in her older brother’s class. (Example of boy behavior: I had to pull the car to the side of the road twice with fifth graders who wouldn’t stop screaming out the lyrics to “Air Force Ones” at ear-splitting volume. And don’t get me started on the body noises and dirty jokes.) Surprise! The groups of girls were actually more challenging on a drive, because they all have squeals and know how to use them, repeatedly.

Before you even start the car, have a short and simple list of rules, and make your passengers acknowledge and repeat them to you. Examples: “We don’t throw, toss, or chuck anything for any reason. We don’t scream. We put on our seatbelts and keep them on the whole time the car is moving.” However, do not expect silence or perfection. If you adjust your expectations and get ready to be calm, detached, and authoritative the whole trip, it will be much better than if you let them get to you. Being shrill or angry does not make things work better!

I remember a trip to an indoor water park on which one boy clung to me for an entire weekend, refusing opportunities to run off with the other kids or play what they were playing. I realized, halfway through, that he was just a lonely kid who didn’t know how to interact with the others. We found ways to have fun together, and by the end, he was playing a little more with the others. What if I had rejected him and pushed him away as the other kids tended to do? You want to come away feeling, “I’m so glad I was there,” and not, “Thank God that’s over with.”

2. Be prepared.

The school will give you first aid equipment, probably, but bring water bottles, juice boxes, and small healthy snacks on your own. (Make sure the school is OK with what you are bringing, and don’t ever have something in your car that a peanut-allergic child might react to.) Also bring wet wipes, towels, and a couple of changes of clothes. Bloody noses happen, and so do traffic jams that delay your return. Bring music that everybody will enjoy listening to so your passengers don’t plug themselves in to their individual electronic devices. Do everything you can to make the driving experience a shared group experience, not an uncommunicative bunch of reduced-size commuters.

Being prepared also means having maps—the old-fashioned kind that fold. GPS and phones work up to a point, but backup maps have saved me more than once when I just needed to see a quick lay of the land.

3. Know your place.

If you are running the field trip yourself—say if you are taking your own kids and their friends on a personal outing—you are the boss. In every other case, you are not. Don’t start bossing the kids in your car or making itinerary or schedule changes; defer 100 percent to the teacher or leader. This is harder than it sounds when you are taking your own child and his classmates somewhere! But you need to model deference and respect for your child’s teacher the whole time. Being a pain in the neck to the teacher will backfire down the line, for you and for your kid.

4. Know your stuff.

Don’t just take the school-supplied map and follow the car in front of you. Find out about the place you are going, and know a little about what you’ll be doing. With the Internet, it’s not hard to go to the zoo website and check out the parking areas and the walking route. Extra credit for learning about the fish you’ll be seeing in the aquarium, not so you can bore the kids with your knowledge, but so you can answer questions if anybody has any.

5. Be there.

Remember that the kids you’re taking on this trip are kids. They may have all kinds of bravado. They may behave with complete confidence and seem very independent. But don’t just get them to the door and then get back on your cell phone, or go off to gossip with the other field trip drivers.

Here is a story for you. A few years ago on a trip to Greenfield Village, I was standing near a large group waiting for a train. I noticed out of the corner of my eye when a tall, athletic boy teased a smaller, sensitive boy until he cried, then got a group of their classmates to notice and laugh at the crier. I got up in Athletic Boy’s face, and my son and his friends saw me do that and declined to go along with the bully. That was almost three years ago, and my son just mentioned it the other day.

Be on the field trip. Take pictures. Be the one standing there with the towel or cool drink when someone doesn’t yet know he or she needs it. Be the one who helps a wild kid express his exuberance appropriately. It will pay off if someday, in your dreams, you see what I see.

title: Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance
promoTeaserSmall: This is the place to be in August for the car show of car shows. I wouldn't dream of missing it.

metaDescription: Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance: Here is my photo gallery taken this year at the Monterey historics and Pebble Beach concours. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I went to my first Pebble Beach in the late 1980s. I don't think I've missed more than maybe two. I may say I hate dead-car shows, but clearly I'm a liar. I love the people who collect these cars. I love to see my friends, among them retired and working racing drivers, car designers, car collectors, and royalty. Yes, royalty. There he was, HH Maharana Sahib Manvendra Singhji Bahadur, 58th Maharana of Barwani, in the flesh, standing in the line of judges ready to go on the field. "Manvendra!" I shouted, six inches from his face.

"Oh, my God in Heaven!" he shouted back. I hadn't seen the Prince of Barwani since 1991, when he visited me at Automobile Magazine's old offices at 120 East Liberty Street. Don't you love it when that happens? He's not the only prince I've ever met, but he's certainly the only one who ever visited me.

The Monterey weekend is packed with vintage car events from races at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca to the Quail, an exclusive event on the grounds of the Quail Lodge. There's the Concorso Italiano, car shows in the streets of Pacific Grove and Carmel, and big, important auctions all over the traffic-choked peninsula. In fact, a 1967 Ferrari 275GTB/4S N.A.R.T. Spider Corsa, sold at the RM Auction by the family of its original and sole owner, Eddie Smith, brought $27.5 million—a staggering amount that broke multiple auction records. The family donated it all to charity.

image.caption: Start/finish line of the Pebble Beach Tour d'Elegance.

pageElements.text: The Monterey weekend actually begins in the early morning on Thursday, when the cars that will be on the lawn at Pebble Beach on Sunday gather for a long drive down to Big Sur and back. This year, the drive began with two circuits of Mazda Raceway before heading to Big Sur. The green ribbons you see everywhere on Sunday indicate the cars that went on the drive. When the judges can't make a decision, the green ribbon is the tie breaker.

This year, amazingly, there were four Prinz Heinrich Benzes, considered to be one of the first true sports cars, at Pebble Beach. I had the great fortune to ride in the back seat of a 1910 Prinz Heinrich owned by Mercedes-Benz Heritage, which was restored in tandem with a privately owned 1910 Prinz Heinrich. I was chauffeured by the head of Mercedes-Benz Heritage, Michael Bock, and racing driver Alex Lloyd was in the other.

image.caption: In the back seat of the 1910 Prinz Heinrich Benz.

pageElements.text: I was excited to see how wide the back seat was. I had plenty of room for myself and a bag. And then I discovered that the car was not meant for one person in front and one in back, but two people in each seat. They sure were tiny back then. Much to my surprise, our German riding mechanic showed up and got in the back seat with me. He was the same size as me. This was a seat big enough for three of our butt cheeks, but not quite four.

Over the course of the five-hour drive, we perfected the maneuver of counting to three and then, each with an arm wrapped around the other's shoulders, sitting down together, perfectly wedging ourselves into the back seat.

image.caption: Michael Bock of Mercedes-Benz Heritage, driving the 1910 Prinz Heinrich Benz.

pageElements.text: Meanwhile, in the front, there was no windscreen. Herr Bock took the brunt of the wind coming at him from the ocean, which was so brutal on the way back north to Carmel that he put on goggles and had his left hand clamped over his mouth to keep his lips from ripping off.

Like the Millers I drove the month before, being in this car was a thrilling, visceral experience that I can barely describe, other than to say that the openness, the big steering wheel, the smell of all the mechanical parts and fluids, the amazing comfort of the big cart-sprung suspension, and over it all, the sound of the valves chattering happily under the big, long hood, all transported me back more than 100 years ago. The Prinz Heinrich was more than a century old and delivering one of the most pleasurable, satisfying motoring experiences of a life that has included driving some of the world's most exotic cars.
Thank you, Mercedes-Benz.

The culmination of the weekend is the Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance, which has become much more fun and less stuffy in recent years with the addition of vintage Indy cars, vintage motorcycles, and the Preservation class of unrestored cars mixing things up. Yes, there are still the overrestored, Q-Tip-swabbed wheeled objets d'art. In fact, one car rolled in with what someone in the crowd described as "tire condoms" protecting tires from, God forbid, blades of grass adhering to the treads. But when you walk down the lawn, every third car is a car you've never seen before in your life, and you're so glad that somebody decided to be its benefactor. This is Sandra Button, the queen of Pebble Beach. She is responsible for all of this, ensuring that I can't imagine an August without being here.

The cars are not just in exhibitions everywhere but driving past you on every road. On scenic Seventeen Mile Drive, I was following a Pagani at one point, the first one I've ever seen on the road, from behind the wheel of a new Maserati Ghibli. The noise was stunning but after a while I wasn't sure which car it was coming from, so I opened the window. It was the Maserati's engine. Musica! See ya, Pagani!

title: Is My 17-Year-Old Ready for a Car?
promoTitle: Is My 17-Year-Old Ready for a Car?
promoTeaserSmall: Time to have The Talk...about money and responsibility. Looks like it's job first, Mustang later.
promoTeaser: Time to have The Talk...about money and responsibility. Looks like it's job first, Mustang later.
metaTitle: Is My 17-Year-Old Ready for a Car?
metaKeywords: shopping for a car for a teenager
metaDescription: Is My 17-Year-Old Ready for a Car? What he had to learn about financial planning and financial literacy before he was ready. Read my story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: “My friend just got a new Mustang,” my seventeen-year-old son, Cole, informed me recently. His expression said he was hoping this information would start a competitive mothering frenzy that would end with him seated behind the wheel of same. In fact, I could feel just such an impulse rising like a craving for chocolate. “What did it cost?” I asked, giving in a little. But he didn’t know. Even his friend the new Mustang owner didn’t know. And just like that, the craving was gone.

I wanted to give my child a new toy. But at seventeen, these boys are nearly men. Adults don’t own cars without even knowing what they cost. No. It was time to teach the boy to be a man—at least when it comes to buying a car.

Grant Baldwin, a motivational youth speaker and author of Reality Check, a book and curriculum that teach teens to be prepared for the real world, backed me up. Whatever I did here would teach something, he told me. The lesson I chose was up to me. “That mom taught her son he isn’t competent, that he needs a handout,” he said.

Harsh. But true. Treating my son like a child and the car like a big toy would be sending him a clear message, and not one about behaving like an adult. In the real world where I live, buying a car involves a dozen or more financial skills, from budgeting to comparison shopping to negotiating.

So where to start? “Involve him in the start-to-finish car buying process,” advised Tony Wahl, director of operations for the online credit and loan counselor Credit Sesame. Okay. Why not start with wanting a Mustang? Every car I’ve ever bought started with a dream car. But I’m an adult, and I don’t drive a cherry 1960 Ferrari coupe.

Lesson One: Sticker Shock

Since Cole didn’t know how much the Mustang he coveted cost, we looked it up online. So his first lesson was sticker shock. Its starting price of $22,995 (including destination charge) was more than twice his highest guess. That reality check brought him right down to earth. In fact, it made him give up. So, at Baldwin’s suggestion, I offered to match dollar for dollar everything he could save, which would put a car—if not necessarily that car—within reach. “This makes it possible for him to buy a car without financing,” he explained. “But he will still have some skin in the game. And if he can’t afford much car, that’s his fault. But if he pulls together $10,000, you will have to have to match it. So be prepared.”
Duly warned, I moved on to the next lesson.

Teaching a Teen to Budget

“Create a simple budget,” said Wahl. “Include up-front costs and costs that occur over time, such as gas, maintenance, and insurance. Be sure he shows his income and expenses.” Cole liked being treated like someone mature enough to have income and expenses—and the intelligence to manage them. And budgeting was well within his math skills. But he didn’t have a job.
“Well, you need one to own a car.” I told him. To my surprise, he agreed and went off to return some job-related calls he’d been putting off.
“If he is not earning an income,” said Wahl, “he could contribute by taking on car-related responsibilities like picking up his sibling from school or sports or helping with grocery shopping.”

Should I Help Him Get a Loan?

Baldwin insisted that this is an important opportunity to teach Cole that financing is bad financial planning. Much better, he said, that I teach him to buy what he can afford and avoid debt, which raises the long-term cost of the car and limits his future financial choices. “Financing teaches him that he can buy a car he can’t afford to impress people he doesn’t know,” he said. I agree—at least when it comes to financial planning. But I know my son. He will like the possibility of a fast solution.

Wahl said:  “It’s important for him to understand that a loan helps you get what you want more quickly. But it comes at a cost. You can show him how big that cost is by using online loan calculators. Also show him how larger payments can reduce the cost of the loan over time.”

Needs vs. Wants

Now that we are talking about his own hard-earned money, the Mustang doesn’t appeal, at least not for a first car. In fact, his car of choice right now is “something I can afford.” But choosing a car is big part of the process. So we are having an ongoing conversation about how to do that well.

“This is a great time to talk about needs and wants,” says Baldwin. “You may want a great car. But you probably don’t need it.” My fear is that Cole’s needs and wants might not be very mature. I’m sure he would choose fast and sexy over safe, whereas I would like him to live a long and happy life. But we will cross that bridge when we come to it.

In addition to safety, we are exploring the long-term expenses. “Is there a difference in fuel economy and the total gas costs?” asked Wahl. “Is one model less expensive to maintain?” All important things to consider.

Negotiating

For now, Cole is driving our old minivan and saving his money. But these car-fueled financial lessons are working. He has already gotten a job. And he has pushed off the financing decision until he has enough money for at least a sizable down payment. Meanwhile, he is hyper aware that every fast food meal and video game he buys is pushing his new car further into the future. When he is ready to buy, I will explain how to evaluate a used car and the art of negotiation. In fact, we might try negotiating on some smaller purchases in the interim.

I suppose it would be fun to have a big child (and budget) so I could wrap a car up and hand my baby the keys. Every parent loves that Christmas-morning glee in a child. But I think teaching him that he isn’t a baby anymore and that adult decisions are well within his ability is a much better gift.

title: 2013 Toyota Highlander V6 4WD
promoTeaserSmall: Want a capable family vehicle that lets you skip the minivan? This may be the prettier alternative.
promoTeaser: Want a capable family vehicle that lets you skip the minivan? This may be the prettier alternative.
metaDescription: 2013 Toyota Highlander V6 4WD: Should you buy it? I take my years of minivan expertise into account when saying a family of six will love this crossover. But what does the Peanut Gallery think? Read our real-world reviews on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
The Car:

Price: $33,772 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter DOHC V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/22 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Side curtain airbags in all three rows
Option I can’t live without: Running boards ($649)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Hyundai Santa Fe, Kia Sorento, Mazda CX-9

See more specs on the Highlander in our Car Guide.

You could be forgiven for thinking, as I did, "Here's yet another in a long list of garden-variety crossover/SUVs. Not excited." Yes, Toyota's Highlander is a garden-variety crossover in that it has three rows of seats, comes in two- and four-wheel-drive versions, and has a slightly high, slightly chiseled body that straddles the line between a minivan and an SUV. But the Highlander is much more than the sum of its stereotypes.

Yes, there's no doubt that the Highlander looks just about like any other crossover, but it was immediately understandable and comfortable for me as a minivan driver. It feels like a classic family hauler: no highly advanced or hard-to-understand technology and nothing strange about the seating position or the visibility. The front seat area is pleasantly spacious and comfortable, and the Highlander doesn’t have any of the bouncy-jouncy feel that I associate with an SUV (and that I dislike very much on longer trips). Yet it still has that veneer of capability that an SUV owner would recognize and appreciate.

I took the Highlander on a quintessential family trip: delivering my daughter to her freshman year at Indiana University, some 300 miles from home. My state of mind may have been bumpy, but the ride was sedan-quality smooth on any road surface. And I was surprised how much power was instantly available when I accelerated. The Highlander sure felt totally different from my minivan then—in a good way. The V-6 in the Highlander makes 270 horsepower, so that explains that.

But what this kind of vehicle is all about is its three rows of seats, taking you on beyond the family of four. I have six in my family so I'm well qualified to judge, even though I brought along a mere two kids this time, so I only used the first two rows for people on this trip. I had the third row folded down the whole time to carry cargo. Even so, I liked the easy-to-slide second-row seat that grants quick access to the third row.

I was less excited about the second row as a three-passenger space. Toyota is proud of its Center Stow seat in the middle of the second row, which lets you get rid of the center seat or replace it with a console. However, it’s too small to be a true third seat, and the amount of space it saves is minimal as well. Nobody who has ever driven three small children seated that closely together for any distance would call that row a permanent home for three. For two (like my boys, shown here), it's fine.

The third-row seat doesn't seem spacious on paper, with 29.9 inches of legroom versus 43.2 inches in the front row, but my leggy eighteen-year-old son fit in there reasonably well. Six people really can find room to enjoy the ride in this crossover.

The Chevrolet Traverse, to name one major competitor for the Highlander, claims twice as much space for cargo (24.4 cubic feet with seats in place, compared wtih 10.3 for the Highlander), but I didn't feel penalized when loading dorm gear into the Toyota. The liftgate was high for me, but it didn't feel appreciably different from any other vehicle in this class.
The optional running boards ($649) were a big help in climbing in and out, and as a short person, I wouldn’t get this vehicle without them. (Your height may vary.)

To get a few other desirable features on your Highlander, you’ll want to upgrade models. Go up to the Plus or Limited models, and you get a standard backup camera, which is quickly starting to feel like a must-have item—and it isn’t available even as an option on the base models. You’ll have to go all the way up to the Limited for the optional ($1,760) rear-seat DVD entertainment system. (The Plus starts at $31,730, and the Limited starts at $40,065, including destination.)

For others, you might find yourself downgrading. If you want a six-speed automatic transmission, you’ll need to select the model with a 2.7-liter four-cylinder engine. That one also offers slightly better fuel economy numbers at 20 mpg in town and 25 mpg on the highway. (It starts at $29,880, including destination.)

If you want to be green, you’ll be looking at the Highlander Hybrid. It has the 3.5-liter V-6 teamed with an electric motor. The hybrid model starts at a more vertiginous $41,030 (including destination) and gets you 28 mpg city/28 mpg highway, not a huge jump from the traditionally powered version. But it does have the vaunted Hybrid Synergy Drive that Toyota is known for.

Toyota's name and reputation are probably a big part of the equation when someone looks at the Highlander, and that makes sense. The Highlander is a Top Safety Pick from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and has four stars out of five in federal safety testing. It's got side curtain airbags for all three rows and, perhaps even more enticing, comes with Toyota Care, which gives you two years or 25,000 miles of free maintenance and twenty-four/seven roadside assistance.

The Verdict:

If you are able to stop at six people nearly all the time, the Highlander is a very comfortable, go-anywhere ride that would give everyone as much personal space and comfort as in a minivan, which is my gold standard for whether a “family vehicle” really is a family vehicle. If you want four-wheel drive but you don't want a traditional SUV, or if crossover looks are important to you so you're not pegged as a minivan type (I won't be offended), put this one on your list. Just don't try to squash in seven people too often.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie: I took the Highlander on a weekend trip to northern Michigan, and while it's certainly not the most fun I've ever had driving, it was a solid road trip vehicle: spacious, comfortable, easy to drive. I easily matched the Highlander's 22-mpg highway rating even though I was driving a little faster than is strictly recommended. If I were buying a Highlander, I might spring for one of the cushier trim levels, but that's just because I like heated seats so much. The base Highlander has plenty of features to keep the low-maintenance family happy on long drives.

pageElements.text: This request goes out to all the parents out there. How many hours a week do you estimate you spend in the car with your kids?

And when you're driving them, what kind of attention are you paying to the music they hear? With babies and toddlers in car seats, I'm betting you mostly play what you like to hear, and they're along for the ride. With tweens on up through the teen years, they're most likely plugged in to their own iPods or phones, listening to what they want to hear (and you probably would rather not).

That leaves a whole demographic that nobody's paying attention to, and they're mainly the ones I'm talking to you about today. Between babyhood and eighth grade, there are many years of listening in the car, and you can use them to teach, to share your musical tastes, and really, to blow your kids' minds with beauty or outrageousness in music. And you don't have to get into World War Three to make it work. Here are my five secret strategies that I hope you'll make your own.

1. Know what you want your kids to hear.

Don't be mindless about what you play. In my case, I wanted my kids to hear complex, gorgeous classical music. So I used to go to the library and check out cassettes, and later CDs. One memorable day, I maneuvered to have the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto in one hand and my three-year-old in the other. I waited for my moment: we had a twenty-five-mile drive to take, just the two of us. I put it on, and he ignored it and wriggled around in his seat...until it got to this part where the orchestra explodes. His eyes as big as saucers, he didn't move a muscle for the rest of the drive. I could see his brain cells expand at that very moment. These days, you have the whole YouTube/iTunes world of music at your disposal. Think it over, and choose wisely.

2. Start low and gradually get louder.

By this I mean, you can play almost anything if it's almost unnoticeable at first. I can't even overstress what a huge discovery that was for me, and it still works no matter how old my kids get. I used to be a Suzuki violin mom, meaning I had discs of violin music that my two violin student children were supposed to listen to a lot every day. If I put on the CD at normal volume, they might protest (the other two who were not studying violin protested loudest of all). But, I learned, if I put it on almost vanishingly softly, they wouldn't care, and I could slowly increase the volume until it reached loud. By that point, they were listening and usually liking it.

3. Make it into a treat, not a lecture.

For instance, I waited till my three older children, then all between eight and ten, were in the car together. I announced, "I'm going to play you one of my favorite songs. It has a murder in it. I think you're all big enough to handle it. Okay?" Had their attention then! Guess what the song was? Bohemian Rhapsody, by Queen. I will never forget the looks on their faces as they took it in. They all still listen to Queen, years later. I also tried to get under-twelves interested in Bob Dylan. That one didn't take at first; I mainly remember their derisive laughter at his "bad voice." I accepted that and didn't force the issue or lecture, and now my eighteen-year-old has virtually the whole Dylan catalog on his iPod. I have to think that presenting the music to him at a young age was a start, even if I didn't get instant gratification for it.

4. Tie in the music with other things you can do together.

You could plan to take a child to a concert of someone you love to hear, or someone you want your kids to appreciate. I got Paul McCartney tickets for my eight-year-old, who had just started guitar lessons at the time. It was a surprise, but in the weeks before we went, I played a ton of vintage Beatles and McCartney music in the car. I didn't say anything about why. When we arrived at the Palace of Auburn Hills to hear Sir Paul, my boy already knew all the songs without being told he had to. You could also choose a theme, such as New Orleans jazz when you're going there on a family vacation, or songs in a language your kids are learning, or movie music in the week before the Oscars are on. The car is the place where you have the block of uninterrupted time with kids to build a theme like that.

5. Have a sense of occasion.

If you're going on a trip, why not make a road trip playlist? (Here are some of the Jean Knows Cars playlists we just made, for inspiration.) I associate M.I.A.'s All I Wanna Do with a drive to Vermont with my fourteen- and sixteen-year-old sons, because we had it on our playlist. Not like I am recommending that music, but it helped us bond, and when I appreciated that, they appreciated what I wanted to play, in that case Graceland, by Paul Simon. What fun to roll out a "Road Songs" playlist for your kids next time you are driving somewhere for the weekend. Come on, you can think of some great songs your little kids need to hear that won't be on the radio or their iPods.

You may not care if your children absorb Tchaikovsky (shame on you, though). But if you want your kids to grow up knowing and appreciating jazz, or Prince, or Leo Kottke, or Pink Floyd, they're not going to pick it up at elementary school. It's absolutely your job to insert it into their heads. In the car is the best place to do that. Bonus: The more you set the expectation that you will give your kids a great listening experience in the car, the fewer times you'll have to twist the dial to get away from "Blurred Lines" and One Direction.

title: Back to School by Cadillac SRX
promoTitle: Back to School by Cadillac SRX
promoTeaserSmall: The ritual drive back to college with my daughter was made so much easier in the Cadillac crossover.

metaTitle: Back to School by Cadillac SRX - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: New York to Michigan driving trips
metaDescription: Back to School by Cadillac SRX: A cross-country drive to return my daughter to college, made easier because we drove a 2013 Cadillac SRX. Read our story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: This is the third year we’ve ferried my daughter, Jenna, back to the University of Michigan from New York at the end of August, and it's all about the car. The discussion about which vehicle to test drive from New York to Ann Arbor starts months ahead of time. The first year, it was the Lexus RX450h, a hybrid. The second year we took a Ford Flex, and this year, we drove the 2013 Cadillac SRX Premium. All three of these vehicles look good, haul a ton of whatever Jenna has collected over the summer, and are comfortable rides for the nine-plus-hour drive.  No complaints, and I like the SRX's distinctive look that separates it from a sea of similar crossovers.

Because we live in the heart of New York City, on the Upper West Side, logistics are tricky. We usually pick up the car early in the morning from a parking lot and put it in the driveway in front of our building. Then it takes several elevator loads to bring Jenna’s goods to the lobby. This time, as always, we were stuffed to the windows but with enough space for Jenna to sit comfortably in the back and for the driver to have a clear view out of the rear-view mirror. Here's the story of this year's ritual drive.
Friday

We got on the road at 9 a.m., two hours later than we had planned. Unfortunately,  Mike, my husband, has his own time zone. So we started off the trip on a moody note, or as Mike put it, “You two are being passive-aggressive.”

The bad energy only lasted about fifteen minutes. By the time we crossed the George Washington Bridge, Jenna had turned on a movie on her iPad, and I was already analyzing how the car was driving. And true to its technology, the SRX was analyzing me, too. I kept feeling a thump on both of my thighs and finally figured out it was the Safety Alert Seat. Its mini motors planted on both sides of the driver’s seat give your hips a bump if you veer into another lane.
The SRX offers plenty of power to get ahead of traffic. The 3.6-liter V-6 has 308 horsepower and gets 17 mpg in the city and 24 mpg on the highway.

Then there was the CUE (Cadillac User Experience), a standard eight-inch screen in the center stack with touch controls for everything from the navigation system to the temperature. CUE is engineered to approximate the iPad. In fact, Cadillac gave out an iPad with the purchase of a CUEd-up vehicle when it was first introduced. But CUE is not as user friendly as the iPad, and since I am the type of person who needs everything immediately, it took about eight hours for me to figure out how to get a quick reaction from the screen. The vehicle was also equipped with OnStar, a voice-activated system that works for quick answers. 
Playing with CUE took me through the swoopy hills of Pennsylvania. The rest of the time I listened to Chill, the electric club music station on SiriusXM through the dynamic Bose surround sound system.

Besides the predictable features, the SRX had some cool additions, like the heated steering wheel with rake and telescoping, adjustable pedals, heated and cooled leather front seats, heated rear seats, an extra large power sunroof with power blinds, tri-zone climate control (so everyone can adjust his or her own temperature), a power liftgate, a retractable cargo shade to hide our suitcases, and a Xenon HID lighting system for excellent vision on the frighteningly dark Interstate 80.

Luckily, Ann Arbor, Michigan, is easy to get to from New York City. As one friend who often drives there quipped, “Just get through Pennsylvania and take a left.” By the time we took that left, we were starving for more than my bag of berries, bananas, and almonds.
Our first stop: Bingo! A grocery store with a Subway inside. It was right next door to a yard sale, which, of course, Mike decided to check out. Unfortunately, no finds.

For the second part of the trip, Mike took the wheel. Jenna remembered that she had forgotten her TV and her vitamins. For the next hour, we had a discussion about the price of shipping versus the price of purchasing a new or used TV. Or did she really need a TV? That suggestion didn’t go over well with my daughter, so we decided to table that for the next day when we went shopping. 
 
Hour seven: We begged Mike to change the radio station. His choice, the Underground Garage station, played a steady dose of obscure rock and roll, but it eventually got on our nerves. (It’s tough being a solo man with two strong women.) Bottom line: Jenna got her choice of popular tunes. I fell asleep, and Mike drove the rest of the way.
Our destination that night was Steller House. The B & B, located a few miles outside of Ann Arbor, has been our home away from home for the past three years.

The owners, Hillary and Terry Steller and their baby, Ruby, have become old friends. Plus, Terry works in the automotive industry, so he’s always interested in whatever I’m driving. He can also talk bicycles with Mike. And Hillary prepares awesome breakfasts and even cooks gluten-free muffins for me.

We went to downtown Ann Arbor's Blue Tractor for dinner, a funky barbecue and brewery with local beers, including its own. The eclectic menu includes sliders, beef brisket sandwiches, fried green tomatoes, and black bean burgers.

Saturday

After one of Hillary’s amazing breakfasts, we went shopping for Jenna’s room. The first stop was Target for everything that wasn’t nailed down and then to Macy’s for anything we forgot.

In the afternoon, we visited Kerrytown, a neighborhood that is home to Zingerman’s, the famous deli. It also has a thriving farmer’s market and craft fair. There we bought fresh roasted coffee beans from RoosRoast, olive oil from Sparrow Market, and fresh ground cornmeal from Ernst Farm.

After a deep nap, we had a late dinner at Pacific Rim, a restaurant that my daughter has been waiting for us to take her to. Obviously, entrees like Japanese-style sablefish marinated in miso and sake, pan roasted with a soy-tamarind sauce, aren’t in a college kid’s budget. Sitting outdoors with the evening falling on a quiet Ann Arbor street: priceless!

Sunday

We started early with a trip to Jenna’s storage unit, followed by a day of unpacking at Chi-O, her stately sorority house that resembles a Southern mansion.

After a day of setting up, throwing out, and rearranging her small room in ninety-degree weather (without air conditioning), we were spent. It was 5 p.m. and time to head back to the Big Apple. Needless to say, I hate leaving my baby girl, and I cried like it was our last goodbye. Okay, I’m a wuss.

Epilogue

A few days later, after recovering from arriving home at 4:00 Monday morning, I asked Jenna for some stimulating feedback on our annual trip.

Q. Any big thoughts?
A. We only had to do one round from the storage unit, because the car held so much.

Q. Would you rather drive than fly?
 A. I like a car, because I don’t have to pack everything nicely. I can just shove it in a car, and unlike flying, there’s no weight limit on clothes.

Q. What about spending time with your precious parents?
 A. It’s always nice for you guys to come to Ann Arbor, because it brings a piece of home to school…and we go to [expensive] Main Street dinners.
Oh, and about that TV set. We forgot about it. I guess Jenna doesn’t need one after all.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

Price: $30,290 as tested (includes destination charge)

Transmission: One-speed direct drive automatic
Fuel economy: 122 MPGe city/93 MPGe highway
