Price: $30,425 as tested (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 178 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/26 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: MyFord Sync voice-activated system
Option I can’t live without: Power liftgate($495)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Equinox, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, Toyota RAV4

See more specs on the Ford Escape lineup in our Car Guide.

What I Think:

When my high school besties decided to take a whirlwind trip to the Lake Michigan town of Saugatuck earlier this month, I took the opportunity to get some seat time in the 2014 Ford Escape. And there were some good reasons to get to know this new model. The Escape had an extensive redesign in 2013, and for 2014 both a rearview camera and the Sync system are now standard. Ford’s smallest sport-ute is trying to push the Honda CR-V off the sales pedestal for this competitive segment. A bit of trivia for your quiver: the F-Series truck is the only Ford vehicle that outsells the Escape.

In high school, we were most often driving around in my friend’s AMC Hornet that we had named the Hornet Bomb. The Hornet was built to battle with the imports in the early 1970s, and our old Hornet Bomb would be proud that the Escape is standing its own ground against both Honda and Toyota. My besties, Julie and Teresa, are car enthusiasts and happily agreed to help me take a hard look at the Escape.

The Escape actually looks more like a tall Focus than an Explorer, and that is not a bad thing. In fact, it is a good-looking vehicle from every angle, and the inside looks great, too. The material choices in the interior feel and look good. Even though the majority of the cabin is plain molded plastic, it doesn’t offend, and the gray cloth seats were nondescript. There is a feeling of utility with an emphasis on durability.

Ford has paid attention to the need to be more eco-friendly in material choices and used a soybean-based foam for the seats and head restraints, and the carpet is made out of recycled fibers and plastic bottles. The Escape also works on its carbon tireprint with its standard active grille shutters that make the vehicle more dynamic and help with the fuel economy (which is 26 mpg in the city, 32 mpg on the highway). I think this earth-friendly strategy is perfect for the Escape's demographic, and besides, it yields good karma points.

There are three trim levels available, S, SE, and the all-tricked-out Titanium. The Escape we tried was in High Impact Blue SE with a convenience package ($1,340) that included an eight-inch touchscreen with MyFord Touch, reverse sensing, a perimeter alarm, roof side rails, dual-zone temperature controls, nine speakers, and Sync Services. The power liftgate added another $495. The top-end Titanium models get a foot-activated hatch.  I for one would pony up for the luxury of swirling my foot under the bumper and having the hatch magically open.

Teresa called shotgun and grabbed the front seat navigator spot. Even though she was a basketball standout back in the day, she is just shy of 5'5", but strangely her head hit the roof of the car. We were sure that there must be some way to lower the front passenger's seat, but after consulting the manual, we realized that the four ways it did move were not up and down. Granted, she does have an abnormally long torso, but if you plan on having any tall passengers, they will be most comfortable in the rear seat. Full disclosure: this vehicle did have the panorama roof that takes away some headroom. It is a very nice option but comes with a $1,495 price tag.

We quickly switched navigators so that Julie, who is barely five feet, could feel tall in the catbird seat. The ten-way power driver’s seat did not suffer from the same height problem, and I was extremely comfortable. Too-tall-torso-Teresa was content in the back seat and never complained again. That is, until I made her pump the gas.

I am not a fan of pumping gas. In high school, I lost too many gas caps, and I always think my hands end up with a slight smell of gasoline. The Escape, in fact like all Fords, has a capless gas tank—genius. Seriously, is there a prize for most obvious invention ever?

Julie was our DJ for the day and pecked around on the MyFord Touch, toggling between SiriusXM satellite radio and FM—she is one of those people who change the station for every song. I kept switching back to the navigation screen to try and keep us on track, since my navigator had no idea where we were headed. Like in the movies when drug dealers give away drugs until the users are hooked, Sirius is free for the first six months. As any satellite addict will tell you—especially if you live in remote areas—you will need rehab to kick this habit. To add the navigation component is a $795 upcharge, it worked effortlessly, but if you have a smartphone you may prefer to splurge on other options.

We used both the touchscreen and the voice-activated mode, and both worked without a hitch. We agreed that once you settled in with the Escape, you would probably use the voice method most of the time.

The Escape SE and Titanium come with either a 1.6-liter or 2.0-liter EcoBoost engine and your choice of front- or four-wheel drive in either size. The base S comes with only a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine and front-wheel drive. We had the 1.6 with front-wheel drive and were very impressed with the sporty handling. The EcoBoost engine is essentially a turbo that is engineered to be fuel efficient. Since we were mostly on two-lane highways, we did some aggressive passing, and the Escape didn’t hesitate when we needed to overtake Sunday drivers.

The steering was quick and responsive, and it actually felt more like a sedan than an SUV. The engineers also paid attention and added some more sound-canceling features. As a result, the cabin was indeed quiet, except of course for the incessant chatter of three old friends catching up on their lives. I was the only one who drove, but my passengers agreed that the Escape delivered a sporty ride that made the trip zip by, although Teresa would have preferred if I had driven a tad faster.

Since we were on a day trip, cargo space was not an issue, but we did note that it should be enough for a family of four on a vacation. If you are camping,  you might benefit from a roof-rack-mounted storage box. Both the Honda CR-V and the Toyota RAV4 have slightly more cargo space, but not by a significant amount.

The Verdict:

Since the Escape is no longer offered as a hybrid (in fact, there is not one in this segment), and most of the models in this segment are neck and neck with EPA numbers, it comes down to personal preference: which car do you want to fling down the highway? If the choice is which compact sport-utility vehicle, the Escape is a great choice. It is a winner for driving experience, good fuel economy, and adequate cargo space. If you are leaning toward a sedan with plenty of room, I would also give the Escape an extended test drive. You will find that it is actually fun to drive and looks great in your driveway. And remember, the good karma points will transfer to you.

Peanut Gallery:

Annie White: I don't know why, but I've always had a soft spot for small crossovers, and the Escape is no exception. It's got just the right mix of practicality and style. My only gripe with this Escape was that it felt a little cheaper than its $30K price. Sure, it's got navigation and a panoramic sunroof (both extra-cost options), but what does a girl have to do to get leather seats?

Laura Sky Brown: First, full disclosure: I am not an SUV fan. My household contains a Ford Explorer, and I've never liked how bouncy-jouncy it is, how narrow and enclosed the front compartment feels, or how high up it rides. Nevertheless, I entered this Escape with a somewhat open mind. I liked three things about it before even turning the key: the low, comfortable entry into the front seats; the low, friendly lift-over height in the back luggage compartment; and the auto-opening liftgate operated by pressing the key fob control twice. I didn't enjoy the driving experience, though. It's smaller and lower than the Explorer but still more bouncy-jouncy than I like. Having said that, I know lots of people do enjoy this kind of vehicle; I'm just not one of them. Would I get one of these for a college kid? Absolutely.

title: My Detroit: An Occasional Series
promoTeaserSmall: There are people making this city live again, and we're getting in the car and going to meet them.
promoTeaser: There are people making this city live again, and we're getting in the car and going to meet them.
metaTitle: My Detroit: An Occasional Series - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: My Detroit: An Occasional Series. We keep hearing about people who are making this city live again, and we're getting in the car and going to meet them. Read the introduction to our occasional series at JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Detroit is the big city that has always been a part of our lives. On the Jean Knows Cars staff, everybody grew up in Michigan, and each of us has a set of important memories from childhood onward.

These days, we all use the city in just about the same way, though: we drive in for a specific reason, and we leave as soon as we’re done. Nobody ever says, “Let’s go in to Detroit and wander around,” the way they might take a day or weekend trip in to Chicago or Boston.  Detroit is a crumbling, bankrupt, downright scary place, right?
And auto manufacturing is dead there, right?
Despite everything, the Big Three are all still headquartered in southeastern Michigan. I wonder if we can make the mental shift to seeing what a good thing that is.

There’s no disputing that cars used to be made in Detroit and practically nowhere else, and now they are made practically anywhere else. But listen: despite everything, the Big Three auto companies are all still headquartered in southeastern Michigan. They make cars in Canada, Mexico, China, Europe, and other parts of the United States, but they're still Detroit based. And I wonder if we could do the mental shift to seeing what a good thing that is.

These three companies haven’t gone under. They have adapted to what is now a small planet and a global economy. You can still buy a Camaro and drive it up to Comerica Park off Woodward Avenue, and Annie and Molly did that last week, and it was great.

That’s not forgetting that the Camaro is assembled in Oshawa, Ontario; that Comerica Park, fabulous as it is, exists in a Disney-World-esque wedge of bright shininess surrounded by a whole lot of disrepair and abandoned buildings; that Woodward Avenue, that once glorious boulevard of gleaming shops and cafes, is now not much more than a big, wide bus stop for the proletariat.  You can drive down a main street in the central business district of the city on a weekday, and half the lights at intersections are not working at all. Yes, the city does have big problems.

Let’s not forget any of that. We don’t want to look at Detroit as tourists and focus on a few cute stores or ambitious startups, without making it clear that Detroit also has a really hard road to travel. We’re not writing a fantasy movie here. But it’s also totally unfair to Detroit to look at it as a Mad Max kind of place where bankruptcy is the final chapter in its decease.

Actually, the city of Detroit these days reminds me less of Mad Max, and more of the movie Fahrenheit 451. Do you remember how that ends? There were a few people left in a ruined city where education was forbidden and culture had disappeared. But these few people weren't buying it. Despite the dangers of going against the rules, each had stayed and secretly memorized an entire book. You wondered why they didn’t try to escape and go somewhere nicer.

But they didn't. And if you listened closely, under their breath as they walked, each was mumbling the text of a classic work of literature, so that it wouldn’t be forgotten. As the movie ended, you just knew that these people would find a way to make it be spring again in that forlorn place.

There are people in Detroit who are doing something like that, and those are the people we are going to meet and talk to. We're looking forward to telling those stories in the coming weeks and months.

metaDescription: The Weekly Windup: This week's best collection ever of time-wasting gems from around the Web, each with a tenuous but admirable connection to the world of cars. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Here we go again with a plethora of time-wasting gems I found on my way to finding what i was really looking for. Enjoy!
1. Happy Halloween a week early from Mini.
2. TreeHugger gives a quick chemistry lesson to explain Toyota’s new fuel cell vehicle. If my high school teacher had been this clear, I probably would have been to the moon and back.
3. So tell me what you want, what you really, really want. Well, what Spice Girl Mel B wants is an armored car that will actually shock unwanted guests.

4. Unfortunately for Sporty Spice, she was not invited to attend the Porsche Sport Driving School: Women’s Only Course, but Oakley’s athletes were. They learned driving skills both on the track and on an off-road course. Porsche made this video to promote their women-only program to all women who love to drive. It is a two-day spa-like experience that has a hefty entrance fee of $3,200. It takes place in September 2014, so if you start saving now you can be an expert driver by this time next year.

5. My family’s Buick Riviera had a sweet eight-track player, which is why I know all of the words to every song on An Evening with John Denver. (I know the people who once rode in this 1967 AMC Marlin fastback pictured here enjoyed the eight-track as much as we did.) But now I can actually watch him belt out “Rocky Mountain High” while my husband chauffeurs me along the highway. Fast Company takes a look at past, present, and future dashboards.

6. You may also enjoy this trip in Mr. Peabody’s WABAC machine to view some vintage dashboards.

7. Attention Rubik’s Cube masters: Toyota has turned the agony of the Rubik’s cube virtual. Now you can rule once again with your mad twisting skills. Full disclosure: I lasted about two minutes until I hit Solve.
8. The Big Three automakers lit the October skies in Michigan with a pink salute to recognize National Breast Cancer Awareness Month.
9. If I were teetering on the edge of buying a Honda CR-V, this would push me over the cliff.
10. And here is how they made the magic happen.

11. Let's close with a little Halloween ridiculousness, again from Honda. You already know how crazy we are about the Honda Odyssey's in-car vacuum; that's why we're passing along these eight seconds of fun in which it turns to Count Vacula.

title: Volkswagens Meet Their Canine Match
promoTeaserSmall: Which car is most like an Old English sheepdog or an Afghan hound? VW lays it out for you.
promoTeaser: Which car is most like an Old English sheepdog or an Afghan hound? VW lays it out for you.
metaTitle: Volkswagens Meet Their Canine Match - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Volkswagens Meet Their Canine Match: A British ad campaign matches a breed of dog to each VW in the lineup. Fun to watch. Which one is a Siberian Husky and which a Lab? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: When you think about the experience of driving a Volkswagen, you may not automatically think about how happy your dog will be riding in it—but Jean does; her Jetta TDI Sportwagen was specifically chosen to ferry Bob the Reluctant Show Dog.
Now, I’m not suggesting that Jean and Bob were the inspiration for Volkswagen U.K.’s new dog-centric ad campaign, but stranger things have happened.

Each car is matched for personality and temperament with a breed of dog. A lineup of thirty-six dogs of every breed from small terriers (Polo, Up!) to a greyhound (Scirocco) and a Saint Bernard (Touareg) has been chosen to represent VW’s range of cars.

Volkswagen rolled out the canine-centric campaign with ads on The X Factor in the U.K. The automaker is following up with a print, digital, movie theater, and social media campaign over there, all under the silly (but no sillier than Fahrvergnügen) hashtag #woofwagen.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/65Rrl6Lka18" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

You may not be in the market for a VW out of the U.K. lineup—in fact, you probably aren’t—but it’s a lot of fun to click on the dogs and watch them wag their tails and jump. What a clever way to market to families and dog lovers of all types and to draw a parallel between the many breeds of dog and the many flavors of Volkswagen these days. Are we going to see this campaign in the United States? Mark Gillies of VW in the States says there are no plans yet. Another reason to love the global reach of the World Wide Web.

metaTitle: 2014 Ford Fiesta ST, Meet Mr. Song - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2014 Ford Fiesta ST, Meet Mr. Song: The sporty variant of the subcompact Ford meets a giant of the millinery art, and we all have lunch. See my short, sweet video review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $22,195 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $24,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 26 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Engine: 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 197 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Safety features: Front and front-side airbags, traction control, electronic stability control
Tech features: Recaro sport seats, aluminum pedals, Sony premium audio, navigation, ambient lighting in seven colors
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Sonic RS, Mini Cooper S

Key Points

• The ST stands for Sport Technologies, Ford's "global performance brand" that was first seen in the U.S. with the Focus ST.
• The Fiesta ST made its debut in Europe in 2005 but is new here this year.
• Compared with the standard Fiesta, the ST is 0.6 inch lower to the ground, has a different grille and hood, and wears dual chrome-tipped exhaust pipes and a unique ST high-mounted rear spoiler.
• Internal cosmetic changes include a leather-wrapped ST steering wheel, a leather shift knob, and leather-trimmed seats. There's also a power moonroof and seven-color ambient lighting.
• The suspension modifications include a stiffer rear axle for stability in corners, electronic torque vectoring control, and three-mode electronic stability control that provides Standard, Sport, and "off" settings.
• The car seen in this video had the ST Recaro option package ($1,995), which includes heated seats and mirrors in addition to the snug-fitting Recaro sport seats.
• If you're looking at this car, don't overlook the optional Molten Orange paint color (as if you could). It's a $595 option.
• Compare the price of the ST, at $24,190 as tested here, with the price of the base Fiesta S hatchback with manual transmission. It starts at $15,395, including destination.
• This little hatchback doesn't just feel powerful to drive; it sounds powerful, thanks to Ford's sound symposer, which pipes amplified engine sound directly into the cabin; Ford calls it an "enhanced soundtrack for drivers out tackling the open road."
• When Ford says this hatch has an "aggressive ride," it's not just hyperbole. Ride quality and sporty feel are on a different planet from the standard Fiesta.

Mr. Song and Me

As you may already know, I have quite a collection of Mr. Song hats.

The very first thing anyone always says about Mr. Song is that he made the purple hat that Aretha Franklin wore to sing at President Obama's first inauguration in January 2009. And that's how I found out about him. I loved it; it was such a standout hat.  I found out he was from Detroit, so I went and looked for him. By the time I found him, he had moved out of Detroit and into Southfield.

We became friends the first time I walked into his store. It was late on a Saturday night, and he was there. I didn't know it was him at first; he just helped me, and I asked him if he was Mr. Song, and he said, "Yeah," and we were off to the races. I had an instant bond with him.

We try to get together for lunch as frequently as we can. He loves cars, so I thought it would be cool to bring him a car.

Mr. Song has a lot of outlets around the world. It is not unusual in a good year for him to sell 13,000 hats for the Kentucky Derby and the parties around it, and that is his day because everybody wears a hat there.

Luke Song started out in biochemistry but decided it wasn't his forté, so he changed to studying fine arts at Parsons The New School for Design. Then he wanted more structured, classical training, so he went to Paris. He came back to Michigan to make enough money to go back to Paris, and his first hat factory was in London, but he's headquartered in Michigan now.
In his little back room, as you see in the video, it's floor to ceiling hats.

The blocking and molding are done in another building, but the fine work is done on the premises, in his back room: the hand work, the beading, the feathers. Among the staff working in the back room are Mr. Song's parents. Mr. Song's shop sends out thousands of hats every week.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/vEKZmelCZ48?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
You can buy Mr. Song creations of your own, or find out more about his work, here.
Next visit, we're going to trade services. I'm going to teach him to drive with a manual transmission, and he's going to teach me how to make a fascinator. The cameras will be rolling!

metaDescription: 5 Ways to Spot a Flood-Damaged Car: Steer clear of cars with flood histories or other damage by following our list of guidelines. They're on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: Buying a used car can be a great choice for some buyers. You can get more car for less money, and certified pre-owned programs mean that you can trust your used car to be reliable and in good condition. If you’re not buying from a trusted dealer, though, you’ve got to keep your wits about you to avoid ending up with a lemon. A year ago this week, Hurricane Sandy pummeled the East Coast, flooding 250,000 cars. Some estimates say that as much as 50 percent of those cars will be resold, despite water damage. New Jersey-based nonprofit Kars 4 Kids takes flood-damaged cars as charitable donations, which makes it conversant with the problem. Here are five tips based on the group's advice to help you make a good used-car decision that doesn't involved unwittingly purchasing a flood-damaged vehicle.

1. Know Your Dealer

It may be tempting to snag a great deal off Craigslist or buy a car from your boyfriend’s second cousin’s roommate, but when you’re looking for a used car it’s important to work with a reputable dealer. Car dealers rely on building trust in their communities, so they’re not likely to sell a car if they know it’s been damaged in a flood. Buying from a dealer is also the only way to get a certified pre-owned car, which often includes an extended warranty and other perks.

2. Be Wary of Too-Good-to-Be-True Bargains

If you find a used car that’s priced significantly cheaper than other models just like it, proceed with caution. It may be a great deal because it’s been damaged in a flood or other accident. Make sure you know the going rate for the kind of car you’re looking for, and be cautious of vehicles that are priced far below the norm.

3. Carfax Is Your Friend

When you’re shopping for a used car, a vehicle history report that uses your car’s VIN to alert you to any past accidents or incidents could save you a lot of trouble. Carfax has an online guide to spotting flood-damaged cars, but a report on a vehicle's history is important whether you suspect water damage or not. Essentially a background check for your car, these reports can tell you if a car has sustained structural damage, had an airbag deploy, or if it was ever used as a taxi or commercial vehicle. This should help you sniff out a car that has hidden problems associated with past accidents. You can find a list of vehicle history report providers at vehiclehistory.gov.

4. Don’t Buy without an Inspection

You wouldn’t buy a new house without getting the foundations inspected, and the same goes for a used-car purchase. Before you close the deal on a used vehicle, take it to a mechanic you trust to look for signs of any damage that wasn’t reported to you by the seller. It may cost a little more up front, but it could save you money in the long run.

5. Do a Walkaround

Don’t just take the seller’s word for it that the car is in good shape. Do your own mini-inspection. Make sure to go for a test drive, and pay attention to any unexpected bumps or rattles. Look for water damage in the hood and trunk and rust inside the doorjambs. Sniff for moldy smells. Look for signs that carpeting has been replaced or excessive air freshening or perfuming is present, all indicators of possible previous water damage. Kars 4 Kids suggests that you feel some of the wires under the dashboard. Brittle wires are one sign that a car has sustained flood damage. Progressive Insurance suggests you get a look at the title to see if it's stamped Salvage or Flood: a dead giveaway that it has been damaged.

As long as you keep your wits about you, there’s no reason to be nervous about buying used. Just do your homework so you can make an informed decision, and before you know it you’ll be driving off into the sunset in your brand-new (used) car.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: I had big plans this weekend. I was joining Chevrolet in Las Vegas at the annual Specialty Equipment Market Association (SEMA) show, the biggest, wildest show to overflow the massive Las Vegas Convention Center (and every hotel in town), every year, even the lean ones. It’s the dream of every speed merchant, every pinstriper, every hot rodder, every custom-wheel seller, every tire manufacturer, every Hot Rod cover girl, every racing team and racing team sponsor, to gather the first week of November in an explosion of hot metal and hot times.

But despite the flu shot I so diligently lined up weeks ago, I was slammed to the mat by Saturday morning. I pulled on flannels and the neck gaiter my friend Debra knitted for me, grabbed my pillow and fleece, decamped to the couch, whistled for Ray the Stray, and passed out for two days in front of a roaring fire. It wasn’t enough to get me ready for the week ahead.

I hate being sick on the road, and I’ve been so sick in Vegas (medically, I’m talking about) that they had to bring a vaporizer to my room. I was very happy to be in my own bed, but I couldn’t help feeling sorry for myself—my SEMA dance card was triple booked, and this was what I was missing:

I had a little bird. Her name was Enza.
I opened the window, and influenza.
popular 1918 children's rhyme

• Staying at The Palazzo, part of the Venetian Resort, a true oasis from the seedy Las Vegas scene. The Guggenheim Museum residing within the Venetian opened with a motorcycle exhibit that lured me from Los Angeles, and I’ve been fond of it ever since.

• Driving tricked-out Chevrolet Sonics and Camaros for four hours at Las Vegas Motor Speedway. Chevy has been a wildly enthusiastic player at SEMA for years. In headier times, they would completely change their massive display every single night, so you had to travel to the Chevy corner every day in order not to miss a trick. And that’s what it’s all about, tricking out your ride—from Sonic to Corvette to Silverado and everything in between—with go-fast parts and look-cool visuals. Driving hyped-up Chevys (the Camaro parts were developed from Chevy’s ZL1 and 1LE programs) at the Speedway would have been a riot, wouldn’t it? Right.

• Admiring the new Source Interlink Media corporate booth. SIM, the parent company of JeanKnowsCars.com and Automobile Magazine, also happens to be the parent company of Hot Rod magazine, among some seventy-plus other titles, the biggest of which is Motor Trend. But at SEMA? Hot Rod rules the roost. Editor in chief David Freiburger is a rock star at SEMA, as is former publisher and Mr. SEMA, Doug Evans. The SIM booth is smack in the center of the action in the Central Hall, an oasis of leather loungers and thick carpeting. I shook rapper and car guy Nelly’s hand there once. He looked totally normal, other than the $250,000 diamond stud in his ear.

• Drinking champagne with the Queen of Motorsports, Miss Hurst Golden Shifter, Linda Vaughn, to celebrate the reveal of the Linda Vaughn LV-1 Camaro, designed in her honor by old compadre at Hurst Jack “Doc” Watson, former president of Hurst Performance Research. “You had better be there,” was her last e-mail to me on Friday.

• Partying with Pete Brock. For the third year in a row, I am missing Shelby Cobra designer Pete and Gayle Brock’s house party. They’re the only people I know who live in Vegas, other than Celine Dion, and she moved back to Canada. And I didn’t really know her. You can only imagine that guest list!

• WeatherTech’s ritzy party at PURE nightclub, high above Caesar’s Palace. At least the metal VIP invitation and encrypted pass were ritzy. WeatherTech not only makes the best heavy-duty floor mats in the business (I buy them for all my vehicles), it’s part of MacNeil, great Midwest guys from next door in Hinsdale, Illinois. College junior Cooper MacNeil (he of the excellent last name) also happens to race the WeatherTech Porsche in the ALMS series, winning the GTC championship in 2012 and 2013, with Jeroen Bleekemolen. You can only imagine that guest list!

• The never-to-be-missed Continental Tire party, also at PURE nightclub. Continental is the founding and sole sponsor of the Grand Am racing series, and the company's massive tire operation at the Rolex 24 Hours of Daytona is the most impressive thing I’ve ever seen at a racetrack. They party as hard as they work.
Continental also launched a new Nurburgring-tested, high-performance tire for track and street, the ContiForce Contact, which is for sale exclusively at Tire Rack.

That’s just off the top of my head. Ford’s booth is massive and fabulous. Honda announced a new performance parts division for its production cars, along with the next-generation Civic (right). Mazda Racing, Dodge, Jeep, Kia, Toyota, racing heroes signing autographs—everywhere you turn, you find a friend. And all the little guys with their DayGlo doohickeys and crazy thingamabobs that make our Cool Tech stories cooler. I could go on, but I didn’t make it, and I need to go lie down again.
Let me wrap this up by saying there was only one thing I didn’t miss (along with driving a rental car to the Brocks' party).
Really, really sore feet.

title: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant
promoTitle: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant
promoTeaserSmall: I paid a final visit to Rosie the Riveter's old workplace and met some people who hope to save it.

metaDescription: I Met Rosie at the Willow Run Plant: I paid a final visit to Rosie the Riveter's old workplace and met some people who hope to save it. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: As I walked into the Arsenal of Democracy/Willow Run Conference, marking the closing of the Willow Run Bomber Plant near Ypsilanti, Michigan, and saw that the path to the conference room was lined with guides dressed up as “Rosie the Riveter,” I felt a little out of place.

When I hear the word "conference," I move into academic mode and expect talks of remote history, often laced with vocabulary drawn from impenetrable theoretical texts that only make sense when discussed over a bottle or two of wine.

No “Rosie the Riveters” generally line the halls, and the audience certainly isn’t filled with men in bomber jackets sporting baseball caps (and I don’t mean of the “swag” kind).  This, I quickly realized, was a distinctly manufacturing crowd, one present because of personal histories and intimate associations with the Willow Run Bomber Plant.

As an architectural historian, I am used to thinking about history and space.  The buildings I normally study, however, have few personal narratives attached to them. Short of a séance, I don’t have access to any twelfth-century citizens of Rome gathering together to tell me about their connection to their parish church.  So the most compelling, and perhaps the most important, element of this story of Willow Run is its human factor.  Those Rosies weren’t just there for a costume party.

Its interior space no longer of use to the new owners, Willow Run is slated for destruction. The Save the Bomber Plant Campaign hopes to preserve a small part of the building for a new Yankee Air Museum, a site dedicated to America’s aviation history and Detroit’s contribution to World War II. The campaign has until May 1, 2014, to raise $8 million.

As I listened to the history of the plant and then to the narratives of those in the audience, I began to see the significance of the Riveters and the larger importance of the campaign.  This story touches on the issues that drive urban history: the conflict between oblivion and preservation. Looking at it this way takes the conversation about the preservation of Willow Run from a story of local interest to one of more universal signifcance.

The Back Story

Willow Run is more than an exit off I-94 between Ann Arbor and Detroit. The bomber plant’s history is inextricably linked to the Detroit auto industry and its response to World War II. In 1940, the United States government, recognizing an urgent need to massively expand American production of military arsenal—everything from tanks to anti-aircraft guns to munitions to planes—turned to the auto industry, as only its mechanized processes of mass production could answer the need for such high volume at such a short period of time. It was a time of unprecedented cooperation among automakers; indeed, they agreed to suspend the 1943 model year to allow tool-and-die makers to work for the war effort.

Willow Run Bomber Plant, built by Henry Ford on his private land, came to represent the auto industry’s involvement in the war effort and in the country’s creation of an Arsenal of Democracy.  Ford had originally been commissioned to mass produce subassemblies for the B-24 and B-29 bombers, which were to be manufactured at Consolidated Aircraft. A team from Ford visited Consolidated’s California facility, noticed its lack of standardized modes of production, went home, and asked for (and received) total production of the B-24. So it was that on April 18, 1941, the ground was broken for the building of Willow Run.

Architecture by Albert Kahn

While the story of the plant’s significant contribution to the war effort surprised me, I was also struck by the fact that the factory was designed as a purpose-built site for airplane manufacture by the architect Albert Kahn. In its state today, the site looks unremarkable and unworthy of preservation. Yet Kahn, too, is inextricably linked to the auto industry in Detroit, and his firm singlehandedly transformed the landscape of southeastern Michigan in the first decades of the twentieth century. He was responsible for numerous factories, the Fisher Building in Detroit, and Hill Auditorium and Angell Hall at the University of Michigan. His challenge, to create an efficient industrial space, was shared by many architects in the first half of the century. Immediately, I thought of Frank Lloyd Wright’s Larkin Building, an iconic response to industry’s architectural needs.

Built in 1904 to house the corporate headquarters of the Larkin Soap Company, a national mail-order company, the structure answered the new demands of industry in a new century, with the executive offices rimming the perimeter while the center spaces housed the employees responsible for the company’s workings.  Kahn’s Willow Run answered different demands: his space had to account for the assemblage of airplanes with a wing span of 110 feet by what peaked at 42,000 workers.
The result was a streamlined factory, the largest in the United States, over a mile long and housing 3.5 million square feet of space, with doors on the receiving end that were 144 feet wide.

A Turning Point

The factory’s L-shape plan highlights the personality of its patron, Henry Ford, who demanded that the factory space stay within Washtenaw County and not cross the county line, lest he have to deal with Democratic Party forces in neighboring Wayne County. The factory space represents the progression of assembly, beginning with the clustered areas of parts assembly and ending with the open spaces for the fully built airplane. That disposition of the space of the factory has been lost since the day the last plane rolled out, but a sense of the unity of the factory design remains in Kahn’s one hallmark, the beautiful aesthetic of the lights that line his industrial spaces with, well, military precision.

Willow Run Bomber Plant represents a watershed moment in American labor practices. Before the war, women represented only eight percent of the automotive work force, but the demands of production at sites of the Arsenal of Democracy could not be met solely by men. At its peak, Willow Run was producing one B-24 bomber per hour. Such rates of production required the labor force of 42,000 workers, 40 percent of whom were women. Many of these women drew inspiration from the national propaganda campaign featuring Rosie the Riveter, an idealized strong, beautiful, patriotic woman who selflessly leapt into the workforce to help produce the items needed for war. Willow Run Bomber Plant employee Rose Will Monroe, one of many who migrated to the Detroit area from Kentucky, came to embody the ethos of Rosie the Riveter. She served in promotional films and on posters for the campaign that shifted labor practices in the twentieth century. And that's how, largely because of the Rosie campaign, this plant is identified with the somewhat inadvertent launching of a feminist movement.

The deepest historical significance of Willow Run is found in the people who worked there. Mike Schroder of Northville, Michigan, came to the conference because his mother had been a “Rosie.” He was carrying a picture of the plant from the 1940s of his mother and two other women on break. Schroder’s parents actually met at Willow Run. His father had been an aeronautical engineer from Ford, and his mother, like the real Rosie, had migrated from Kentucky. He was the product of love from the factory floor, as were many others in the audience. Jane Vass, the head “Rosie” at the event, became involved with the Save Willow Run campaign because her parents were Holocaust survivors, and she feels that were it not for the Arsenal of Democracy and the sacrifice of “Rosies,” her family line would not have survived.

The elegantly attired Margaret Strickland of Bloomfield Village, Michigan, had been a “Rosie” herself, not as a riveter, but as a worker in the blueprint department.  An Ann Arbor native attending the University of Michigan during the war years, Mrs. Strickland felt compelled to work at Willow Run in the summer of 1942 to do her part for the war effort.  She still has one of the drawings from her time at the plant: a beautiful section rendering of a B-24.  She says she admired it so much that one day she simply folded it up, stuck it in her coat, and snuck it out of the plant. Preserving a beautiful drawing?  She’s my kind of “Rosie.”

Willow Run Bomber Plant embodies a particular moment in United States history, when the automotive industry turned to industrial production for the Arsenal of Democracy, when the landscape of Michigan was changed, and when women entered the workforce in unprecedented numbers, unwittingly opening doors for women of future generations. For the week after the conference, I couldn’t stop thinking of the fate of Frank Lloyd Wright ’s Larkin building. Demolished in 1950, that iconic monument of industrial production was condemned to oblivion over the protests of historians. The complete destruction of Willow Run would be more than the destruction of an old building.  It would be to condemn a space, and therefore its history, to oblivion.
Let’s hear it for those “Rosies” and their determination to preserve an important piece of Detroit’s—and America’s—history.

title: General Motors' Online Car Shopping
promoTeaserSmall: GM's Shop-Click-Drive invites you to handle the red tape without doing time in a dealer's cubicle.
promoTeaser: GM's Shop-Click-Drive invites you to handle the red tape without doing time in a dealer's cubicle.
metaTitle: General Motors' Online Car Shopping - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: General Motors' Online Car Shopping: Ready to buy your next car online? GM's Shop-Click-Drive invites you to handle the red tape without doing time in a dealer's cubicle. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I know what your parents did when they bought new cars. They flatfooted it down to the dealership under the tiki lights one September evening, probably with you in tow, and sought out their regular salesman, Vic, the one with the Ban-Lon shirt and the scratchy moustache. They picked out a car off the lot with very little comparison shopping. Did Vic give them a good deal? Maybe, maybe not, but they were loyal and didn’t have a lot of information to go on.

Unless you had “smart shoppers” for parents. Then they flatfooted it from dealership to dealership, trying to get a better deal, after thumbing through Consumer Reports until the pages fell out. You may or may not have been invited to go along, but it was a long, tiring, sweaty process.

And I even know what you did the last time you bought a new car. You spent hours upon hours online, surfing the car company websites, then on to the advice sites with their screens full of specifications and color choices. You played with configurators. You got pretty close to knowing what car you wanted to buy.

Then, of course, you made like your parents and flatfooted it down for a negotiation tango that was as unpleasant as it was exhausting. In the end, you drove off with the car you were ogling online all those lost hours ago. Did you get the best deal? You still weren’t that sure.

So go ahead, ask me: Do I know what you’re going to do next time you buy a new car? Why, yes, I do. It’s quite possible that you are going to buy it online from start to finish. Maybe the dealership will bring it right to your house for you, and you’ll never set foot inside a dealership. How do I know this? Because the first salvo has already been heard. This month, General Motors has rolled out online shopping and is said to be strongly encouraging its dealers to get on board with online sales. The Shop-Click-Drive website is up, and its logo proclaims: “worry-free, pressure-free, hassle-free.”

But not necessarily free of dealer interaction. You will still be hooked in to a dealer who will make the final sale, and you will still shop on that dealer’s website. It’s a five-step process: Get Started, Estimate Payments, Apply for Credit, Personalize & Protect, and Schedule Delivery.
Click Submit, and you get the dealer's offer without leaving your sofa. Negotiating can continue via e-mail before you even go in to test drive.

For the past several months, it was being Beta tested in Michigan only, which was lucky for us. I scrolled through the list of forty-eight participating dealers and chose the one closest to me, Art Moehn Chevrolet in Jackson, Michigan.

Chris Kudner, director of business development at the dealership, which is located about thirty miles west of Ann Arbor, told me the program has been up and running there since the early summer of 2012. Still, he said, only “half a percent” of buyers are using it, a sign that online shopping is going to have a slow curve toward universal acceptance.
“It’s a really great idea GM came up with,” he told me. “I’m just not sure if the consumer is ready yet, because it’s a big purchase. You really have to come and see the car.”

pageElements.text: Of course, most people like the part about sitting in a car and taking it for a spin. It’s the endless sitting around in a salesperson’s cubicle filling out paperwork that we could do without. Kudner agreed that the best part of an online shopping program is that it cuts red tape. “It does take a fair amount of time to shop for a car in the showroom, “ he acknowledged, “just having the salesperson type in all your information, driver’s license, financing application, time on the job, income, Social Security number….” With online shopping, you can fill all that out on your timetable, from your home.

“To me,” he said, “that's the biggest advantage of the program, for somebody who’s strapped for time. Come in, and we’ve got it all waiting for you.”

Of course, online shopping doesn’t mean you can’t go see the car, and Art Moehn Chevrolet, like any dealership, wants you to come get a test drive.

“We handle online shoppers very similarly to the customer who just e-mails the dealership,” said Kudner. “We say, ‘What does your schedule look like?’ because we really want [them] to test drive the car; then we can talk about the numbers. It’s $30,000, $40,000, $50,000—you’ve gotta touch it, drive it, and see it. It’s not like toothpaste on Amazon.com where you can just buy it.”

But, you ask, what about negotiating? One reason the Beta program was concentrated among small-town dealerships around southeastern Michigan is likely that so many Michiganders are linked in some way to the auto industry. “I think they did that on purpose,” Kudner agreed. “With the new cars in our market, we do 98 percent of our sales as formula priced with GM, either employee or supplier or credit union discounts. It’s a set price from the factory, and people know that. It’s kind of a unique market. “

The dealership has recently rolled out online shopping to its used-car department, Kudner said. “Of course there’s always negotiation on them." A quick visit to the Used inventory on the Art Moehn website shows that you can get a lot of information, including Internet pricing, accessory discounts, financing applications, and trade-in estimates, by moving through the site. Click Submit, and you get the dealer's offer without leaving your sofa. Negotiating can continue via e-mail before you even go in to test drive.
It’s $30,000, $40,000, $50,000—you’ve gotta touch it, drive it, and see it. It’s not like toothpaste on Amazon.com where you can just buy it.

Once you've made your decision on a purchase or lease, Kudner pointed out,  state law in Michigan requires the customer to sign the paperwork in front of an agent of the dealership. That has meant a final trip to the dealer to take delivery. However, now that the program is out of Beta, he said, a customer can have a new vehicle delivered to his or her home or business and sign the papers there.
Wouldn’t that make you feel like a rock star?

Kudner noted that his dealership was one of the first twenty to have tried the Shop-Click-Drive program. “When they first came in and pitched it to us, there was some concern—especially with what’s going on with Tesla, with the manufacturer trying to go around the dealers. GM did a pretty good job of explaining that they weren’t trying to accomplish that, but looking for a way to help the consumer. They got us all on board.
“I get [the objectors’] point of view, but you can’t fight reality. I buy all my stuff on Amazon.com, from my phone. If you don’t adapt, you’ll get left behind.”

Will it be harder to negotiate a good deal over the Internet than over the desk? Speaking for myself, as a not very persuasive, perhaps even mousy consumer—but one with a lightning-fast typing speed—I can see definite advantages to negotiation by laptop.

pageElements.text: Have you ever taken your kids to a museum and let them put in a dollar to get one of those quickie injection-molded plastic souvenirs? This is the Hot Wheels equivalent for your house. There is no doubt in my mind that this $49.99 play set will get put to use within minutes of being unwrapped. Whether the novelty will wear off quickly is another story.

I am frowning on, but choosing to ignore, the Mattel advertising that reads: “Boys can make their very own vehicles in a matter of minutes!” After looking in vain for the Y Chromosome Locator that is needed to start the thing up, I chose to chuckle dismissively rather than, you know, run over the ad writer’s fingers with my freshly cooked Hot Wheels Car Maker car. Let’s all resolve to find girls to give this to.

How It Works

The Hot Wheels Car Maker starts with ten sticks of various-colored wax and two generic Hot Wheels molds. You choose your color and mold, set it into the Car Maker, and eight minutes later, the warm body is ready to go. Voice and music prompts, plus flashing lights, tell the user when to put the wax in, when to start the cooking process, and when it’s safe to take the mold out. (Do you think every kid is going to be that patient? But I digress.) You then set the body on your choice of three chassis types, and tart it up with the included sticker pack, and off it goes to race on whatever Hot Wheels tracks your kid has set up, or just down the sidewalk or across the carpet.

One reviewer on Amazon.com made me laugh: “The cars don't break, even when involved in traffic incidents. They bounce off each other like the product of some safety-minded car designer.” Wax cars for the masses!

This being a major toy company, you know there are refill packs, each sold separately, and you're going to need them. The Hot Rods, Street Muscle, or Beast Riders accessory mold packs include wax, molds, and chassis, and they cost $11.99. You can order this and other Hot Wheels products directly from the Mattel Shop online and benefit from free shipping and other discounts during the shopping season.

contributors.bio: I am a car geek dating back to my childhood, when I took notice of the various sizes, shapes, and designs of cars. I named all of our family cars and cried when they reached the end of their useful life. I’ve been mentally composing automotive reviews for years, but it wasn’t until some years ago, when I read one of Jean Jennings's columns while waiting for an appointment, that I realized that it was possible. And here I am… grateful and enjoying every second. My next goal in life is to learn to drive a manual.

pageElements.text:
I was won over by the boy-racer charm of the 2015 Subaru WRX. As it was ushered in at the Los Angeles Auto Show this morning with a club-worthy soundtrack and light show, I was shaken out of
my cold-medicine-induced stupor.

The WRX, based on the Impreza, was shown in concept form at the New York Auto Show earlier this year (shown at right), where it was greeted with excitement. The production version is not quite the same, but that's no surprise. And it's still very good-looking.

But, more than just a pretty face, the 2015 WRX features a stiffer chassis, Subaru's Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive with torque vectoring, and 
a 2.0-liter horizontally opposed turbocharged four-cylinder engine that produces 268 horsepower and a healthy 268 pound-feet of torque. The engine is based on the one in the 2014 Forester 2.0 XT but is adjusted for more performance. The wheels are seventeen inches, and many exterior body parts are new to the 2015 WRX, including the hood, front fenders, bumpers, rear doors and quarters, and the headlights and taillight clusters. Do you like this "wide body" look? I do.
The new WRX will have a standard six-speed manual transmission (of course) or, optionally, a new continuously variable Sport Lineartronic transmission with manual modes.

Subaru forecasts 30 mpg for this car, along with a bigger interior, a new flat-bottomed steering wheel, Bluetooth connectivity, a rearview camera, and an enhanced audio system by Harman/Kardon. Plus, whiplash-reducing sport seats! Perfect for the combination of logical thinker and adventure seeker in us all.—Elaine Nadalin, Correspondent

pageElements.text: Any power shopper worth her salt has already ogled the Saks Fifth Avenue limited-edition Cadillac ELR luxury coupe, for sale in the 2013 Saks Holiday Catalog. But the Cadillac excess doesn't stop with that electric luxury coupe.

Check out this Frozen Escalade in the shop window that's part of the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store's stunning holiday display. Behind that fake ice is the all-new 2015 Cadillac Escalade SUV in White Diamond. The upcoming model's LED lights offer the extra brightness needed to catch shoppers' eyes as it appears to be breaking through a wall of ice.

Buyers of the all-new Escalade won't be able to try this, at least not this winter: It doesn't go on sale until spring. But the tie-in with Saks makes sense in view of the one-percenter marketing push. The Escalade's consumer website features banner text reading: "The Official Mover of the Shakers" and "The 420-hp Gated Community."

The 2015 Escalade is the sixth generation of the massive luxury SUV. It will be available in standard and extended-wheelbase (ESV) versions, in rear- or all-wheel drive, and with the aforementioned 420 horsepower from a 6.2-liter V-8. Luxury and Premium trim packages are offered above the already luxuriant base model. And yes, that White Diamond color is on the list of choices. As for the question, how much is that big dog in the window? Prices haven't been announced yet, but with the current Escalade already starting at about $64,000, you can hazard a guess.

But perhaps you just want to see holiday window displays. Who doesn't? Here is the best quick photo tour of store windows from around the world, including Saks, that I've found this year. Vicarious thrills!

title: Car Buying: What Do Women Want?
promoTitle: Car Buying: What Do Women Want?
promoTeaserSmall: Carmakers aren't good at selling to us. Expert Tinesha Craig tells how to get what we need anyway.
promoTeaser: Carmakers aren't good at selling to us. Expert Tinesha Craig tells how to get what we need anyway.
metaTitle: Car Buying: What Do Women Want?
metaDescription: Car Buying: What Do Women Want? So many dealers are doing it wrong! Expert Tinesha Craig tells us how to get what we need anyway. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text: It’s a fact: women make 62 percent of new car purchases and make nearly 80 percent of car purchasing decisions in the United States. So why are automakers still struggling to effectively target this huge buying audience? Tinesha Craig, director of the i on Women division of the market research firm Insights in Marketing, took a look at how women view the car buying process. She found that only 26 percent of women said they were "extremely satisfied"  with the options available to them in the automotive market.

Craig surveyed women about their habits and experiences in shopping for cars to try to figure out what needs to change. What she learned was that—perhaps unsurprisingly—women aren’t all that different from men when it comes to shopping for cars. But there are a few places where we differ. “In terms of motivators and thought process, [men and women] are fairly similar,” Craig said in a phone interview. But women are more likely to start their shopping process online, and have a greater desire to feel informed before we ever set foot in a dealership. Here are five things that are important to women buyers. Automakers, are you listening?

1. We Want Clarity on the Web

There's a lot of information available on automakers' websites now. Unfortunately, many automakers have websites that aren’t fully responsive to the needs of a variety of shoppers. Websites often fail to clearly demonstrate a car’s full range of features, tending to focus in on its performance attributes instead. “Some women may be interested in performance, some want to know about safety features. It’s important to understand the range,” Craig explained. She said many shoppers would benefit from a full, jargon-free rundown of a car’s features and how it compares to the competition.
We want to know how long cars will last, how reliable they’ll be, and what kind of warranty the manufacturer offers. It should be easier to make head-to-head comparisons.

2. We Want to See Warranty and Resale Information

Women also buy new cars less frequently than their male counterparts, meaning they hold on to cars for longer. This means we want to know how long our cars will last, how reliable they’ll be, and what kind of warranty the manufacturer offers. “The warranty piece, I think, is a mystery to everybody,” said Craig. While some automakers tout their warranties and resale values, others aren’t as clear. It should be easier to make head-to-head comparisons and find the details on the model you are looking at.

3. We Expect a Little Respect at the Dealership

While we’re waiting for car companies to wise up to the things they could do to cater to women in the shopping process, is there anything women can do to streamline the process ourselves? Craig acknowledged that for many women, a trip to the dealership can be a stressful experience. “Going to the dealer feels like being in a pressure cooker. The focus is on [the dealer], not what the customer wants.” This could be why so many women start their search online in hopes of avoiding an unpleasant experience at the dealership. Craig said she has walked away from a dealership that gave her “that slimy, icky feeling,” opting instead for one that treated her with respect and gave her plenty of time to test drive the car she was interested in.

4. We Listen to Our Friends

Craig said that in her own car buying process, she has relied on advice from trusted friends instead. That’s not uncommon: 63 percent of the women she surveyed also looked to friends for car advice. Dealers should be leveraging the socially interactive female customer by asking them to refer friends and inviting them to bring friends along on the buying process.

5. We Want Car Buying to Be Fun

If you’re dreading a trip to the dealer, don't. You have the purchasing power to make it a good experience. Starting your search online could be a good way to get some basic information about the cars you’re interested in. The test drive is still a crucial step, so don’t put up with a dealer who won’t give you the time you need. Find one who will help you feel good about the process of buying a car, and be sure you're comfortable with your purchase before you sign on the dotted line. Craig lamented that car buying has become such a chore for some women. “There’s a lot of frustration with this process, but there doesn’t need to be. It should be exciting.”

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of.
