pageElements.text:
2013 Ford C-Max Energi Plug-In Hybrid

Price: $37,820 (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder, 141 horsepower (188 total system horsepower)
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic (e-CVT)
Fuel economy: 44 mpg city/41 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Leather-trimmed seats and steering wheel
Option I can’t live without: Panoramic sunroof ($1,195)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Honda Accord Plug-In Hybrid, Toyota Prius Plug-In Hybrid

No matter what your feelings are about electric or hybrid vehicles, pretty much everyone agrees that carmakers are going to have to do something in coming years to increase fuel economy. But will the car of the future be one with a big battery pack and a plug? Maybe, maybe not. I was curious to see what the future might look like to a person driving a plug-in hybrid, so I made a 2013 Ford C-Max Energi my commuter car for a work week in November to see how I liked it.

I was looking forward to a week with the C-Max Energi because, even though I normally prefer sportier cars, I’ve thought for some time now that my lifestyle would be perfect for plug-in hybrid ownership. My weekday routine should allow me to drive the C-Max Energi every day without using a drop of gasoline, saving the internal-combustion engine for the few times a month when I need to go more than twenty miles between charges. During my week with the Energi, I decided to see if I could do just that: use as little gas as possible—and, I hoped, none.

On paper, the C-Max Energi was perfectly suited to this task. It’s a plug-in hybrid vehicle with a battery pack that can give it up to twenty-one miles of electric range when fully charged, a little more than I’d need on an average day. Once you’ve discharged the battery, the C-Max acts like a regular hybrid, using the electric motor at low speeds and when coasting but relying mainly on the gasoline  engine. Its electric battery is rated to earn 100 mpg-e, while the car’s gasoline engine is rated at 43 mpg combined.

My C-Max arrived at the office on one of the first really cold days of Michigan autumn. In a "normal" car, this wouldn’t matter. Hop in, blast the heat for a few minutes, and you’ll be cozy and warm. Electric vehicles, though, see their range significantly diminish in cold temperatures, and using accessory functions like climate control and seat heaters further drains the battery.
The C-Max charges in 2.5 hours with a 240-volt plug. I plugged mine in when I arrived at the office each day, and it was ready to go by lunchtime.

In near-freezing temperatures, the C-Max Energi showed a fully charged battery but just sixteen miles of range as I pulled away from the office on the first day of my experiment. I put the C-Max in EV mode (it also has EV Later mode, which saves electric charge for later in the drive, and Hybrid mode, in which it operates like a conventional hybrid) and drove very sedately to the gym, making the most of regenerative braking and accelerating as gently as possible. When I arrived, I had traveled 4.9 miles and had recouped more than a mile’s worth of energy from regenerative braking. I had thirteen miles of range left.

After a pit stop at Starbucks for a salted caramel hot chocolate, a jaunt downtown for dinner, and back home for the night, I had just a few miles of range left for the morning’s trip to work. The EV range estimator, conveniently located on the C-Max’s digital dashboard, showed less than half a mile of juice left when I pulled up to the office charging port. The C-Max charges in seven hours with a 120-volt plug and 2.5 hours with a 240-volt plug. I plugged mine in when I arrived at the office each day, and it was ready to go by lunchtime.

The rest of the week passed in much the same fashion. I had just enough range to cover my travels on electricity alone. Still, I never had range anxiety—and no C-Max driver ever should—because the electric range is just the beginning for this car. The C-Max Energi is rated to go more than 600 miles on a tank of gasoline, and it automatically switches to gasoline power when the battery is depleted or the electric motor is overtaxed (under heavy acceleration, for instance) so there’s no need to worry about getting stranded.

I took a break from my electric-only project to see how Ford’s plug-in felt in hybrid mode, and found the C-Max as responsive and pleasant to drive as any other hybrid I’ve been in. It has a 2.0-liter, four-cylinder Atkinson cycle engine – the same engine that’s in the C-Max hybrid. It has 188 total system horsepower, so there’s plenty of juice for highway passing. The switch between gasoline and electric power isn’t quite seamless, but it’s close enough that you might not notice it if you’re not paying attention.

I succeeded in making it through my four-day turn with the C-Max without using any gasoline (except to test drive the gasoline engine). Senior editor Molly Jean took the C-Max for the weekend and drove it in Hybrid mode all weekend after the battery’s charge was depleted. In her 135 miles of driving, the C-Max Energi averaged 37.4 mpg, falling far short of its 43-mpg estimate. That could easily be chalked up to driving style and other factors, but it serves as a reminder that Ford had to revise the C-Max’s original fuel economy estimate of 47 mpg combined after drivers complained that the cars were underperforming.
There’s no reason—aside from a stubborn desire to prove yourself right—that you can’t drive the C-Max exactly the way you would drive a normal car.

Driving the car in EV mode in the winter required sacrifices that not all drivers would be willing to make; I never turned the heat above 65 degrees and didn’t use seat heaters, especially after I saw the quick dive my range estimate took as soon as those amenities were engaged. But the good news about the C-Max Energi is that you don’t have to live without creature comforts. There’s no reason—aside from a stubborn desire to prove yourself right—that you can’t drive the C-Max exactly the way you would drive a normal car. It’s a toe in the pool of electrified driving, but more like dating than marriage. And that’s exactly what many electric-curious shoppers are looking for.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

I was missing Anthony Prozzi. I really hadn’t seen him since his big debut of the 2009 Ford Flex interior in New York City. I had arranged a project vehicle for Automobile Magazine to build for the SEMA show, and I had chosen the Flex as the perfect canvas for street artist Lee Quiñones, who became famous at the age of sixteen for being the first spray paint Michelangelo to tag an entire subway car. The New York PD called him Enemy No. 1. From those countercultural beginnings, he has risen to be commissioned to do entire buildings, and his artwork hangs in celebrity homes. The vehicle he did for SEMA celebrated the vibrancy of his New York: bridges, cabs, stockbrokers, and the music and garment industries.

During the course of that build, I enjoyed a lot of time with Prozzi in New York talking about his past in the fashion industry and really came to love his articulate expression of the materials and forms that shape an interior of a car. It was so different than anything I had ever heard from a classically trained automotive designer. Of course he was the one who did the Fusion interior, I thought when I found out. It was my opportunity to get back together and have a great day with him.

At the end of our day, we came up with this wonderful designer "sit-around" video, and then I discovered he lived in downtown Detroit, so he’ll be making an appearance in a future episode of My Detroit. I know you’re going to like him as much as I do.

pageElements.text: Every week there seems to be another new development in the race to create a self-driving car. The latest announcement hit pretty close to home: Ford, the University of Michigan here in Ann Arbor, and the State Farm insurance company are teaming up to work on the technology using the automated Ford Fusion Hybrid research vehicle that you see here.

Setting aside its Miley-Cyrus-at-the-VMAs headgear, this is exciting news for two reasons. One is that it's the next logical step for Ford, which participated in the earlier Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) autonomous vehicle challenges in 2004, 2005, and 2007. Those seemed so theoretical at the time. Ford has also been hooked up with the U of M for more than five years, while the university advanced the knowledge base through its Transportation Research Institute's Connected Vehicle Study.

Here's a photo showing the Fusion in autonomous driving testing. Comfortingly, someone is still behind the wheel. Ford sees the autonomous research Fusion as an extension of its already existing driver assist technologies, including blind spot monitoring, active park assist, lane departure warning, and others. In Ford's worldview, these functions get improved through research using the autonomous test vehicle. The next step after that will include the introduction of vehicle-to-vehicle communication, which will then lead to some autopilot ability. Intriguingly, Ford suggests there might be "platooning," or the ability of vehicles traveling in the same direction to synchronize their movements for a more efficient and denser population out on the road. If only we could choose who else is in the platoon next to us...
The automaker calls these steps "the building blocks for the future of fully automated driving."

I'm not so sure about "fully automated," but I wasn't so sure about microwave ovens or cell phones, either, and now I use them both regularly, so I guess I'll just sit back and watch the world change around me yet again.

Since this is happening right in our back yard, we'll keep you updated. How do you feel about this march toward the autonomous car?

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio:
I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad. 

Growing up in Southeastern Michigan means that love of cars is practically a birthright, and one I’ve always been proud of. I still drive my first car, a beloved orange Chevy HHR that has been through the war and keeps on chugging. After three years on the East Coast, I’m happy to be back in a place where the speed limit is treated more as a guideline than a rule.

pageElements.text:
Price: $70,020 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 3.6-liter twin-turbocharged V-6, 410 horsepower, 369 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Driver Assist package with Adaptive Cruise Control, Automatic Collision Preparation, automatic braking
Option I can’t live without: No options on this model
Notable standard features on this model: Magnetic Ride Control with rear air springs, heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats, heated steering wheel, adaptive remote start, head-up display, front and rear park assist
You might also be considering: Audi A6, BMW 5 Series, Lexus LS460

You’d be forgiven for looking at the 2014 Cadillac XTS Vsport and thinking it looked more like a cruiser than a sport sedan. Yes, the XTS Vsport is new for 2014, and it packs a 410-horsepower twin-turbo V-6 under the hood. But it also feels huge out on the road and has all the soft luxury touches of a car built for a driver long past his or her street-racing days. As a twenty-two-year-old woman, I’m hardly the kind of person Cadillac was imagining when they built this car. But I drove it for a weekend anyway, and I was surprised to find myself perfectly comfortable in it.

The XTS Vsport is a step up from the base XTS and a step down from Cadillac’s racing-inspired V line in terms of performance. Aside from the more powerful engine, which offers 105 extra horses compared with the XTS’s base 3.6-liter, normally aspirated engine, the Vsport flies under the radar. You won't find any big, screaming badges here. Just one “V” label on the rear bumper and a unique grille announce the larger engine.

Otherwise, the XTS is the picture of Cadillac design and packaging sensibilities. The exterior’s angles and creases fit in perfectly with the rest of the current Cadillac lineup. The interior is swathed in leather and wood and has heated and cooled seats, a heated steering wheel, and an eight-inch color touchscreen with Cadillac’s Cue infotainment system. I fought with Cue on voice commands, which were consistently misunderstood, but if I took the time to manually enter a destination before pulling out of the driveway, the navigation system was effective and accurate.
The Cadillac XTS Vsport is, for better or worse, exactly what I think of when I think of Cadillac.

Cadillac's XTS comes with a choice of two engines, the 410-horsepower twin-turbo V-6 in the Vsport model) or a normally aspirated 3.6-liter V-6 that makes 305 horsepower. Fuel economy with the standard engine is only marginally better than the twin-turbo, at 17 mpg in the city and 26 mpg on the highway for the all-wheel-drive version. When compared with our test car's 16/24 mpg, it's easy to see the value, as well as the fun, in getting the more powerful engine, but be warned: the base price goes up $17,495 immediately when you choose the Vsport.

You also have three trim level choices on the 2014 XTS: Luxury, Premium, and Platinum. The Platinum model we drove has its own set of 20-inch wheels with chrome inserts, a satin-chrome grille finish, and special interior materials and trim. It also has a seemingly endless list of luxury features as standard, including adaptive lighting, heated and auto-dimming outside mirrors, and rain-sensing wipers, and a interior items including a power rear window shade, real wood trim, heated seats and steering wheel, full leather seating with perforated inserts, a leather-wrapped instrument panel, and a head-up display with color readouts. If you're going to go for this kind of car, why not step up and get all the goodies?

Also on the Platinum edition is a standard Driver Assist package that includes adaptive cruise control, automatic collision preparation, and automatic front and rear braking. The 2014 XTS has automatic parking assist that makes easy work of parallel parking. Add that to the standard Driver Awareness package (also standard on the Premium level), which includes lane departure warning, rear cross-traffic alert, side blind zone alert, and forward collision alert, and you've got a full slate of active safety features on board.

The XTS doesn’t really have the character of a sport sedan. Having said that, it would be a good fit for a driver who wants to feel simultaneously comfortable and in control. Our model's all-wheel drive kept the car planted and confident, even during a snow squall. Rear legroom is more than adequate; one adult of above-average height can sit comfortably behind another. Trunk space is stellar; Cadillac claims "five or more suitcases" will fit in there. Our tester’s blue-black exterior with touches of chrome looked upscale and expensive, although maybe not as expensive as its hefty $70,020 asking price might call for. For that price, you could snag one of its German competitors, and a lot of people probably will.

The Verdict:

The Cadillac XTS Vsport is, for better or worse, exactly what I think of when I think of Cadillac. The XTS is built in Canada, but it feels distinctly American. It’s luxurious and powerful, sure. But it also feels a lot like the car of a wealthy retiree. It’s the kind of car you could take almost anywhere without feeling out of place; it blended in with other cars on the streets of Ann Arbor and was perfectly at home on a trip to the Detroit Institute of Arts. The XTS Vsport will serve its driver well, that is without doubt. But during my weekend with the XTS Vsport, I was never convinced that I wouldn’t be served just as well by one of its competitors.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: When I sat on the cushy leather seats and closed the door, the giant instrument panel behind the steering wheel auto-magically lit up—it knew I was there. Creepy? The entire area is a computer screen; there are no actual dials. Three circles come spinning onto the screen, and then, voilà, you have three dials. Awesome. The center instrument panel features an eight-inch touchscreen that was effortless for me to use. The whole front cabin had swoopy lights that were actually a tad distracting. But the entire experience seemed futuristic, and I am hopeful that this is the direction that automakers are headed.

Laura Sky Brown: I am glad Cadillac has grown out of its Best Little Whorehouse in Texas aesthetic, but I would have been disappointed if this XTS had become as sober as a Volvo inside, and it's not. I know Molly thought the light-up instrument panel was creepy, but I rather liked it. Cadillacs should be a bit wacky-luxurious inside. Case in point: how about that swooping glovebox with a separate control on the dashboard that you need to press to flop it open? But as for driving it, there's nothing wacky or soft about that. It felt great: powerful, capable, and smooth. I also appreciate all the safety features on board. If this is, as Annie says, "the car of a wealthy retiree," I feel good knowing that's one more older person whose car is looking out for him or her. And as Molly says, I do hope all cars, and the people driving them, will be so lucky in the future.

I am a recent graduate of Boston University thrilled to be working my first real job (in this case, “real” means I never have to use a mop).  I have previously appeared as a lifeguard, a mailroom lackey, a part-time nanny, and a fudge chef, but the real reason I'm here today is because someone once told me I could write and I believed them. As a writer and publisher for BU’s online magazine, I wrote about politics and current events and wrote two series: Foxy Congressperson of the Week, which is exactly what it sounds like, and An American in Paris, detailing my misadventures abroad.

pageElements.text:
Price: $25,290 base price of this model
$27,710 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 197 horsepower, 184 lb-ft of torque
Transmission: Continuously variable
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/30 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Nismo Alcantara and leather interior with red leather accents
Option I can’t live without: Rockford Fosgate premium sound system (part of $1,170 Navigation package)
Notable standard features on this model: Intelligent Key with push-button start, Bluetooth connectivity, Sirius XM, halogen headlights with auto off; NISMO-tuned engine, transmission, suspension, and steering; NISMO styling cues including gauges, shift knob, grille and spoiler, and mirror covers
Notable options on this model: Navigation package ($1,170) including Nissan navigation system, Rockford Fosgate premium audio, USB connectivity, rearview camera, all with five-inch color touchscreen
You might also be considering: Hyundai Veloster Turbo, Kia Soul, Mini Countryman

I’ve always had a thing for quirky crossovers. When my parents and I were shopping for my first car, I fought hard for a first-generation Scion xB before eventually settling on a 2006 Chevrolet HHR. I’ve since moved on to a more sophisticated ride—although I miss my HHR almost every day—but I still have a soft spot for the weirdos of the car world. Which is why I’ve been itching to drive the undeniably odd Nissan Juke. Even better: when I finally got the chance, it was the 2013 Juke Nismo, the performance version of Nissan’s smallest crossover.

Performance is a relative term, though, and the Juke Nismo we tested was still a far cry from being truly sporty. The 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine makes 197 horsepower and 184 pound-feet of torque. That’s just 11 extra horsepower compared with the base Juke powertrain. Our Juke came outfitted with a continuously variable transmission (CVT), which immediately disappointed me. I was hoping for a six-speed manual transmission, which is available with the front-wheel-drive version of the Juke. Our all-wheel-drive model was only available with the continuously variable transmission, a notoriously sluggish setup.
I have a soft spot for the weirdos of the car world. Which is why I’ve been itching to drive the undeniably odd Nissan Juke.

The Juke Nismo AWD feels nimble and planted on the road, thanks in part to a Nismo-tuned suspension, and it is plenty willing to be tossed around corners. But during my weekend with the Juke, I never stopped wishing for a manual transmission. The CVT got bogged down in the high rpm on acceleration, giving the car an undesirable four-cylinder engine whine soundtrack. I’ve felt for some time now that the best way to enjoy a car with middling power is to drive it with a manual transmission. Focusing on timing shifts just right and executing them well is what turns a decent car into a fun one.

What the Juke Nismo AWD was lacking in driving enjoyment, it makes up for with lovably wacky styling. Starting with the base Juke’s odd, squat body, the Juke Nismo adds a revised grille and front fascia designed to allow more air through the engine bay. Red door mirrors and gloss black B-pillars and door sills, as well as Nismo badging on the grille and the rear, cue the viewer that this is not your everyday Juke. Ours came with sparkling Pearl White paint, and I found the white-and-red color scheme attractively sporty without being obnoxious.

All Juke Nismos come with black cloth seats and interior trim. The interior was comfortable and attractive, if not particularly spacious. I was flummoxed by the controls on the center stack, though. A small screen below the infotainment system showed real-time information about g-forces and torque distribution (helpful, I guess?), but I couldn’t find the climate controls anywhere. Some experimenting revealed that pressing a button above that display labeled “climate” brought up fan direction controls and temperature information, but it was an odd design that I never quite got used to.

The Verdict:

I still have a tender place in my heart for the Nissan Juke, which I think is a fine example of fearlessly strange automotive design. If you’re looking for a car about this size with unusual looks, there aren’t a ton of choices. A Hyundai Veloster Turbo could fill the bill and is fairly fun to drive, but it’s a shade smaller. A Mini has plenty of attitude, but it’s a bit pricier. So the Juke Nismo should be a good Goldilocks option. And from what I’ve heard, the front-wheel-drive Juke Nismo equipped with a manual transmission is genuinely fun to drive. But I was ultimately underwhelmed by this package and what I considered to be its dull transmission. If you’re interested in one of these, shop away! But my advice is, steer clear of the CVT.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: I am often intimidated by cars that manufacturers create specifically for the tuner crowd. The Juke Nismo reeled me in with its red mirrors, white jellybean design, and nice Nismo details on the interior. I especially liked the slice of red leather on the steering wheel. But what really landed me was how fun the Juke was to toss around the mean streets of Ann Arbor. I am a rule follower, but I was weaving and juking around traffic, possibly stretching a law or three.

title: 2014 Toyota Highlander on the Road
promoTeaserSmall: In the all-new SUV, I took the scenic route through California's artichoke-growing Carmel Valley.
promoTeaser: In the all-new SUV, I took the scenic route through California's artichoke-growing Carmel Valley.
metaDescription: 2014 Toyota Highlander Drive: In and around the Carmel Valley in the all-new SUV. Getting there was most of the fun. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $29,880 (four-cylinder LE FWD) to $50,650 (V-6 Hybrid Platinum AWD) (prices include destination)
EPA fuel economy: 20 mpg city/25 mpg highway (four-cylinder FWD); 18/24 mpg (V-6 AWD); 28/28 mpg (Hybrid)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower; 2.7-liter four-cylinder or gasoline-electric hybrid are optional
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Safety features: Safety Connect roadside and emergency assistance, pre-collision system, lane departure alert (part of optional Driver Technology package)
Tech features: Entune audio (6.1-inch touchscreen on LE, adds navigation on XLE, adds App suite and Premium JBL audio on Limited); rear Blu-ray DVD entertainment system (XLE and Limited models)
Chief competitors: Chevrolet Traverse, Honda Pilot, Hyundai Santa Fe, Kia Sorento, Mazda CX-9
I’d like to offer some tips if you ever get invited to Carmel Valley for a press preview of a Toyota Highlander. First, say “Yes!” Do not hesitate. You will not regret it.

Second, make it task one to study your fellow journalists and identify someone who understands you and your car aesthetic (mine is comfortable and fun to drive) and lifestyle (sarcastic, pleasure-seeking). The latter is a matter of simple mathematics. There are more people than cars at these events, so you have to share.

That means spending the day in a car with a complete stranger. Preferring not to ride along with Mr. Toad or chat with someone who thinks vehicle braking technology is a starting place for amusing anecdotes, I have learned to choose carefully.

Before we had the car doors closed, my choice, Jeremy, and I had identified the car’s most brilliant feature, at least from a hedonistic usability point of view: the in-dash shelf with USB and twelve-volt charger. Every car should have this. After a quick tussle for supremacy over shelf space, which resulted in a compromise that allowed us each to have our cell phones at the ready, we did a quick check to see if the Toyota people had stocked the roll-top center console with the fifty-eight juice boxes they claimed it would hold. Fortunately, they hadn’t. “Good,” said Jeremy, carefully studying the interior of this handy storage area. “I don’t think that’s a good use of space. Looks like it might hold enough beer, though.” (Toyota is positioning the car to appeal to a family van demographic, forgetting that parents have the same beverage requirements as other stressed humans.)
“Is it refrigerated?” I asked, thinking it might even hold a bottle of Pinot Gris. (It isn’t.)

Nonetheless, I decided this storage feature alone—as I dropped my oversized purse into it instead of letting my essentials fend for themselves in the back seat—made the 2014 an improvement over last year’s Highlander. Jeremy was more impressed with the crossover’s updated, more masculine exterior styling. “It’s more aggressive,” he said. Which, I’m pretty sure, for a man who doesn’t want to be seen as driving anything like a minivan, is a good thing. The third-row seating didn’t thrill either of us, but I’m sure we’d both be happy for it it if we were trying to fit eight people in the car.

The Highlander has an “LCD multi-information display” in the dash that hosts the smartphone-driven app suite, navigation system, and backup camera. I tossed the printed directions the Toyota people had provided us with in favor of this navigation system, plugging in our first destination.

The scenery was beautiful and the agenda—a tour of local farms where we would load this crossover SUV with room for eight with produce to deliver to a local food bank—was, we had to admit, a nice idea. We did our best to keep with the route, mostly because food was promised at every stop. But we quickly got lost. This happened mostly because the navigation system interrupted us constantly when we were trying to talk. (It should be technically possible to program some manners into these things, don’t you think?) She also mispronounced the Spanish-language street names, which just isn‘t hip in California. So, as cool kids do when faced with a lack of social grace, we ignored her.

When we found ourselves circling the same block for the third time, our human tendencies to blame someone of the opposite sex kicked in. So I switched to Google Maps on my Android phone. (She gets the street names right!) Harmony was restored in the car’s interior, and we were back in the game.

The first stop was at Pezzini Farms, where we viewed artichokes in their natural state: naked of butter or mayonnaise. Artichokes have been growing on this piece of land since the 1940s, we learned. They looked happy, tended carefully in that perfect weather with a stunning ocean view.
Then we ate some, fried and steamed. They were excellent.

Next stop: Tanimura and Antle Farms, where we would learn obvious things about growing lettuce and the fascinating history of water (with politics reminiscent of Chinatown, but without so much incest, face-slapping, or gunplay) and agriculture (Steinbeck said the same thing with more detail on marine science and hookers) in the Carmel Valley. There was a great collection of WPA-era watercolor paintings here that made the history come to life. Best of all, we would be treated to an outstanding lunch with a view of the valley.

After lunch, there was an opportunity for a car change. So Jeremy and I grabbed the Hybrid model and headed off to the food bank, where we put in a couple of solid hours of work sorting donated food for the homeless. We were not good employees. We overthought everything, tired easily, and were distracted by decisions that people who don’t write for a living would not have noticed. After an hour, we began wondering about mandated coffee breaks. After two, we were organizing into labor unions. If we’d stayed another hour, we would have gone on strike.
Fortunately, we jumped back into our SUV before gang violence broke out. “I don’t feel like I really drove this car yet,” Jeremy complained.
Our turn – back to the Carmel Valley Ranch – was ahead. So I missed it.
“Oops.” I said.
“I guess we’ll have to take the long way back,” agreed Jeremy, smiling.
The long way back involved lots of winding, hilly roads with stunning views of wineries and valleys. I drove too fast, turned too sharply, and braked with excessive suddenness.
“How’s it feel?” Jeremy wanted to know.
“Not bad for an SUV.” I said. “It’s not a sports car. But it’s fun.”
This annoyed him. “I better drive," he said.
He drove even faster, weaving up the hill like a maniac reptile at a Disney park. “Yep,” he agreed. “Handles better than the Lexus SUV.”
And then it was time for dinner.

promoTitle: Road Trips with Babies Made Simpler
promoTeaserSmall: Four tips your mom should have given you about taking road trips comfortably with small children.
promoTeaser: Four tips your mom should have given you about taking road trips comfortably with small children.
metaDescription: Road Trips with Babies Made Simpler: Four tips your mom should have given you about taking road trips comfortably with small children. Read them on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Missions to the moon have been executed with less planning and stress, and certainly less stuff, than the annual holiday road trip that millions of families are embarking right about now.

Did you pack your shovel and fire starting kit? How about snacks? Do you have enough snacks, because what if you get trapped in a freak snowstorm for days and no one can find you? Better stash another box of cereal bars and another blanket while you’re at it.

And toys. 
And DVDs. 
And water. 
And cat litter (in case of ice). 
Whatever you do, DO NOT forget to bring the chargers. Yes, all of them for a weekend trip only five hours away.
Was it always like this? I wouldn’t know, having become a parent in the age of Google.

Search for “road trips with kids,” and Google finds 48 million links in 0.38 second. Imagine what they could do with more time. And each article offers tips, strategies, and hundreds of differing opinions on the ten essential products you need for your car in the event you get trapped in an avalanche on the way to Grandma’s house and die. It’s all just one big “to do” list in the middle of the busiest shopping season of the year.
The old adage is true that you can never be overprepared. However, if you try you will most likely be overpacked.
Before you consult The Art of Survival, try asking your parents how they traveled with kids. Chances are good that the tips they offer will have less to do with gadgets and more with common sense:

1. Leave early in the morning to avoid traffic. You can also travel at night to attempt to capitalize on kids' sleep schedules and avoid traffic, but gas stations and restaurants may be closed if you need them.
2. Play road trip games. Sure, nothing keeps kids entertained quite like a movie or iPad, but road trips can be quality family time if you make it fun.

3. Plan for emergencies, but not every emergency: A first aid kit is great, but a snake-bite kit is probably overkill. Maps (the old printed kind), jumper cables, gloves, a spare tire, blankets, candles, water, and nuts were in my mom’s emergency kit. Add cell phone charger to the list and call it good.
4. Be flexible: Planning your route is great, but don’t hold yourself to a schedule or force stops if little ones are sleeping.

contributors.bio: When people ask me how I started writing about cars, I tell them I'm from Detroit. I tell them about my father, who was a Chrysler engineer, and the crazy cars he would bring home to test drive. But before I discovered the glamorous life of an automotive journalist, I was a writer living in the Motor City, covering music and art in the Nineties. Things changed when I became curious about the industry that made the city tick and interned at AutoWeek magazine. I moved to New York City in 2003, where I’ve worked as a freelance writer for almost a decade. I’ve written for more than 100 magazines, newspapers, and websites, including the New York Times, Rolling Stone, Forbes, Jay-z’s Life and Times, Vibe, Automobile Magazine, AutoWeek and the Detroit Free Press. I finished an MFA in creative writing at the New School this year. I live with two car buffs, Lee Quiñones and our four-year-old son, who both think what I do is pretty cool.

pageElements.text: Great works of art and design are ageless, but the work is also a reflection of the era in which it was created. In 2010, the global auto industry was in a precarious place, still reeling from the economic crises that rattled car culture to its core. The demand for change was at its height. The question of how future drivers would interact and use their cars was paramount in the media, as car companies were under pressure to evolve. New fuel sources and car sharing became viable topics discussed by the mainstream media. That spring, BMW announced that the artist Jeff Koons would introduce the seventeenth car in the BMW Art Car Series. There were only seventeen made in the thirty-five years since Alexander Calder created the first car collaboration in 1975. The art cars are part of the BMW Museum’s permanent collection and have been widely exhibited.
When the Koons-BMW partnership was announced, Koons revealed the conceptual nature of his car: kinetic energy. Think “razzle dazzle” and “Christmas tree lights."

When the Koons-BMW partnership was announced, Koons revealed the conceptual nature of his car: kinetic energy. Think “razzle dazzle” and “Christmas tree lights,” as he later described the crisp bursts of red, yellow, black, and blue stripes on the M3. The Koons car made a joyful statement in a pensive era. The car as we know it was still alive.

The ideas surrounding the Koons car seem to bear significant weight three years later as the car made its American debut at Art Basel in Miami, Florida, this December. The setting provided an entirely different context from the 24 Hours of Le Mans, where the Koons car raced in 2010. At Art Basel, it was surrounded by thousands of works of art from contemporary artists that transform the city of Miami into a week-long art capital of ideas and imagery.

The BMW Art Car series has serious roots in contemporary art. Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, and Robert Rauschenberg created art cars that solidified the blueprint for a series that encapsulated serious works of car art. In 2007, Olaffur Eliason made the sixteenth art car into a transformed work of steel and ice, wildly bending the scope of what the art car could be as he examined the resources it takes to make a car. Koons chose to return to a more functional car creation and paid homage to the Warhol with his creation, drawing cues from Warhol’s motorsports aesthetic. His car, too, would race, he asserted when the design was announced.

Koons reflected on the car at the Miami unveiling orchestrated by BMW. He spoke about some of his experiments that led to the final design. “I looked at images of novas exploding and how energy repels against something,” he said. Model Karolína Kurková assisted Koons in the unveiling. Thomas Girst, who heads up BMW Cultural Communications and is also an art scholar, was there on behalf of BMW.
Koons chose to return to the functional with his art car creation, drawing cues from Warhol’s motorsports aesthetic. His car, too, would race, he asserted.

Girst and Koons interacted frequently during the six-month design process, during which Koons worked on the car. “Koons pays homage to Warhol and Lichtenstein, but he is an artist of this time, using methods of the moment,” said Girst. “Koons made the car in the year that energy was discussed at the height of the economic recession, when the future of the car was precarious, and the car shows the possibilities.”

While the current climate has shifted to more banner times for car companies, the discussion about what’s coming in energy has not. The future is still up for grabs. One thing is certain: the art car is not a dead conversation. “With Jeff, it came it around full circle. It tells you that the art car is continuing. It went racing again at the 24 Hours of Le Mans,” said Girst.

The Koons car acts as a bridge between two eras in thinking about the relationship between cars, technology, and energy. During the first era of art cars, the the world was facing its first full-blown fuel crisis, which ended the same year Warhol made his #79 art car. It’s ironic that the Koons car makes it American debut the same year as the BMW officially launched its sustainable driven i brand—a decidedly more technical discussion about energy and mobility. Or perhaps it’s an image that will become more reflective of an era through the lens of time and the eye of one of its most prominent artists. “He is a very tough act to follow,” said Girst.

Three years after the fact, the Koons car makes a statement about what it means to move forward.

title: 2014 Kia Soul !
subTitle: Not as boxy as you think, and just as much fun as you hope.
promoTeaserSmall: Not as boxy as you think, and just as much fun as you hope.
promoTeaser: Not as boxy as you think, and just as much fun as you hope.
metaDescription: 2014 Kia Soul ! The exclamation point  is how I felt about the boxy thing. What did the Peanut Gallery say? Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
2014 Kia Soul Exclaim

Price: $21,095 (base price of this model, including destination)
$26,195 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/31 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Heated power-folding side mirrors
Option I can’t live without: Heated front seats and steering wheel (part of The Whole Shabang package, $2,500)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, Bluetooth connectivity, leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, LED taillights
Notable options on this model: Panoramic sunroof with power sunshade, navigation system with eight-inch screen (part of Sun & Sound package, $2,600); heated and ventilated front seats, heated rear seats and steering wheel (part of The Whole Shabang package, $2,500)
You might also be considering: Fiat 500L, Nissan Cube, Scion xB

Are you pro-hamster or anti-hamster? Chances are you aren’t neutral about those ubiquitous commercials that are meant to sell the Kia Soul to the young and hip. For some, the ads might be a sales disqualifier, because not everybody wants to buy a car that reminds people of strutting rodents, or a car that anybody would call “cute.”

That’s not me; I kind of like the cuteness, and I enjoy the ad campaign. Besides, I already know that the Kia Soul is not only for the young and hip: my next-door neighbor owns one, and she is decades past retirement age. So it was with a bit of a smirk that I brought home the virtual identical twin to her Soul, a frog green (Kia calls the color Alien 2) 2014 Kia in the top trim, Exclaim, which is spelled as ! (Other trim levels are Base and Plus, spelled +.) Yes, you heard that right; Kia has trim levels that are a ! and a +, and a color named after a sci-fi movie. Okay, maybe I don't like cuteness that much.

This is the more buff-looking model, which—as the hamster commercials advertise—has lost some of the kind of puffiness you see in the Fiat 500L and the Mini Countryman, in favor of a more angular appearance. The new look started with Kia’s critically acclaimed Track’ster concept (right) and ended with a longer, wider new Soul, yet it's still just as upright and just about as boxy as the original.

Let’s face it, nobody goes shopping for a car like this who isn’t already interested in standing out from the crowd. It’s the extrovert in the small-car lot, not as much of a goody two shoes as a hatchback, not as outdoorsy as a small SUV, and not as mainstream/conformist as a sedan. I almost wasn’t sure I was cool enough to be seen driving one, but then I remembered my next-door neighbor, who’s in the Opera Club and doesn’t care who knows it. (I guess extroverts come in all age groups.)

And anyway, I welcomed the opportunity to find out whether the buff look extends to the driving experience. And so, Polar Vortex or no Polar Vortex, I headed out in the Soul in search of an ! of a drive.

The ! is the top trim level on the 2014 Soul, and it comes, not surprisingly, with the biggest wheels (eighteen inchers) and the biggest engine (a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 164 horsepower). The base model has sixteen-inch wheels and a 1.6-liter engine making 130 hp. I was glad to have the additional power while driving on heavily snow-covered roads, although having those larger-diameter wheels and tires to plow through the snow means they weren’t as welcome as they would have been on a clear day. Nevertheless, I found the Soul nimble, capable, and stable-feeling. It was quiet inside, navigated the bumps and unevenness of winter roads with aplomb, and generally felt much more expensive and more powerful than it actually is. Since the base model’s fuel economy is nearly the same (24/30 mpg instead of the ! model’s 23/31 mpg), I don’t personally think it’s worth it to lose the 34 horsepower and 33 pound-feet of torque you’re out by getting the lesser model. On the other hand, if you must have a manual transmission, the base model is the only one of the three that has it. I was very comfortable with the six-speed automatic.

The interior has no qualms about looking different. But it’s not different in a tacky way; you’ll be surprised how luxurious it seems for a brand that stuck to the lower end until recently. There’s a rounded theme inside that extends to the oval gearshift base and the dash-mounted speaker. There's an adorable image of the Soul that appears before your eyes when you push the button to start the car. Even the door handles are ovoid in shape. But you'd better hope for less ovoid back-seat passengers; billed as a five-seater, this car would definitely be more fun for four.

Kia’s Uvo telematics system was quick to react and easy to use, there's Pandora radio, and when you get the optional Sun & Sound package ($2,600), you get a big eight-inch touchscreen that satisfyingly commandeers a lot of dashboard real estate. The stereo system is where you know for sure that young drivers are being targeted. Opting for either the Sun & Sound package or the cheaper ($1,400) Audio package gets you an Infinity sound system with a center speaker on the dash that will appeal to your inner hamster, and even the base model has a six-speaker MP3 audio system and a three-month starter subscription to SiriusXM satellite radio.
The interior is different, but not in a tacky way; you’ll be surprised how luxurious it seems for a brand that stuck to the lower end until recently.

But it’s not all upscale sophistication; there are quirks. How about the baffling way the side mirrors fold in automatically when you shut off the car? Possibly appreciated by people who park in really narrow spaces in really crowded urban lots, but I just thought it was weird. There's the "backpack" rear end with Christmas-tree-like vertical LED taillights; I'm not so sure I like that look. But in both cases, you can't deny they help you recognize a Soul as a Soul.

You can get the base Kia Soul with the six-speed manual transmission for $15,695 (including destination). That’s an entry-level price without the entry-level style penalty. More popular, I imagine, will be the midlevel model with the 2.0-liter four-cylinder and the automatic transmission, priced starting at $19,195 (including destination). That’s a budget price without the budget ugliness. But budget for some of the options; you might want that panoramic sunroof (it’s in the pricey $3,000 Primo package), and I don’t know who would not want that big touchscreen.

The 2014 Soul got five stars overall in NHTSA crash testing and the top Good rating in all four categories by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. It stopped short of getting the Top Safety Pick designation for 2014 (although it had it in 2013) because it doesn’t have active safety items for front crash protection such as forward collision warning and autobrake. Otherwise, it gets a clean bill of health for safety, always good to hear about a small car.
It's not just the Soul that has a new look; the whole brand is in transformation, from the luxurious K900 sedan to the GT4 Stinger Concept at the 2014 Detroit Auto Show.

If you don't think the Soul has really changed that much, a quick look at the 2014 Soul (left) compared with its immediate predecessor, the 2013 model (right), will convince you. But it’s not just the Soul that has a new look; the whole brand is in transformation, from the luxurious K900 sedan to the GT4 Stinger Concept that was at Detroit's North American International Auto Show earlier this month. It’s getting to where Kia has completely changed its image. My oldest son used to joke about a commercial that would just say, “Kia. [awkward pause] It’s….a Kia.” That’s because he had too many friends who owned poorly maintained old Kias of the past. This Soul isn’t anywhere in that vicinity. If you don’t believe me, spend a few minutes behind the wheel of one.

The Verdict:

Think of the list of requirements you have when shopping for a new car. If you’re looking for a car that makes you smile whenever you spot it in the driveway, this one could be it. If you’re looking for a small car with a good safety rating? Check. If you want a car under $20,000 that still has a quality feel? This one could do it. But if you want to carry a lot of people or stuff, need a huge amount of power, or have little patience for quirkiness, this might not be the car for you after all. And don’t forget to weigh how much hamster jokes will annoy you (or please you) once you own one of these.

Peanut Gallery:

Molly Jean: The Soul won me over with its combination of quirky and unique styling. The self-folding mirrors make me smile every time, sort of silly but awesome. The interior boasts quality materials and the unique styling continues in the details of the interior. I would choose the gray houndstooth seats, it seems that cars that hover around $20,000 have all black interiors. The diminutive Soul actually feels roomy inside for the driver, and the hatch provides plenty of cargo room. Buyers who wants their car to stand out from the masses need to take the Soul for a spin.

The 2014 Kia Soul was remarkably agile in the snow.
2014 Kia Soul is pretty svelte, just as the hamsters promised.
Interior of the 2014 Kia Soul is pretty luxurious for a small car, and the ovoid/round theme predominates.
Kia Track'ster concept was the harbinger of the new Soul's look.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Don’t cry for me, Argentina…
Dateline: Detroit, Michigan, New Year’s Eve, 14 degrees F

It was 4:45 a.m. when we jumped in the Acura MDX and headed for the airport for our 8:00 a.m. departure for Maui. It takes about an hour to get to DTW. Don’t ask. If he could, Tim Jennings would settle in with a good book at the gate four hours before a flight's departure time. I will admit that a storm was on its way and if we missed the flight to Maui, I would surely die. Not to put too fine a point on it.
Acura MDX Point #1: Great heated seats, but where’s the heated steering wheel?? What did I care? Tim was driving, and I was fast asleep within ten minutes.
This would be our first visit to that particularly fabulous Hawaiian island. We were guests of Hyundai, who generously included my husband so he could carry my bags. As if.
The closest I got to driving a car on Maui was driving a bar stool in the poolside tiki-hut bar and being served by an exceptional waitress named Portia.

I would like to clear the air up front by saying the closest I got to driving a car on Maui was driving a bar stool in the poolside tiki-hut bar and being served by an exceptional waitress named Portia. This was not an official test drive event. Hyundai was there as title sponsor of the PGA Tournament of Champions. We were there for the golf. That’s right, golf.

I golf, but not as seriously as you might imagine. I already have a high-pressure job; I don’t need a high-pressure sport. I have been known to pay my caddy to throw the ball down course when the going gets rough. I didn’t golf in Hawaii, but Hyundai’s charming public relations chief, Chris Hosford, mysteriously came up with a slot in the Pro-Am game for husband Tim, which made him nearly swoon. He was paired with Matt Kuchar (right), a car fanatic and genuinely nice guy who asked me to recommend a beach car for his home on Sea Island, Georgia. That would be a Fiat Jolly, Matt. Check out Jerry Seinfeld and Louis C.K. testing Seinfeld’s Jolly in Comedian in Cars Drinking Coffee.

Instead of hitting the little round white ball, I took a yoga class every morning, got a massage and a facial, did the coastal walk one day, and had an umbrella drink every afternoon. In the evenings, I hung out with Hyundai dealers (you do know how I love good car dealers!), who were still buzzing over the sudden “resignation” of Hyundai’s U.S. CEO, John Krafcik. I don’t read anything into this regarding hard-charging, high-energy engineer Krafcik. He was wildly successful and worked like a demon, but he would not be the first Hyundai boss blown out by the Koreans in the wake of a great sales year. The head of sales, dealer fave Dave Zuchowski, was named to replace Krafcik.

I don't want to dwell on the 85 degrees, the sun, the seas, the whales breaching just offshore, and the warm trade winds, because arriving home to a blizzard after four days in paradise was a way more real reality. If you know what I mean.
The Acura MDX was waiting to suck all the luggage back in its vast hold (there was plenty including golf clubs), and took us home through a raging blizzard.
Acura MDX Point #2: Great heated seats, but where’s the heated steering wheel?? I care!

It hasn't been this cold in Michigan in twenty years anyway. In the old days, we used to count on one weekend where the mercury would hover at -40, -50, even -60 degrees Fahrenheit with the wind chill factor. It has been brutally cold since we arrived home. We saw -20 real degrees on the thermostat two days in a row and a windchill of -35 on Monday. I had to leave the house to come to work because it was too cold in the farmhouse. The howling wind pummeled our house, finding its way inside under every door, through every crack and every bit of loose grout.

I couldn't contemplate sleeping in the icy bedroom, so I ripped the down comforter off the bed and made my way to the couch right in front of the fireplace. Tim went upstairs with Stella (who would just as soon kill Ray the Stray as look at him), while I settled in with the other three dogs. Louie was curled on a thick dog bed next to the couch, and Bob was sprawled on the floor, but Ray crawled right up on top of my chest, spun twice, and curled up like an armadillo. On my chest.

I can make a Chesapeake move out of my spot on the bed, but I cannot make that hound dog move an inch. I cannot make that hound dog do anything that he doesn't want to do. He is fierce. On the other hand, he is also a very, very warm sixty-two-pound pet rock.

Today was the fourth day of solid sub-zero temps. By now, I not only want the Acura to have a heated steering wheel, I want the armrests to be heated, the headliner to be heated, and the windows to be heated.
Overpasses are skating rinks, glinting in the morning sun, which I find easiest to traverse by putting my two outside wheels on the snowy shoulder for support.

The roads are still a disaster out here. Even the freeway ramps are just packed snow. One of three freeway lanes is actually cleared. Overpasses are skating rinks, glinting in the morning sun, which I find easiest to traverse by putting my two outside wheels on the snowy shoulder for support.

I was surprised to find a bad shudder throughout the Acura at more than 65 miles an hour on the freeway. I suspected snow in the wheel wells, and when it didn't get better after ten miles, I pulled in to a gas station for a look. I kicked giant chunks of snow out of all four wheel wells but could do nothing about the ice that had packed the right rear wheel itself.

I took off, and after about five miles, the ride straightened out considerably. It was just too brutally cold to hit the car wash, even though car washes use heated water. I just wasn’t prepared to deal with the resulting frozen door locks and iced-over windows and frozen window winders and so on.

The North American International Auto Show kicks off this weekend for the press, and a warm spell is predicted. That means it will be 45 degrees and raining, and I couldn’t be happier. Bring on the sleet! Bring on the slush! Because right now, the Acura’s floorboard is so cold that, even using heat aimed at the floor, my feet are frozen.

Love,
Jean

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: In the years since my daughter, Rory, was born, we’ve had our share of girly mother-daughter outings: visits to the hair salon, ladies’ tea, and the American Girl store. Last MLK Day, my daughter had the day off from school,  and I suggested another kind of excursion, her first North American International Auto Show in Detroit.  My parents took my sister, brother, and me. Now it was her turn.

I had my concerns about how this would go, since there’s a certain way one does the auto show. The goal is to sit in as many vehicles as possible, which takes hours. And up until that day, Rory had exhibited only a passing interest in cars. While driving, if I yelled out: “Look look look! It’s the brand-new Ford Escape!” she would muster a halfhearted “Oh, Mom, that’s great.”

Also, there is the endless walking. The show covers what feels like like a million square feet of the Cobo Center convention hall in Detroit. That’s once you get inside. First you have to withstand the cruel run from even the closest possible parking through the bone-chilling winds. We’re talking lung-stopping icy air that rips through the absurdly light jacket you wear, even though it’s January in Michigan, because you plan to skip the coat check line.
The massive digital walls screamed “spectacle,” and her nine-year-old eyes lit up like we were in Cinderella’s castle.

On entering the expansive show floor, though, Rory was dazzled. Bright lights bounced off perfectly polished metal, chrome, and plastic. Futuristic concept cars spun on glamorous revolving platforms, the massive digital walls screamed “spectacle,” and her nine-year-old eyes lit up like we were in Cinderella’s castle. But would she last from the first Acura to the last Z coupe?

Maybe I shouldn’t have worried. Automobiles have fascinated humans since they first puttered past the horse and buggy, and given the right presentation, my daughter was not immune. While I lusted after the Tesla Model X—I'm a sucker for a car with falcon-wing doors—her tastes ran from the very small to the ridiculously huge. I couldn’t get her away from tiny cars like the Smart Fortwo, the Minis, or the new Fiat 500. “It’s just my size!” she exclaimed.

The reverse was true when we approached a humongous Jeep, roll bar exposed and monster tires looming large.  She happily waited a good ten minutes behind a bunch of other kids, and, ahem, grown men, to literally climb up into the seats.

When I was a kid, the thrill was simply getting the chance to sit in a fresh-off-the-line Corvette. Now manufacturers have added high-tech interactive displays. At the Michelin booth, we could feel what it’s like to Be the Tire by standing on a road-approximating pedestal. Subaru’s giant touchpad not only took our picture but allowed Rory to place us in a beach scene with a bright blue BRZ, surfboard, tent, and even a bald eagle swooping at our heads. Once complete, we e-mailed the final picture off to my husband via the same touchpad.
In the Mazda simulator, Rory was nervous when I secured her five-point harness, but fear gave way to giddiness as we were pitched into each curve of the virtual Laguna Seca racetrack.
I couldn’t get her away from tiny cars like the Smart Fortwo, the Minis, or the Fiat 500. “It’s just my size!” she exclaimed.

Midday, we refueled with $10 hamburgers in the glass-walled food court and watched the freighters passing along the Detroit River. I found myself telling Rory the stories my parents had told me whenever we were downtown. The Motor City was the land of opportunity when they came in 1949, and even as the city declined, they wanted to make sure we kids still appreciated that legacy. For Rory, the city’s current struggles are eclipsed by the inspiring Detroit destinations she loves: a Tigers baseball game, the Thanksgiving Day Parade, and the Detroit Institute of Arts.

That January day, she added another event to her list: the auto show. After lunch, we tied our coats around our waists and began Round Two. As we slipped back into the sea of auto lovers from every walk of life, I knew she was hooked. “Oh, Mom, let’s make sure we find that Lincoln that everyone is talking about.”

If you're in the area, this year's North American International Auto Show opens to the public on Saturday, January 18, and runs through Sunday, January 26. The show is open 9 a.m. to 10 p.m., except the final day, when it closes at 7 p.m. You can buy online tickets here.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: As a geek, I liked the idea of this BMW i3 even before I got behind the wheel. It’s an all-electric car made with sustainably sourced materials. And it’s designed to live in a city, with a flexible exterior that can sustain bumps and small altercations without chipping its manicure or getting bruised. It appealed to the San Franciscan in me.

But the ultra-connectedness of it is amazing. A tap to an app on my smartphone or Samsung Gear watch, and it will honk its horn so I can find it. Did I lock it? A glance to my phone will tell me. And it will buzz my phone or watch when the battery is charged so I can keep shopping till it’s ready to go. It will let me locate a charging station—one that’s not in use—from an app on the dash. And it displays the apps on my phone on the dash so I can stay connected to my social world while I commute.

It has long frustrated me that my car is so much less tech-savvy than my smartphone. But this car works brilliantly with my phone to keep me connected, informed, and listening to my own music. I was thrilled finally to find a car that appealed to the Silicon Valley geek in me. It even looks, with LED lighting behind glass in the rear, like a smartphone.

But I didn’t quite expect to like driving it. It’s cute, but not in an aggressive way. It’s sporty, it’s ultra-greenness, and it's sustained materials: leather tanned with olive-leaf extract, environmentally refined wood in the dash, and a combination of wool and recycled plastic in the door panels. The BMW i3 is an emblem of modern, green style.
The one-pedal system has a brake, but you don’t really need it except when you start the car and need a place to slam your foot if someone cuts you off.

I was warned that driving it was a very different experience. The one-pedal system has a brake, but you don’t really need it except when you start the car and need a place to slam your foot if someone cuts you off. You just push your foot on the ultra-sensitive accelerator to go faster and ease your foot off the accelerator to slow or stop. And there is no real gearshift. You turn a lever forward to drive and turn it backward to reverse. Push the Park button to park. No-brainer simple. In fact, the word “golf cart” came to mind during the learning portion of my test drive. How much fun could that be?
The cars around me seemed stupid, clumsy, and slow by comparison.  I was driving a car from the future, and everyone else was still stuck in a messy, lumbering past.

But as soon as I got moving, I liked the car right away for the precision of the controls. Once I got used to it, there was no hesitation between my will and its action. Then I got to a straightaway with no traffic ahead and accelerated to pull away from the crowd.

I left those smelly combustion-engined vehicles behind me in a silent second as I launched into light speed from a near stop. All thoughts of “golf cart” were gone, leaving me with just a gleeful, “Wheeee!”

Like I said, I’m a geek. And my first thought was, “Spaceships are almost here!” It was fun, accurate, and agile. The cars around me seemed stupid, clumsy, and slow by comparison. I was driving a car from the future, and everyone else was still stuck in a messy, lumbering past. My first question when I got out of the car was, “How much?" (as I mentally reached for my wallet).

The answer? Pricing (before federal or local incentives) starts at $42,275, including destination charge; it will be $46,125 for the Range Extender model, which has a small motorcycle engine that serves only to charge the battery and extend the range. It goes on sale in the United States in the second quarter of 2014. So it won't be that long before you can try it for yourselves.
