contributors.bio: I'm a trial attorney, car blogger, and motorsports enthusiast whose idea of fun is going to Detroit in January or watching a six-hour endurance race. A native Texan, I currently live and work in the Austin area. When I'm not in the courtroom, you can find me driving my red Mini John Cooper Works, wrangling my pets or enjoying some delightful Texas cuisine (Tex-Mex and barbecue!). In 2013, I started a blog, Motorista, to document my car adventures and opine on all things auto related. The courtroom is no longer a man's world, and the car world won't always be, either!

pageElements.text: I’m the kind of person who goes to Detroit in January by choice. Not because I have to, or because it’s part of my job. Because I want to.
Why?

The Detroit Auto Show. For a car enthusiast like me, the Detroit Auto Show is better than Christmas: literally acres of new cars spread out before you, with a palpable feeling of excitement and anticipation. I attended for the first time in 2012 and quickly decided that I had to make this a yearly pilgrimage. Last year I was very fortunate to get a personal tour of the hottest new introductions as part of the Jean Knows Cars Group of Seven. This year, when JKC heard I was coming again, they offered to let me tag along during the press days. So I flew up from Texas, camera in hand and grin on face, to experience the 2014 Detroit Auto Show press days.

Being a car enthusiast, and a bit of a leadfoot, I headed straight for the sexy sheetmetal. This year, that means the 2015 Chevrolet Corvette Z06. The new Corvette is striking anyway, and the Z06 takes that presence to the next level. It’s a mean and visceral car. To look at it is to want it.

I was even more excited to see the Corvette C7.R, the new racing Corvette. I live near Circuit of the Americas, the new racetrack in Austin, and I love watching the Corvette race there. It is loud, brash, and faster than stink. The new C7.R promises to carry on that tradition, and I can’t wait to see it on the track.

The SRT Viper also has a fabulous presence. Newly revamped after a short hiatus, it looks as Viper-ish and mean as ever, but with a certain panache that was lacking in prior iterations. Like the Corvette, I look at the Viper and I want it. I want to touch it and sit in it, but mostly I want to drive it.

Speaking of good ol’ American muscle, the redesigned 2015 Ford Mustang also caught my eye. I like the new design, particularly the more pronounced fastback roofline. To my eye, it looks more substantial and sophisticated than prior versions, likely because Ford is making a big global push with the new Mustang. I think they’ve got a winner.

I can’t talk about the Mustang without mentioning the big news of the day, the all-new 2015 Ford F-150. True, I am not a likely F-150 owner, but you can’t throw a stick without hitting one in Texas. A lot of people I know will buy an F-150 in the next few years, so it was fun to watch the brand-new version (literally) drive onto the world stage at Ford’s press conference this morning. It's continuously the bestselling vehicle in America, and you and I will be seeing much, much more of the new F-150 very soon. Luckily, it looks good!

I hope to also see more of the Mazda Clubsport 3 concept. Yes, as a longtime Mini owner, I’m a sucker for a hot hatch, and the Clubsport jumped out at me with its combination of cheeky attitude, sportiness, and utility (did I mention I love hatchbacks?). The Clubsport looks great inside and out, and I could have wept for joy to see its six-speed manual transmission, an all-too-rare feature these days.

In contrast to the little Mazda, the new 2015 Mini disappointed me. I have been a Mini owner since 2004, first with a base Cooper and more recently with a John Cooper Works. The look and feel of the Mini is almost second nature to me. And the look and feel of the 2015 Mini is not what I was hoping for. The styling has morphed from quirky to cartoonish, and the new interior feels cheaper. I know Mini wants to continue to expand its audience, but its larger models, such as the Countryman, are already doing that. I wish the new hardtop hewed more closely to its roots: that unique combination of personality, performance, and quality. I did not see nearly enough of those three characteristics.

I really wanted to love the Kia GT4 Stinger concept, since its name alone is fabulous. Kia has made huge strides in design lately, and I had high hopes for the Stinger. Alas, it didn’t appeal to me that much. The design struck me as an amalgam of different styles and elements that did not quite work together. Too bad. On the other hand, Kia’s new K900 sedan looks seriously upscale.

Other cars that caught my eye today: the Audi Allroad Shooting Brake concept, another hatchback (do you detect a trend here?) with beautiful design details. The Audi RS7, a beast of a performance sedan with the most beautiful roofline on a car today. The Mercedes-Benz CLA45 AMG with its exquisite taillights. The Jaguar F-Type coupe, which I truly want to drive out the front door. I doubt I would get far, but if I could make it out the door, they would never catch me!

What a great day of cars, cars and more cars. I can’t wait to go back and look at them all over again, and to see what new and exciting things will be revealed on Tuesday. Another fabulous sports car, perhaps?

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: We went directly to the top of the design food chain at General Motors, to the big boss, Ed Welburn, for a few words on the most powerful Chevrolet Corvette in its history.

The Z06 is lower, wider, and built for the racetrack, sporting a big, honking 625-horsepower supercharged V-8 and a seven-speed transmission with automatic rev matching. While waiting for my own hot laps when the snow melts (heavy sigh), I asked Ed to tell us what it took to transform the look of the seventh-generation Corvette into a Z06.

pageElements.text: One thing about an auto show floor: there’s a lot to stimulate the senses. Among the candy-colored sports cars and flashy new-model introductions, you would be forgiven if you had not immediately found yourself riveted by a Volvo. And yet, the clean but rugged lines of the Concept XC Coupe did get noticed.

The Concept XC Coupe was named Best Concept Vehicle at the 2014 North American International Auto Show. It was also the recipient of the first ever award for Innovation in the Use of Color, Graphics, and Materials. Both prizes were announced Tuesday night at the EyesOn Design Awards ceremony in Cobo Center, at the end of the second day of the media previews in Detroit.

The judging panel for this awards ceremony is impressive, made up of more than thirty current or former design chiefs at car companies and heads of schools that focus on automotive design. The lead judges were Chrysler design chief Ralph Gilles, Ford’s retired design chief Jack Telnack, and Chuck Pelly, founder of The Design Academy (and a former EyesOn Design lifetime achievement award winner). They were joined by a star-studded judging group including the creative directors and design chiefs of the world’s top auto companies. It has to be an incredible moment when your peer group, the top car designers in the world, pick your design. It is undoubtedly the Detroit auto show’s most prestigious award for the car design community.

About the award-winning Volvo: It is a preview of the upcoming 2015 XC90, but it’s also a showcase for the Swedish automaker’s future design direction and its newly minted Scalable Product Architecture, or SPA. In English, that means that the designers have freed themselves from the tyranny of cross-brand platforms and can make something really, well, Swedish.
In my opinion, a Volvo should seem capable, safe, and a little iconoclastic, and the Concept XC Coupe is definitely all of that, plus so clean and so Scandinavian!
For some time now, Volvo has been introducing not just concepts but actual production cars that are exquisitely tailored, very modern, and yet clearly Volvos.

As Jean put it: “It must have been difficult to choose the winner because there were several stunning concepts there. At the same time, it’s very gratifying to see Volvo win this award from their design peers. For some time now, Volvo has been introducing not just concepts but actual production cars that are exquisitely tailored, very modern, and yet clearly Volvos. There are car companies out there who are trying every design trick in the book to make a statement, trying to find their way, trying to express a national identity which is extremely difficult when your designer pool comes from all over the world. It looks effortless for Volvo. Bravo!”

This Concept XC Coupe is the second in a series of three. The first, the Concept Coupe (right), was introduced at the Frankfurt Auto Show last fall. It's a futuristic version of the classic Volvo P1800. Anybody who appreciates the old Volvos has to appreciate the homage, even if twenty-one-inch wheels and “the powerful calmness of a lion” (as the automaker described it) don’t come to mind when you think back to Volvos of the Sixties. Can’t wait to see the third in this concept trio.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: When Ford announced a one-year partnership with Rent the Runway (RTR), I was slightly confused. RTR is a service where members can rent designer dresses and accessories for 90 percent off the retail price. I wondered how the partnership would work. If you purchase a Ford, you drive out of the dealership in a designer gown? Perhaps Ford throws in a free RTR rental or two depending on the vehicle you purchased? Or maybe RTR was consulting on the interior fabrics that would be used in upcoming models?

I attended a press conference at the North American International Auto Show, where Ford senior interior designer Anthony Prozzi, co-founder of RTR Jennifer Fleiss (I don’t believe she is related to Heidi), and Ford’s marketing manager of global cars and crossovers, Amy Marentic, enlightened us on this somewhat odd relationship. They went to great lengths to explain how the two brands are focused on saving their buyers time. Ford has chosen the Fusion as the vehicle portion of the initiative and points out its time-saving features of keyless entry, easy-fill capless gas tank, and park assist.

Prozzi shared his passion for design and talked about how he has been influenced in the interior of the Fusion and more recently the F-150 by the fashion industry. Fleiss shared the time-saving virtues of being able to shop for designer clothing from any device that can connect to the Internet. I left the press conference unclear on why these two companies were forming an alliance.

Once I returned to my office and started to dig through the RTR website, I realized that Ford is brilliant. According to Fleiss, RTR has five million members with an average age of twenty-eight, and a majority of the members hold a college degree. The demographics of these women are enough to give a grown marketing exec heart palpitations.
After foraging through the site, I am hoping to be invited to an event worthy of this Allison Parris dress or this Kate Spade number.

You look through the website and select a dress from one of the 170-plus designers on the RTR roster, and then you order it much as you'd order a movie from Netflix. You choose a guaranteed delivery date, and your dress comes in the mail. You are even sent two sizes of your choice to ensure you get a good fit. You can select four or eight days as the rental period. Then, simply pop it into a postpaid bag and return it. They even dry-clean it for you when they get it back.

Rent the Runway has a social network on its site: customers can post photos of themselves in the dresses and comment about how they fit, so you can imagine the dress on someone other than a model. I found it helpful to see the dresses on the different body styles. But the real genius part for me, is I would not have to look at the dress in my closet for the next twenty years. If you wear a fabulous designer dress to an event, it is unlikely you want to wear it to another event where some of the same people may attend. But who can keep track?

Back to the partnership. What does this mean to you? Beginning this week and running through June, you have a chance to win a Ford Fusion and a $1,000 gift card to RTR. In addition, there will be pop-up events in Los Angeles and New York in the spring where the Fusion will be on display and you can actually try on RTR dresses and accessories.

It is refreshing to see an automaker that understands how important women are to its bottom line. If Ford can get a fraction of these women to consider purchasing a Fusion, someone is going to have earned a promotion.

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: We call our Chesapeake Bay retriever Bob "the reluctant show dog" because he'd really rather be out hunting with Tim or hanging around with our other dogs than on the show circuit. At least, that's what we used to think. Lately he has been on a serious winning streak.

This past weekend, at the Michigan Winter Dog Classic, he won Best of Breed all four days (in a field of nineteen to twenty-one Chessies). In the capable hands of handler John Benoit, Bob also had his best finish ever, third in the highly competitive Sporting group.

This was his last show before Westminster. The Westminster Kennel Club's 138th annual show is February 10 and 11 in New York City, and Tim and I will be there and hoping not to jinx GCH Irish's Robert Garcia de Padua, a.k.a. Bob, during his big moment in the national spotlight.
He'll train by standing very still in the kitchen for the next three weeks, begging.

We will know soon whether he is the number-one Chessie in the 2014 standings. That won't last long, because we don't show him much, so once we see the official standings, we'll print it out, guzzle good champagne, and keep it in the box with the ribbons.
Craft ideas for displaying a couple hundred ribbons are welcome...

pageElements.text: I moved to Detroit last weekend to zero in on the North American International Auto Show’s dinners, parties, television opportunities, and then…two full days of cars and their designers. This year was totally overrun as never before by 5,169 journalists (from sixty countries, including Mongolia and Qatar) battling for a scrap of quote, a minute of an executive’s time, floor space, press kits, and all the cool USBs they could grab. The humanity (oh, the humanity!) was the stuff claustrophobia is made of. And I can’t say enough bad things about video crews from Russia.
But first, a hat.

On Sunday night before the show floor opened, Mercedes-Benz had a huge party at the historic Book Cadillac hotel (GM execs from out of town live upstairs) to unveil the new C-Class sedan and GLA45 AMG, the hotted-up version of its compact crossover. It was a mob scene. M-B takes over a floor of the hotel and has a suitably upscale cocktail and roving dinner party for an SRO crowd, which it entertained with the very funky Detroit Rollers. I throw the word "funk" out there specifically because the wildly stylish keyboard player was none other than Amp Fiddler, of Parliament-Funkadelic, one of my most favorite bands in the whole world.

I had worn my very best and coolest, my voodoo top hat from Barbara Feinman of New York City, and earlier in the evening I spied Mr. Fiddler and his fabulous chapeau at the very moment he spotted mine across the thousands of hatless revelers. We came like zombies toward each other and were trading milliner information before our own names. His hat came from Cha Cha’s House of Ill Repute. Cha Cha and I have already been in touch; stay tuned.

All right then.

Monday began with a technical meltdown that canceled my live appearance on the CBS Morning Show, so I joined the entire JKC staff at Cobo Center, deployed with the wildly ambitious intention of completing a dozen videographed designer walkarounds of the hottest new releases, all the while Tweeting and reporting the news and gossip before it fell to the floor.

I was in charge of the videos, with our resident artist Scott Allen behind the lens and senior editor Molly Jean (our spare Jean) keeping us on schedule. Molly also kept running shot lists for B-roll, took still photography, and even taped the English simultaneous translation of Lexus chief designer Yasuo Kajino's comments on the radical RC F concept as we sidled around the car, trying to stay out of the camera’s way. Freelance videographer Garrett Sammons and design student Joe Boniface followed in our wake, capturing B-roll details.

Executive editor Laura Sky Brown was the live reporter, accompanied by freelance photographer Susan Campbell, and Anna Eby, our friend from last year’s G-7 consumer panel, who couldn’t stay away and took her own notes. She’s a lawyer from Texas, so you know she’s opinionated. Her stories and photos are here and here.

Over the course of Monday and Tuesday, we managed to film more than a dozen videos of the hottest cars at the show, as explained by the most talented and fun designers in the world. They are being edited; the first one, on the Kia Stinger Concept, is up now, and the others will roll out over the course of the next couple of months.
So of course I drove nothing. And I’ve driven nothing since I left on Tuesday.
You know how you're supposed to stop skiing about an hour before the ski lift closes, because that's when all the accidents happen? Right.

You know how you're supposed to stop skiing about an hour before the ski lift closes, because that's when all the accidents happen? Right. At 5:00 p.m., the last day of our press day coverage, I trotted up the Mayan temple that was the tall, shiny white altar to the Nissan Sport Sedan Concept parked at the top, made it up the steps in my clogs...and took a face plant in front of about 100 journalists in the tiers facing the stage.
I flipped on my back like a turtle and saw them all frozen in silence and said, "Please go back to what you were doing. Everything is fine."

An exceptional Nissan PR representative rushed to my side and said: "We have no ice, Jean, but I brought you this cold beer bottle.  You could put that on your ankle." I looked at him and said, "Go find a cold water bottle, and open that beer."

I limped off, pretty sure it was just a bad sprain, but the next day it hurt so bad that I actually went to the doctor. I got an X-ray and, yes, it was broken. In less than a week I was flying to London with Bentley, bringing along videographer Scott Allen. Bentley had arranged for me to meet my millinery god, Philip Treacy, and go through the Isabella Blow exhibit in London. I would then carry on to the Maison & Objet furniture show in Paris, where Bentley designers were showing the Bentley Furniture collection. There was no way I was missing that!

So as you read this, I am stumping around London, meeting Philip Treacy, and then on my way to Paris to bring back a couple of really great videos. There is so much exciting news about Jean Knows Cars that I can't even begin to tell you, but I can't wait for you to see what we will have coming up.
2014 is going to be a year to remember here. Tell your friends to jump on board! This is going to be not just a great year for us, but a wonderful year for you.

contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: Auto insurance generally does not fall into the category of “things about which people worry.” One picks a policy, and then it fades into the background, simply a monthly deduction that appears on your bank statement.  You might read the often copious correspondence you get from your insurer, or, if you’re like me and you let mail stack up, you might not.  Sound familiar?

Complacency is not your friend. Twice in the last three years, I’ve had insurance shockers. The first was right before my divorce was final. In a rare moment, I happened to be going through the mail in a timely manner, only to open a letter sent from our insurance company stating that my soon-to-be ex- husband had canceled our policy. I was no longer insured. Nice. Apparently it did not occur to him to tell me. After uttering a few choice phrases, I did what most of us do: I got on the computer and the phone, compared rates with companies, and went with the lowest offer.
I remember a moment of panic when I thought I had handed the officer the suddenly defunct insurance information. Would he believe my story of my insurance being canceled?

The very next day, I happened to be pulled over, my first time in twenty-five years. I remember a moment of panic when I thought I had handed the officer the suddenly defunct insurance information. Would he believe my story of my insurance being canceled?  Then, as he smiled, apologized for pulling me over, and, with a “put your broken headlight on the top of your list, please,” sent me on my way, I was thanking my lucky stars for having read my mail.

Having sorted out my insurance, I was set forever, right? This past July, when I went to sign my lease for my Fiat 500, I simply called my insurance company, added the Cinquecento, received my proof of insurance via e-mail, and all was in order. Or so I thought.

Four weeks ago, I noticed that my monthly premium appearing on my bank statement did not seem as high as it should be. I went to my stack of piled-up mail, opened my insurance statement, and discovered the Fiat was not on it. I looked at my proof-of-insurance card: expiration August 31, 2013.

I called the insurance company. For reasons neither they nor I understood, they had only insured the car for a month, and they had not even processed the Fiat. For four months, I had been driving my Fiat uninsured, and that included a trip in the snow to Cleveland for a hockey tournament! I mentioned this to a fellow hockey parent, who happens to be a police detective, and his eyes widened and he said, “Oh Catherine, that is bad. Very bad.”
Bad indeed. The phrase “put you under the jail” comes to mind.
In that moment, I learned the value of having a relationship with an agent who personally attends to your matters, rather than a company with an anonymous representative.

In that moment, I learned the value of having a relationship with an insurance agent who personally attends to your matters, rather than an insurance company with an anonymous representative on the phone. I needed an agent.

As it happens, Nathan Lamb, my bank manager at Chase who saw me through the financial machinations of my divorce, had recently left the bank and moved to Farm Bureau Insurance. He missed working directly with clients and relishes helping them shape their financial security. I called Nathan immediately, and as we talked, I realized that auto insurance is part of a much larger picture.  I didn’t have a clear understanding of what it entails, the options available, and the choices we should make.

So on a very snowy January 2 (one reporting lots of auto accidents), Nathan and I sat down over a long coffee. My insurance needs are now addressed. In the next few weeks, I'll be sharing some of the tips he shared with me. Meanwhile, go have a quick look: Is your insurance in order?

pageElements.text: January of one of the worst winters in decades, and the unthinkable happens: a Saturday morning phone call, a death in the family, and we need to drive to Washington, D.C., immediately.

Three children and I, a week's worth of luggage, and the dog were not all going to fit in the Fiat 500, and the ’02 Odyssey needed servicing that couldn’t happen on such short notice, so we decided to rent another minivan for the drive.

At the counter, I blithely declined the insurance Hertz was offering, having recently sorted out my auto insurance, and my Hertz agent was not pushy, given the bereavement situation.  Yet, on the return leg, as I was driving on the Ohio Turnpike in some of the worst conditions I have ever experienced—a highway covered in snow, whiteout visibility, and the side of the road littered with cars and semis having hit ice and one another—I wondered, with a slight pit in my stomach, about the “loss of use” policy I had heard an agent hawking to a young couple next to me at the Hertz counter. My first phone call on my return was to my agent, Nathan Lamb, to talk about insurance and car rentals.  Here are five questions I had answered.

1. What is covered by your own insurance when you drive someone else’s car or a rental car?

If you have comprehensive coverage, your insurance policy extends to any car you are driving: your personal vehicle, your friend’s pickup truck, or the cute little convertible you chose to rent on your weekend getaway. Damage to your friend’s pickup would be covered by his policy; your policy covers you for your liability while driving his car. The cute convertible? You will have the same coverage for the rental convertible that your policy provides for your own car. It's a good idea to check your car insurance policy to make sure before you rent.

2. What about “loss of use” coverage?

“Loss of use” extends above and beyond most people’s insurance. While your personal policy will provide you the same coverage for an accident in a rental car that it would for your own vehicle, it does not cover the losses the rental car agency experiences by having one of the cars in their fleet out of service. They can’t rent out a car that is in the shop, hence “loss of use.” “Loss of use” policies offered by the rental car agency protect you against the daily charge, which varies by vehicle, that rental agencies charge to recoup their losses while the rental vehicle is out of commission. That charge can be as much as $100 per day. The rate you would pay for “loss of use insurance” is calculated by the number of days for which you rent the vehicle. If it’s $8 a day, and you are looking to rent the car for ten days, you are adding $80 onto your rental bill. That might seem a little steep, but Nathan pointed out that this winter many body shops have two-to-three-week wait. We had a foot of snow while we were in the Washington area, and Virginia drivers are not known for their winter driving skills. What if the person sliding through that stop sign had actually hit me? It may have been a small dent, but the body shop could have taken fifteen days to get to it. Suddenly, I could have been looking at $1,500 to the rental car agency for “loss of use,” even though the accident wouldn’t have been my fault. $80 seems like a bargain compared with the $1,500 I could have been out. Nathan’s recommendation: always get the “loss of use” insurance.

3. How old do I have to be to rent a car?

We recently did an article about millennials renting vehicles to test them out for lifestyle fit. Note that those drivers were in the twenty-five-to-thirty-four-year-old age range. Many agencies do not rent to drivers under twenty-five, a policy that gave me fits two decades ago as my driving record was spotless compared to my “responsible” friends a couple of years ahead of me. If the agencies do rent to younger drivers or allow the second driver to be younger, most require the driver to be at least twenty-one, and the price for those in the under-twenty-five bracket is higher than for those twenty-five and above. There are some benefits to getting older.

4. Who can drive the rental vehicle?

Typically, any driver who is not a spouse or a domestic partner should be listed on the rental contract. That said, rental companies often require verification of licenses for all drivers, including spouses or domestic partners. Moreover, some companies charge an additional fee for additional drivers, but that varies by company and state law. Additional drivers must meet the minimum age requirements. There go my sixteen-year-old daughter’s dreams of getting in some highway driving in the rental car when we do the East Coast college tour in April.

5. Are bereavement rates a decent savings?

I was actually at a hockey tournament in Downriver Detroit when I received that phone call, so my dear and savvy friend Simone took care of arranging the rental car details for me. She discovered that many of the national rental agencies offer bereavement fares. You have to be a direct relation and be prepared to have the name of the deceased and the hospital or coroner’s information. It may be the last information you want to think about at times like this, but the savings are substantial.

We made it back safely from our unexpected January journey east.  Indeed, the Dodge Caravan was akin to driving a tank, and, as much as I love my Fiat, I’m glad we weren’t driving her during the whiteout on I-90. Next time I rent a car, I’ll think of the multitude of accidents we saw that day, and when the agent asks me about insurance, I’ll say “yes” to “loss of use” and drive off the lot comforted by the fact that I’m fully covered.

Want even more detail? The Insurance Information Institute offers this video explaining the types of coverage you'll be offered at the rental counter.

)

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: The cleverly named ConceptCar project is a joint initiative of the Helsinki Metropolia University of Applied Sciences and the bio and forest industry company UPM. The concept car will be shown at the Geneva International Motor Show in March.

What makes this concept car unique from all others is hidden in the materials. Not only will this vehicle be powered by a renewable diesel fuel made from bark, stumps, and branches, the car itself will be made of various bio-based materials. The frame, for instance, uses tree pulp and plywood. The idea behind the project is to show how to use sustainable materials instead of fossil fuels and plastics.

Best of all, this concept car is street legal and is expected to meet European crash standards. In fact, according to the website Good News Finland, the concept went out for road testing last summer, during a rain storm, "to eliminate concerns that a wood car cannot handle exposure to water."

I like the idea of being able to take a concept car out on the road. At a time when our oceans are becoming increasingly polluted and our landfills are overflowing, it is exciting to see an emphasis on green design that is a step forward technologically but keeps one eye on Mother Earth.

title: 10 Cheapest Cars with Active Safety
promoTeaserSmall: What's the price of entry for the newest active safety features? Automobile Magazine  tells us.
promoTeaser: What's the price of entry for the newest active safety features? Automobile Magazine  tells us.
metaTitle: 10 Cheapest Cars with Active Safety - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 10 Cheapest Cars with Active Safety: What's the price of entry for the newest active safety features like lane departure warning, blind spot detection, and forward collision warning? Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
This story comes to us from our brother publication, Automobile Magazine.

The trickle-down theory may be best known for its economic application, but it’s an idea that’s relevant to the automotive sphere as well, especially in regard to safety. Features like antilock brakes, airbags, and stability control first came about in high-end luxury sedans and gradually propagated to more mainstream vehicles before eventually becoming required standard equipment in all cars sold in the United States.

These days, active safety technologies are making their way into more affordable, mainstream cars and are even factored into the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s vehicle safety ratings.

We compiled a list of the least expensive new vehicles that are equipped with a basic suite of active safety technologies. Each qualifying car had to be equipped with the following: a blind spot monitor (BSM), a lane departure warning system (LDW), forward collision warning (FCW), and a backup camera. Just as a refresher, we’ll explain what each of these systems do.

- Blind spot monitor (BSM): uses lenses or other sensors to detect if another vehicle has entered in either the left or right blind spot areas. It then displays a visual and/or audio warning to alert the driver of the other vehicle’s presence.

- Forward collision warning (FCW): uses radar, laser, and/or camera sensors to detect an impending collision. From there, systems vary on what action is taken. Some notify the driver with flashing lights and an audio warning, whereas some also ready the seatbelt pretensioners in the case of a crash. Higher-end FCW systems can also engage the brakes to help lessen the impact speed or avoid the collision altogether.

- Lane departure warning (LDW): Cameras are able to detect lane markings and alert the driver if the car is drifting outside the lane without the driver signaling. More complex versions of LDW can also intervene and use the steering to correct the car’s course and keep it in its lane.
- Backup camera: Mounted on the rear of the vehicle, this camera provides an image of the area behind the car on a central display screen on the dashboard.

Pricing for this list was determined by adding up all options and/or trim levels needed to get the aforementioned features. As it turns out, the average price of entry for these features is right around $30,000, undercutting the average new car transaction price, which is now above $31,000. We were also surprised to see that seven out of our ten vehicles come from American automakers.

1. 2014 Buick Verano Convenience Group: $25,795

The 2014 Buick Verano is the least expensive car on our list by a margin of more than $3000. A backup camera is the only one of these features to come standard on the Verano, but buyers of this compact premium sedan only need to step up one trim level from the base model to get the full suite of active safety technologies included on the Convenience Group trim.

2. 2014 Chevrolet Malibu 2LT: $29,105

Another General Motors vehicle comes in as the second cheapest, the 2014 Chevrolet Malibu. A backup camera is standard on the mid-grade 2LT trim, and the three other active safety features come with a reasonably priced $890 Advanced Safety package. This package also requires opting for the $1,000 Leather package and the $1,175 Electronics and Entertainment package, but all in this nicely-equipped Malibu still comes in at a reasonable $29,105.

3. 2014 Mazda 3 s Grand Touring: $29,390

The 2014 Mazda 3 sedan and hatchback have an impressive set of technology features, but FCW and LDW systems only come on the top-trim Grand Touring model in a special $2600 GT Tech package. That makes for an expensive little compact. You do get a lot for the money, though, as we are impressed with the Mazda 3’s upscale interior and best-in-class driving dynamics. If you can’t quite afford this loaded-up 3, the backup camera and BSM system do come as standard on lower-priced trim levels like the i Touring and Grand Touring.

4. 2014 Buick Encore Premium Group: $29,890

Buick’s compact SUV has trim levels that are structured slightly differently than on the Verano sedan. To get FCW and LDW systems, you have to step up to the Encore’s top trim level, called Premium Group. This loads the Encore up with lots of other luxury and convenience features, but it still comes in under $30,000 with front-wheel-drive.

5. 2015 Chrysler 200C: $30,475

Chrysler just introduced the new 200 at the 2014 Detroit auto show, and this mid-size sedan is thoroughly modernized with a more stylish look. The new Chrysler 200 also ups its technology game, with a $1,295 SafetyTec package optional on the 200C that adds not only the required safety systems for this list, but also adaptive cruise control and a parking assist feature. This safety package does require the addition of $795 Premium Lighting Group and the $1395 Navigation and Sound Group, but a Chrysler 200C with these options only just tops $30,000. The Chrysler 200 will go on sale this spring.

6. 2014 Jeep Cherokee Limited: $30,645

Next up is another Chrysler product, the 2014 Jeep Cherokee crossover. To get the option of selecting the $2155 Technology Group package, Cherokee buyers have to step up to the Limited trim level. This package adds the required active safety features, along with adaptive cruise control and parking assist, just like in the Chrysler 200. The Limited comes standard with front-wheel drive and a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine; adding four-wheel drive adds $2,000, and opting for the 3.2-liter Pentastar V-6 costs $1,495.

7. 2014 Nissan Rogue SL: $30,920

Nissan first got into the idea of affordable active safety features with the Altima sedan that sourced its optional LDW, BSM, and moving object detection all from the same rearview camera. The Altima lacks FCW, which keeps it off this list, but the recently redesigned 2014 Nissan Rogue does have FCW and earns a spot here. A backup camera is standard on all 2014 Rogues, and a $1,990 Premium package available only on the top-trim Rogue SL adds FCW, BSM, and LDW.

8. 2014 Ford Fusion SE 2.0 EcoBoost: $31,700

The 2014 Ford Fusion is available with a whole host of luxury features that drive its price up into the high-$30,000 range, but Ford offers its full set of active safety features in the midrange Fusion SE when equipped with the 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder engine. Fusion buyers must opt for the $1,200 Driver Assist package to get BSM and LDW, and FCW comes along with the $995 adaptive cruise control. This also requires adding the $2,350 Equipment Group 202A which adds leather, fog lights, and a power passenger’s seat.

9. 2014 Chevrolet Impala 1LT: $31,750

The 2014 Chevrolet Impala is one step up from the Malibu in size and price and offers a similar $890 Advanced Safety package that adds FCW, LDW, and BSM on top of the standard rearview camera on the Impala’s 1LT trim. Adding this package also requires the $940 Convenience package. At this price, the Impala is powered by a 195-hp 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine; to get the optional 305-hp 3.6-liter V-6, buyers have to step up one trim level to the 2LT model.

10. 2014 Mazda 6 Grand Touring: $32,570

Like its Mazda 3 little brother, the 2014 Mazda 6 packages most of its active safety features into the $2,080 GT Technology package available on the highest Grand Touring trim. This adds FCW and LDW to the backup camera and BLIS that come standard on the lower-trim Mazda 6 Touring. Other features like adaptive cruise control and Mazda’s i-ELOOP fuel-saving technology are also included in this package.

Honorable Mention: 2014 Honda Accord Sedan EX-L: $29,060

The 2014 Honda Accord doesn't quite make it onto our list because it does not have a full blind spot monitoring system. We wanted to give it some credit thanks to an interesting substitution, the Honda LaneWatch system. LaneWatch is a camera mounted below the passenger side mirror that projects a video feed to the central display screen showing an expanded view of the car’s right side. While it doesn’t display a visual alert like other blind spot monitors, LaneWatch provides an extended field of vision that helps diminish the car’s blind spot on the right side of the vehicle. All Accords offer a backup camera as standard, LaneWatch comes as standard on all Accords EX and up, and LDW and FCW systems come on the EX-L trim level and up.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. pageElements.text: Timing is everything, and for the Blizzerator and me it was perfect. This triple threat to winter is an ice scraper, snow brush, and squeegee in one. I had a broken ice scraper with a mangled brush on the other end as my only weapon against this Michigan winter. On a few mornings, I had resorted to using a credit card on the ice and a household broom to remove the snow.

The Blizzerator arrived during the snowiest winter in Ann Arbor since 1978. Had it arrived last year, I am not sure I would have even opened the box. The first thing I noticed was the sheer size of it: it is 55 ¾ inches long when fully extended, but even at its shortest it is 44 inches.
After every storm I see some tool driving with the entire back window covered. Recently I saw a car that had only cleared the area directly in front of the driver.

I love winter, and I welcomed the new piece of equipment to help me make quick work of clearing off our vehicles. In my book, you need to remove the snow off your entire car. You should not just uncover a little area so the driver can see out and then allow the defroster to clear the windows as you drive to work. Seriously, after every storm I see some tool driving with their entire back window covered, and recently I saw a car that had only cleared the area directly in front of the driver.

The Brush

The brush has four angles to make it easy to swoop away the snow, but it did take a few attempts to get the angle just right. This particular storm had left a thick layer of ice on the car, with a crispy snow layer on top.The fact that you can adjust the Blizzerator's brush at all is a giant leap for snow removal.

The Squeegee

The squeegee is the key to clearing snow off the top of your vehicle. I personally have neglected to clear the roof of my car before, and when the snow started to melt and I applied the brakes, all the snow from the roof slid down and completely covered the windshield. I would rather not repeat that lesson.

The Scraper

My favorite part, and it was completely unexpected, was the ice scraper. I am 5’7”, but I still cannot reach the center of the windshield, and once I extend my arm I have no leverage to remove any ice. The Blizzerator easily reaches the center, even of our van, and delivers the leverage needed to remove stubborn ice.

Snow-Free Clothes

Best of all they throw in a set of Ginsu knives. Just kidding, but you can actually detach the ice scraper to make it less unwieldy for getting under the wipers, or in order to use it on the side windows. And the hidden bonus is, since you don’t need to stretch over the car, you can perform this all without getting a speck of snow on yourself. In fact, for owners of oversize vehicles, there is a three-foot extension that can be purchased separately.

My husband is seriously frugal, and I asked him if he would plunk down $19.95 to buy the Blizzerator. Drum roll...Yes, he would open up his dusty wallet. The ability to keep clean while clearing off his car made the decision easy. Since most mornings he clears off my car, too, I will chip in for half.

pageElements.text:
Nissan rolled out a new version of its entry-level hatchback, the Versa Note, at the Chicago Auto Show today, and here it is. This new 2015 Versa Note SR is a sporty trim level. It's targeted at the twenty-five-to-thirty-five demographic, with an emphasis on young parents who are willing to give up some luxury features for economy but still want good design with a sporty edge. I love it, even though I'm a little past the age category...

This is the second generation of the Versa Note, and this spring when the SR joins the lineup, there will be five trim levels to choose from.

The difference between this and the more workaday five-door Versa Note versions is all in the looks. The Versa Note SR has the same 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine and Nissan Xtronic continuously variable transmission as the standard model. It makes 109 horsepower and gets 31 mpg in town and the magical 40 mpg on the highway.

What distinguishes the SR from the other Versa Note models is a special fascia and blacked-out grille, subtly different headlights, standard fog lights, body-color side spoilers, a rear spoiler, and redone side mirrors with turn signals integrated into them. The rear bumper is pudgier. There’s also a set of sixteen-inch dark-painted aluminum alloy wheels—Nissan product planning manager Eric Vaughen thinks they look like the blades of a Kitano knife—and some SR badging.

Inside, there’s a leather-wrapped steering wheel “inspired” by the 370Z, a piano black instrument panel with chrome knobs, and imitation suede seats with orange dots and contrast stitching. The adorable dot patterns extend to the door inserts. A new center stack and a set of center dials are all new and will be on the other Versa Note models for 2015, too.

The SR will be available with an optional Convenience package that includes my favorite, an adjustable “Divide-N-Hide” floor that lets you make the floor flat when the middle row is folded. There's also a center armrest with cup holders for kids in the car seats, plus a five-inch color display, hands-free text messaging, a rearview monitor, and NissanConnect smartphone integration and apps. The SR will join the current Versa Note lineup in Nissan dealerships this spring.
 
Model year 2015 will be notable for the entire Nissan Versa Note lineup: all versions will get standard Bluetooth connectivity with steering-wheel-mounted controls.
Nissan isn't saying how much the new Versa Note SR will cost, but it shouldn't be far out of the $15,000 neighborhood the regular Versa Note lives in.

pageElements.text:
Photography by Susan Campbell

When you picture traffic on the streets of New York City, it's unthinkable not to imagine yellow taxis. It's really true that 600,000 people a day ride in taxicabs in New York. But how many people get to drive them? So I was very excited to have the opportunity to take the brand-new Taxi of Tomorrow, the Nissan NV200, from the Chicago Auto Show back to Ann Arbor. That's about a 250-mile drive.

The best part of the deal was that our cab had all of the New York City taxi graphics, including the flat rate to John F. Kennedy International Airport (FYI: the flat fare is $52 between Manhattan and JFK, plus any tolls). I have ridden in taxis in many cities and even in a few different countries, but I have never driven one. My test drive would differ from most cabbies’, since I would rack up all those miles without stopping to pick up a new passenger.

But first, a little history about this taxicab that isn't shaped like a traditional cab: The Ford Crown Victoria,  previously the cab of choice, went out of production in 2011. That left a spot wide open for a new darling in the Big Apple. The purpose-built Nissan 200NV won a Taxi of Tomorrow design competition in 2011 to become New York City's exclusive taxi provider for a decade, and Nissan was set to bank some serious coin. Unfortunately, from the moment they stepped off the podium, the lawsuits started to be filed. First up was the United Spinal Association, followed by fleet owners, and then the powerful taxi lobby. As of today, the NV200 is an approved New York City taxi, but it's far from the exclusive choice.
Nevertheless, Nissan is looking to win over the fleet owners and the taxi community as a whole to prove that the NV200 really is the Taxi of Tomorrow.
A typical New York City cab travels approximately 70,000 miles per year and is on average 3.3 years old.

Photographer Susan Campbell and I received a quick debriefing on the unique attributes of the Nissan taxi before we hit the road. The biggest news is its partition between the driver and the back seat. It's factory installed, which Nissan calls a first. Nissan is also proud to state that this is the only taxi to have been crash tested with the partition in place. Nissan's Travis Parman told me that the NV200 taxi was tested at "an external facility and was verified to comply with applicable U.S. federal motor vehicle safety standards with the partition installed."

For both passenger and driver safety, the partition is made out of bullet-resistant plastic. I have been in many taxis that I assure you would not have passed a crash test, and I would be pleased to have a thick piece of plastic between the driver and me. The NV200 taxi has roof-mounted curtain supplemental air bags for side impact and rollover protection; those rear passengers who choose not to buckle receive no extra padding from the partition. So, remember, the same physics apply to taxis as to a normal passenger car, and buckle up!

Antimicrobial Vinyl: Nice Touch

A typical New York City cab travels approximately 70,000 miles per year and is on average 3.3 years old. This taxi was obviously spanking new, so it did not suffer from ground-in dirt and the stench that I automatically associate with cabs. But Nissan has added a few features to stave off the odors and germs that hover inside a cab. The rear seats are an antimicrobial vinyl that can easily be wiped off, and there's an active carbon material in the headliner. It is difficult to tell how effective these weapons will be against the nauseous overserved or other less than clean passengers, but hats off to Nissan for giving it more than an air freshener hanging on the rearview mirror.

Points of Passenger Control

The passenger also has control over the HVAC, interior lighting, two USB plugs, and a twelve-volt outlet. I am constantly running my phone in the red zone, so I give another point to the NV200 from a passenger's perspective. Possibly the best feature for the rider is the legroom. It is positively roomy for three passengers, and I am sure there will be late-night riders cramming a half-dozen friends into the sliding side doors (although it would be illegal to transport more people than seatbelts can hold). Luckily, there is a small sliding window in both doors to give a little extra air into the cabin.

Chicago from Inside an NYC Cab

As we tooled around the Windy City, we realized the very best feature of the NV200 was the view out the giant moonroof. Passengers can see the tops of the skyscrapers without smashing their heads against the side windows.

Having never piloted a taxi, I found it a bit challenging to weave in and out of the bustling Chicago traffic, but I felt it was important to get a feel for how the NV200 would navigate in its natural habitat before we took it on the relatively calm highway between Chicago and home. I would assume a driver would rip out the tiny rearview mirror and install an aftermarket mirror that would increase the rear perspective, but that being said, the curving edge of the partition adds an odd distortion that could be annoying if you spent nine and a half hours behind the wheel, as the average NYC taxi driver does each day.
In Chicago, we received a few hails and lots of attention as we tooled around taking photos through the moonroof. The NYC graphics confused more than one pedestrian.

In Chicago, we received a few hails and lots of attention as we tooled around taking photos through the moonroof. The NYC graphics confused more than one pedestrian. We pulled over to set the navigation for home and received a call from a stranded colleague seeking a ride home from the auto show. Well, why not? We punched in the address of Union Station, where his train was being delayed for several hours, and took the detour to save the day and selfishly get to actually taxi someone.

As our guest passenger situated himself in the rear, I reminded him to fasten his seatbelt. The NV200's belts have bright yellow accents to remind the passenger to buckle up. Perhaps this will improve New York City’s current 38 percent buckle rate in cabs. We threw his luggage into the absolutely cavernous cargo area and followed the navigation route to I-94, leaving his colleagues in the dust. He claimed to feel bad, but he didn’t really seem too concerned as he settled in for his chauffeur-driven drive.
The NV200's belts have bright yellow accents to remind the passenger to buckle up. Perhaps this will improve New York City’s current 38 percent buckle rate in cabs.

Susan and I chatted away in the front cabin while he acted like a real paying customer; plugging in devices, talking nonstop on his phone, and even pulling out his laptop to tackle a few e-mails. The NV200 does not have a Wi-Fi hotspot, but that is the type of accessory that can easily be added in the aftermarket. He pointed out the built in credit card reader. In New York City, every taxi must accept credit cards, and in fact 55 percent of passengers pay with a card. There is a large monitor in the center of the partition, but Nissan explained that for New York City it was not installed; the taxi companies want to install their own systems. I have not been in a Gotham City cab lately, but I assume you are bombarded with advertising as you are ferried about the city.

How Does It Feel?

The NV200 is front-wheel drive, with a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine mated to a continuously variable transmission (CVT). The relatively small engine size, coupled with the CVT, delivers an acceptable combined 24 mpg in fuel economy. I am confident that the true number dips much lower because of the inherent stop-and-start nature of the taxi lifestyle.

As our guest passenger shared, the ride is slightly bumpy on the highway, especially since the seat is directly over the rear wheels. In reality, the NV200 will spend the majority of its life darting around the city for quick jaunts. It's really meant for passengers who care more about space and cleanliness than about a premium ride experience.

The NV200’s handling is what you would expect from a slightly underpowered small van. The steering felt a tad disconnected but acceptable, and it did not feel top-heavy but actually rather nimble. On the highway I found the road noise quite loud, but I easily drowned it out with a little more volume from the Sirius satellite radio. I was pleased to see that the navigation screen doubles as the monitor for a backup camera.

How Does It Drive?

For the driver, the experience is nothing like the luxury they may remember from their puffy Ford Crown Victoria days, but there are some amenities that should please them. It has a six-way adjustable driver's seat with a manual lumbar control, and it is able to slightly recline. I found it quite comfortable on my ride, but I would have preferred the NASA-inspired seats that have popped up in other Nissan vehicles. Since the average cab is in service for three years and will likely have well over 150,000 miles before it retires, I am thinking that the seat comfort will be greatly reduced as the miles pile on, but that would happen with any seat. And be sure that wooden bead seats will be quickly installed for many. Bluetooth is standard, but note that New York City's laws forbid a driver from using a phone while driving, even hands-free. So rest assured no driver will use this function.

How Cabdrivers Will Use It

Every taxi in New York City has a distress button the driver can push that lights up on the exterior of the cab to alert police or savvy observers that something is amiss in the cab. In the NV200, the button is just left of the steering column and will activate a flashing red 911. It made me think perhaps the passengers deserve a button, too. Agreed?

The maximum shift a NYC cabbie can have is twelve hours. If you are spending half your day in a vehicle, you are going to customize it to make it work for you. The NV200's front passenger's seat folds down to create a flat surface that I imagine many cabdrivers will love. There is no center console, so the cup holders, mirror adjusters, and lighting controls are way down between the seats. I assume the drivers will want to take advantage of that space and get the cup holders up to a more convenient level. The steering-wheel-mounted controls for audio and cruise control are a nice touch, and the intercom can be turned off from either cabin. There is a hearing loop system for the hearing impaired. For the hearing public, the horn is considered low-annoyance, but when you have dozens of taxis honking at random, how can it not be annoying?

Why No Hybrid?

The sticking point for me in understanding how the NV200 was chosen as the Taxi of Tomorrow is the mileage. The current fleet of NYC yellow cabs is 60 percent hybrid-electric, and since this vehicle is not available as a hybrid and in fact only gets a combined 24 mpg, isn’t that a step backward for mankind and pocketbooks as well?

Nissan currently offers a hybrid version in the Asia market called the Serena S-Hybrid. The New York Taxi & Limousine Commission is interested in a hybrid, Nissan's Parman says, but "additional consultation" still has to happen before the wheels are set in motion to bring a hybrid version of the NV200 here as a taxi. Until that time, it doesn’t seem like hybrid buyers are going to want to eat into their profits to make the experience nicer for customers.

The Passenger's Point of View

We swung into the Amtrak parking lot to drop off our guest passenger, a full three hours ahead of his co-workers whom he had abandoned at Union Station. I explained to him that his bill for the ride would arrive in the mail shortly. The next day, he shared with me the story that he will add into his Christmas letter eleven months from now.

"This winter, Amtrak has been about as predictable as Toronto mayor Tom Ford, so a 240-mile fare in the back of a Nissan NV200 taxi seemed like the sure-fire bet. And on a Friday afternoon in February, the ride was most appreciated. The passenger compartment in the new cab is roomy and well appointed, and the big, wide sliding door is a certainly the right solution for a quick pickup in front of Chicago's Union Station. Driver Molly had to just slow down for me to jump in, and away we went. Eastward, ho!

In transit at highway speeds—which admittedly most taxi riders won't experience—the ride is not exactly Checker soft, suffering from highway hop on Michigan's cruel roads, but this Nissan cab is certainly quieter than any Checker ever was and feels solidly built. In my quiet, partitioned-off cabin, I was able to catch up on work as the miles rolled past, making calls and connecting with old friends and associates. Riding home from Chicago in a taxi was a novelty indeed and is now a story I am glad to have. I think driver Molly and co-pilot Susan were fine hosts, though a bit chatty and directionally challenged.

Overall: A welcome ride. Certainly better than Amtrak could do that day. And the fare was affordable. Thanks, Jean Knows Cars."
Actually, thank you, Nissan. Next time I spot a Nissan NV200 taxi, I will certainly hail it so that I can see how it is holding up to the grueling taxi life.

title: Flag-Draped Marketing That Fails
subTitle: What's with the jingoism in these Chrysler & Cadillac ads? asks Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
promoTeaserSmall: What's with the jingoism in these Chrysler & Cadillac ads? asks Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
promoTeaser: What's with the jingoism in these Chrysler & Cadillac ads? asks Automobile Magazine's David Zenlea.
metaDescription: Flag-Draped Marketing That Fails: We've seen two new car ads that go beyond merely wrapping themselves in the American flag. The ads, for the 2015 Chrysler 200 and 2014 Cadillac ELR, display an ugly streak of jingoism. Read the commentary on JeanknowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Vanity would have me believe you’re reading this because you’re a devoted fan of my writing. In that case, you may want to know that I also edit the magazine’s Ignition section, read lots of Kurt Vonnegut, and would eat sushi at every meal if it were socially acceptable. Reality tells me you just want to know how I landed this amazing job. Fine. Based on my experience, here’s some advice.

1) Major in journalism. Most of us here aren’t racecar drivers -- we’re writers and reporters. It probably helps if you’ve attended journalism school, as I did at the University of Maryland, or worked for some periodical. That said, deputy editor Joe DeMatio now claims he was more intrigued by my second degree in Jewish studies, even though he’s never once asked me to write about the exploits of Simon bar Kochba.
2) Know how to operate a manual transmission. Seems obvious, but I actually did not upon being hired. I taught myself during my first month on the job by visiting six Ann Arbor dealerships to test drive stick-shift economy cars. My sincere apologies to whoever ended up buying that Ford Focus.
3) Learn everything you can about cars. I grew up pouring over car magazines and memorizing zero-to-sixty times as if they were catechism. People have been asking me for car-buying advice since before I could drive.
4) Realize you actually know nothing about cars. A brief conversation with design editor Robert Cumberford, editor-in-chief Jean Jennings, or any other of the veterans here leaves you humbled and astounded by their wealth of automotive knowledge. It’s truly one of the best parts of working here.
5) Be persistent. I wrote to Automobile’s editors. And called. And wrote them some more.
6) Be lucky. I really have no idea why then deputy editor Joe DeMatio answered my unsolicited voicemail. I hadn’t even pronounced his name correctly (it’s De-MAY-shee-oh, not De-MAH-tee-oh). But he did, and here I am, driving cars and writing about them for my devoted fans.

pageElements.text: American car companies love to remind us they're American. That's nothing new. Chevrolet, of course, is as American as baseball, hot dogs, and apple pie. More recently, George Washington defeated the British behind the wheel of a Dodge Challenger.

But in the last two weeks, we've seen two new car ads that go beyond merely wrapping themselves in the American flag. The ads, for the 2015 Chrysler 200 and 2014 Cadillac ELR, display an ugly streak of jingoism.
"We will build your car"
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/KlSn8Isv-3M" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Against a montage of rodeos, cheerleaders, and baseball games, Bob Dylan proclaims all the ways we're the first and the best. We have vision, pride, and true cool. Our assembly line workers have hearts and souls. All these things, Dylan insists, "you can't import."
"Let Germany brew your beer. Let Switzerland make your watch. Let Asia assemble your phone," Dylan concludes. "We will build your car."

The first, and most obvious question for this ad's creators, the agency GlobalHue, is, What foreign-made cars is Dylan referring to? The 2015 Chrysler 200's key "import" competitors are built in Ohio (Honda Accord), Kentucky and Indiana (Toyota Camry), and Tennessee (Nissan Altima, Volkswagen Passat). I also couldn't help but notice there was no reference to letting the Italians—who now own Chrysler—cook your pasta.

Beyond the complexities of what actually constitutes foreign lies a more basic question: why does it matter? Before you insult my intelligence in the comments section, let me say I know why it matters. I grew up in a town that suffered badly when a General Motors factory closed (Framingham, Massachusetts) and I live in Southeast Michigan, where not just the assembly workers, but also doctors, lawyers, and writers rely on the health of the American auto industry. American cars are not important because we have diners, Route 66, Bob Dylan, or factory workers. I've visited assembly lines in Mexico, Japan, England, and Germany. The workers on those lines appeared to have hearts and souls, too.
Now, let's re-watch the brilliant ad Chrysler showed at the 2011 Super Bowl:
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/SKL254Y_jtc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Note how this advertisement consciously avoids the old tropes about American versus foreign manufacturing. It doesn't even say, "America," until the very end. Rather, it presents an honest picture of Detroit, using the embattled city as a metaphor for ethos we all hold dear, like hard work and resilience. If anything, there's a subtle dig at the rest of the country for forsaking Detroit and these ethos. "We're certainly no one's Emerald City," the narrator reminds viewers.
"We're crazy, hard-working believers."

Chrysler isn't the only domestic automaker thinking it can sell more cars by telling us how superior we are. The first advertisement for the 2014 Cadillac ELR, which was developed by Lowe Campbell Ewald and debuted last week, indulges in clichés similar to the Chrysler commercial. We went to the moon! We have Bill Gates! But the commercial's core message is that Americans work harder than people in "other countries."
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/Q4hI6koIRYk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Poolside - Lowe Campbell Ewald

images.caption: 2014 Cadillac ELR in the Super Bowl commercial.
2014 Cadillac ELR in the Super Bowl commercial.
2014 Cadillac ELR in the Super Bowl commercial.

pageElements.text: "Other countries, they work, they stroll home, they stop by the café. They take August off," explains the pitchman (played by Neal McDonough—apparently Macaulay Culkin was not available to reprise his role as Richie Rich).

This spiel, and the potshots at Europe, will probably appeal to Red State conservatives. Unfortunately for Cadillac, most in that audience are unlikely to buy an electric car from so-called Government Motors. (Even those who supported the bailout may chortle when the ad proclaims, "You work hard; you create your own luck.")

The ad opens Cadillac to uncomfortable questions. Like, if Europeans are so lazy and unproductive, how come their luxury brands have been cleaning Cadillac's clock since the 1980s? Why did Cadillac hire a former BMW executive (the very European Uwe Ellinghaus) to run its marketing? How does the brand expect to establish itself in Europe, as it still hopes to, if it derides Europeans? And, finally, what's a Cadillac ELR? The ad never really bothers to tell us.
Contrast this with rap artist Macklemore's ode to Cadillacs, "White Walls."
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/8PLifPUIuic" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Macklemore, too, presents Cadillac as the reward for American ambition and hard work. But he does so with tongue firmly in cheek, and without alienating anyone. He also shows lots of actual Cadillacs.

To be perfectly clear, there's nothing wrong with celebrating America, and there's nothing wrong with Detroit-based automakers celebrating their role in the American story. The problem is with trumpeting American superiority as an argument for buying American cars. It's the difference between saying Chevrolets are as American as baseball and saying that baseball is much better than foreign sports and thus Chevrolets are better than foreign cars (a line of reasoning we're unlikely to hear so long as Chevrolet is locked into its sponsorship of the Manchester United soccer team). The Chrysler and Cadillac ads—both of which, it must be noted, were developed by local Michigan-based agencies—display the insular chauvinism that got American carmakers in trouble.

title: D-Insurance for Detroit's Drivers?
subTitle: New mayor proposes city-run car insurance in the nation's priciest market. Can he pull it off?
