promoTeaser: New mayor proposes city-run car insurance in the nation's priciest market. Can he pull it off?
metaKeywords: State of the City Speech in Detroit
metaDescription: D-Insurance for Detroit's Drivers? New mayor proposes city-run car insurance in the nation's priciest market. Can he pull it off? Read the details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: In his first State of the City address on Wednesday, Detroit’s new mayor, Mike Duggan, announced plans to tackle the city’s high car insurance rates by creating a first of its kind city-run auto insurance plan called D-Insurance. "We're going to keep going until we get people an affordable car insurance option," the mayor said in his speech.

If you live in the city of Detroit, you pay the highest rates in the country, according to one study by Nerdwallet.com, an online consumer comparison site. Using the profile of a twenty-six-year-old male with no accident history on his 2012 Toyota Camry, NerdWallet calculated auto insurance rates in the 125 largest U.S. cities. Detroit’s average premium was $10,723.22 yearly, well over $6,000 more than the next highest city, New Orleans.
When he moved from a nearby suburb into the city to run for office, Mayor Duggan's own premiums doubled, from $3,000 to $6,000, as a result of his new zip code.

When he moved from a nearby suburb into the city in order to run for office, Mayor Duggan experienced the phenomenon himself, stating during Wednesday’s address that his premiums doubled, from $3,000 to $6,000, as a result of his new zip code. "What's the single biggest barrier to driving a car?" he asked during the speech. "Insurance," came a chorus of replies. Indeed, more than half of Detroit car owners are reportedly driving uninsured.

The mayor’s idea is a bold one. According to Robert Detlefsen, vice-president of public policy at the National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies, Detroit will be navigating uncharted auto coverage territory. “We know of no other major municipality that has ever attempted to institute an insurance program of this sort,” said Detlefsen.

Unfortunately, Detroiters seeking insurance relief will have to wait for a required feasibility study to be conducted jointly by the Detroit City Council and the mayor’s office before the dream of D-Insurance can be attempted. Mayor Duggan says the Detroit city charter permits it, and a team has already been assembled, according to the mayor’s office. Residents, he said, should expect to see progress on the study by the summer.

Since he took office in January, access to safe and affordable transportation as a means to increase citizens’ employment opportunities has been a top priority for Mayor Duggan. His administration has initiated safety camera installations on the city’s DDOT buses, totaling fifty this month with the goal of outfitting 300 buses by the fall. He complained in the speech about the public transportation system, calling Detroit's buses "the oldest fleet in America" and saying extending hours on buses and replacing the aging fleet are high priorities. In fact, the mayor said, the Obama administration is helping cut red tape to get fifty new buses delivered to Detroit by fall. A program to install lower-maintenance LED streetlights on the city’s east and west sides has also begun.

These improvements are undoubtedly welcome by Detroit’s commuters, but in a city built around the automobile, one has to imagine that significantly lowering the cost of owning a car by providing affordable insurance would be better news still.

title: 2014 Honda Pilot
subTitle: Versatile eight-seater.

promoTeaser: Versatile eight-seater.
metaDescription: 2014 Honda Pilot: Versatile eight-seater. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: The big and boxy Honda Pilot shares many of its qualities with its minivan cousin, the Odyssey.  The Pilot, however, falls squarely in SUV territory with its high stance, nicely tuned suspension and a serviceable five-speed V-6 that will tow up to 4,500 pounds when paired with the four-wheel drive.  Up to eight passengers can fit in three rows and still have 18 cubic feet of cargo space in the way back.  Fold the two passenger rows down and cargo space becomes nearly epic.  A recent and welcome tech upgrade brought new audio and media interfaces plus a rearview camera to modernize the driver’s experience.  Inside and out the look is pleasant but the strength of the Pilot is its utility, reliability and capable handling rather than standout styling presence.  In the asset column is that at 17 to 18 mpg in the city and 24 to 25 on the highway, the Pilot is the highest EPA-rated fuel economy for an eight passenger SUV.  Safety-wise the car is coated with high tech airbags and was rated in 2013 as an IIHS Top Safety Pick.  Expect to pay between $30,000 for the base two-wheel drive Pilot and $40,000 plus for all the bells and whistles, which will be prohibitive for some.  Neither showy nor ground-breaking the Pilot’s versatility has still won over loads of fans who will be looking forward to seeing what a 2015 redesign will add to their favorite SUV.

title: Consumer Reports Picks
subTitle: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them?
promoTeaserSmall: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them?
promoTeaser: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them?
metaDescription: Consumer Reports Picks: The 2014 model ratings are out from the consumer publication. What weight should shoppers give them? Read our perspective on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Every year about this time, Consumer Reports publishes its April Best Cars issue. Even though this nonprofit organization, founded in 1936, does extensive testing and surveying to come up with its rankings, the question remains: who decides what “best” means, and is this or any publication’s “best” choice the best for you? Awards and top picks belong in any shopper's tool box of information, but as one among many research tools you should avail yourself of.

Consumer Reports is well known for placing a high value on reliability. The organization does its own road testing and consults National Highway Transportation Safety Administration (NHTSA) and Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS) crash testing results, then rounds out its rankings using data from subscribers on the actual problems they experience with their vehicles. All well and good, but it’s important to understand what “problems” might mean. It’s not necessarily something mechanical, such as early brake failure; often, it’s difficulty in learning to use the telematics and electronic systems.

This directly affected ratings for Ford and Cadillac this year, because subscribers criticized both brands for their Ford Sync MyFord and MyLincoln Touch, and Cadillac Cue systems’ user-unfriendliness. Would this stop you from buying and enjoying the cars? That’s another question, and that’s why it is important to understand what the ratings are based on. Let's take Ford as an example, since that company was kicked all the way to the basement for 2014, ranking at the bottom of the brand rankings next to Jeep. Consumer Reports put that down to "widespread reliability problems" with its infotainment systems, as well as problems with the automatic transmissions in two models, the Focus and Fiesta. These issues were weighted more heavily than the Ford lineup's "fairly high test scores" in road testing. Since Consumer Reports doesn't skimp on details, numbers, and charts, the information is available, although most can only be accessed by subscribers.

In a separate ranking, CR did a survey in December about “brand perception” in which Ford came in second and Cadillac made the top ten (at the #9 position, between Volvo and BMW). Ford also made the top five in perception of Technology/Innovation, Value, Performance, Safety, and Quality.

Here's the full list of Best Car Brands:

Best Overall Goes to Tesla

CR gave its best-in-show award, Best Overall, to the Tesla Model S. The organization is in good company: our brother publication Automobile Magazine named the Model S its 2013 Automobile of the Year. The car, priced just under $90,000, is undoubtedly a game changer. CR ranked it tops in road testing, reliability, and safety measures. The average Consumer will be hard pressed to afford one, of course.

Top Picks

Listed by category, the Top Picks are:
Honda Accord (Mid-size sedan): "Handling is agile, although the ride isn't quite as comfortable as that in some competitors. Just avoid the HondaLink infotainment system that comes on EX-L versions."
Subaru Impreza (Compact car): "Easy to live with, thanks to a roomy interior, spacious rear seat, simple controls....our only serious gripe is pronounced road noise. But it's no deal breaker."
Toyota Prius (Green car): "Our Green Car pick for the eleventh year in a row," but "skip the slow, noisy Prius C econobox."
Audi A6 (Luxury car): "A sumptuous, impeccably finished, first-class cabin that's brimming with the latest high-tech features."
BMW 328i (Sport sedan): "Excellent handling and a high fun-to-drive factor....roomier, more luxurious, and more fuel-efficient than past models."

Subaru Forester (Small SUV): "The easiest access and best visibility in its category....OK, the ride is a bit firm and the in-car electronics are behind the curve; there's still room for improvement."
Hyundai Santa Fe (Mid-size SUV): "A lot of features for the money, including a standard backup camera. But the tiny third-row seat is for kids only."
Honda Odyssey (Minivan): "The most complete family vehicle you can buy....also relatively fun to drive for a minivan, with its vigorous V-6 engine, responsive handling, and supple ride."

Ram 1500 (Pickup): "Surprisingly refined and inviting...effortless power while returning a relatively good 15 mpg overall. The Chevrolet Silverado outscored the Ram in our testing, but its reliability is unknown."

It's always good to read widely when looking for a new car. IntelliChoice lets you research cars by make and model, check out costs of ownership in seven areas from insurance to fuel, and offers real-world fuel economy numbers—and, unlike Consumer Reports, gives up the data without requiring a subscription.
But, if your fascination with the Consumer Reports model continues, check out Automobile Magazine's 2013 behind-the-scenes look at CR HQ.

title: 2014 Buick Regal over Ice
subTitle: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.
promoTeaserSmall: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.
promoTeaser: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.
metaDescription: 2014 Buick Regal over Ice: To Montreal and beyond in the new all-wheel-drive version of the classic Buick.  Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text:
2014 Buick Regal GS AWD

Price: $40,195 base price (including destination); $44,550 as tested (including destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 259 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway
Notable standard features on this model: Brembo front brakes, front and rear parking assist, traction and stability control, Bose premium audio with navigation, Buick IntelliLink infotainment system with Bluetooth connectivity and 8.0-inch driver information display, heated front seats
You might also be considering: Acura TSX, Audi A4, Lincoln MKZ, Volvo S60

My adventure with the Buick Regal AWD sedan started out brilliantly. I arrived in Montreal a night early, because New York City was on Polar Vortex alert. What I didn’t know was that Montreal was already in the midst of it. Our group spent the first night at the Montreal-Trudeau Airport's Marriott Hotel overlooking the landing strip, which is one of my favorite visual vistas.

The plan was to start out early the next morning driving to northern Québec for an overnight stay at the Fairmont Le Château Montebello, billed as the largest log cabin in the world. Our ultimate destination was the ice track at Circuit ICAR (International Center of Advanced Racing), where we would put the Regal’s prowess to the test.

Let me first explain that the reason we were on this snowy trip was to test out the Buick Regal’s new all-wheel-drive system. For 2014, the Regal, known as the athlete of the Buick sedan family, has added a turbocharged engine and all-wheel drive (the AWD models are priced starting at about $2,000 higher than the front-wheel-drive versions). In other words, the GM division has amped up the equation for driving enthusiasts. And Buick wanted to show us just what this car could do.

As I said, the conditions were less than perfect. It was snowy, icy, slippery, overcast, and bleak. I took the wheel first and have to admit that I was a wee bit unhinged by the weather. Dirt and slush kept spitting up from the highway making it hard to see clearly. Thankfully, my driving partner, Nik Miles, a Fox Morning News reporter, is my favorite type of navigator. He kept repeating directions to me. Instead of assuming that I’d remember that in twenty kilometers or so I should take Exit 35, he’d give me up-to-the-moment details. After a half-hour of getting used to the elements, I was in the groove. The car felt confident and grounded, and so did I.

Our first stop was Centre de Pêche Sportive, a small ice-fishing village with colorful wooden huts set up on the ice as a respite from the cold and wind. A group of us cocooned within a warm hut about the size of a large walk-in closet. It was blowing freezing winds outside, so we watched the fisherman through foggy windows while snacking on local cheeses and sugary homemade doughnuts. We were given the opportunity to catch and release (they cast for walleye, pike, whitefish, lake trout, or perch), but nothing was happening.

It was my first time visiting an ice village, so I did some research. Canadians have been gouging holes in ice for centuries. Ice fishing is practiced all over Québec, as soon as the layer of ice covering their rivers and lakes is thick enough to bore through…and drive cars on. The huts—some of which are equipped with conveniences including stoves —are moved to the shores during the summer.

After the “fishing” or snacking, Nik took the wheel and drove over a gray landscape of flat snowy roads to our next destination, the ice bridge, which is simply an iced-over ferry crossing. This was playtime, just to whet our appetites for the track. I took a few spins, handed the wheel to Nik, and got out of the car (so I wouldn’t get nauseous). We all had a laugh when Nik ended up getting our car embedded in a snowbank. A group of guys pushed him out, and we were good to go on the last leg of our trip.

We arrived at Le Château Montebello around noon. The strapping red cedar structure is built around a rotunda with a six-sided stone fireplace that rises more than sixty-six feet to the roof. Its rafters are crafted from sixty-foot logs, and two upper balconies circle the space. The spacious chateau has 211 guest rooms, including fourteen suites, in four wings, with additional wings for the dining room and ballroom.

The hotel's amenities include indoor and outdoor pools, a spa and fitness center, tennis courts, an eighteen-hole golf course, and more than sixteen miles of cross-country ski trails. We were offered the choice of cross-country skiing, dog sledding, ice skating, or snowshoeing.

Once we had wolfed our way through a three-course lunch, I decided to go for the dog sledding. A different mode of transportation indeed! No heated seats or shocks in this two-person sled; a blanket was our cozy covering from the elements. A team of gorgeous huskies ferried us through the silent woods on a bumpy, breathtaking, and stunningly quiet ride. I felt slightly heady from the whole experience.
Once back to earth, however, on the way back to the Château, I took a giant slide on the ice and landed flat on my rear end.

The next day was our turn to test the Regal on Circuit ICAR. We tried everything from schussing in and out of cones (autocross) to braking on black ice and driving around a circular ice skidpad track with traction/stability  both engaged and disengaged.
When driving on ice, you can drift or basically slide backward or sideways. The experience is exhilarating! The Buick Regal was tight, bright, and responsive.

When driving on ice, you can drift or basically slide backward or sideways. If you know what you’re doing and have a trainer, as we did, it’s a wonderful way of seeing how the vehicle can lose and gain control under different conditions. The experience is exhilarating! The Buick Regal was tight, bright, and responsive. Exactly what the automaker had promised.
We finished our track time by lunch, and I was back in New York City in time for dinner.
A brilliant beginning, middle, and end to the Buick Regal adventure.
A short history of the hotel:

In the late 1920s, Harold M. Saddlemire, a Swiss-American entrepreneur, acquired a portion of land along the Ottawa River. His dream was to create a private wilderness retreat for business and political leaders. The original project, "Lucerne-in-Québec," came to be known as the Seigniory Club. Despite the 1929 stock market crash, work on the planned wilderness retreat began on schedule in early 1930.

The project continued, most likely because the presidents of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the National Bank of Canada, the Bank of Montreal and the Royal Bank of Canada and the Premier of Québec, were all club directors. Construction and woodworking teams toiled around the clock using electric lighting at night. At the time, the church did not approve of working on the Sabbath. Perhaps to counteract this, the local curé was dispatched on an all-expenses paid trip to Rome for two months while the work continued.

3,500 laborers completed the job in four months and the club opened on July 1, 1930. Over the years, the resort has welcomed guests including Crown Prince Akihito of Japan, Harry S. Truman, Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, Bing Crosby, Perry Como, Bette Davis, and Joan Crawford.
To note: The Fairmont properties in the Québec province have installed electric vehicle charging stations in partnership with Hydro-Québec’s Electric Circuit.

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: Every time I see a blimp flying high overhead, I smile.  (And I often do, because I live in a town where it visits during college football games.) It seems unreal, just floating in the blue sky, or even better, humming in the night flashing messages seemingly sent from heaven. It offers the ultimate bird's-eye view. A blimp is better than a hot air balloon because you don’t need to rely on fickle winds, and better than a plane because you can hover for hours.

So that's why I was thrilled that I drew the golden ticket that invited me to see Goodyear’s spanking new blimp. I was allowed to get up close and examine the airship, but unfortunately I would not be leaving the ground. It is scheduled to begin test flights this week, with a goal of being ready for actual duty by midsummer.

The new blimp is the first complete remake of the classic dirigible since 1972. The current fleet's design actually dates back all the way to 1919. So it was about time for a change, and I suspected I would be seeing something completely different.
When the door slid open to reveal the moored blimp, it seemed like we were entering a whale’s aquarium. It was downright majestic.

The huge hangar sits alone on a rural road near Akron, Ohio. It is perched alongside Wingfoot Lake—yep, named after Goodyear’s logo. When the door slid open to reveal the moored blimp, it seemed like we were entering a whale’s aquarium. It was downright majestic, and we could walk right up to it.

At 246 feet long, the New Goodyear Blimp is just eighteen yards shorter than an American football field. It's also fifty-four feet longer than the blimp it replaces. The new paint scheme features tapered yellow arcs that stretch from tail to fin, and only the visually impaired will miss the enormous Goodyear logo.
Will people notice the difference? Absolutely. Both inside and outside, this is a whole different dirigible.

The blimp we have been seeing for years has no internal framework. Its balloon-like body, called its "envelope," is made of Dacron and Neoprene, and it has two engines that are mounted directly on the gondola where the driver and passengers ride. Those engines can make it very, very loud inside the gondola: up to 110 decibels.

By contrast, the new blimp is actually a zeppelin, because it has a framework inside the envelope. (But don't think, "Oh, the humanity"; the fuel is helium, not highly flammable hydrogen as in the Hindenburg.) The framework is made up of aluminum and carbon fiber trusses. The envelope is polyurethane, polyester, and Tedlar film from Dupont. It has three engines, which are attached to the envelope instead of the gondola, and as a result, the noise level in the gondola is way down to 64 decibels.
The New Goodyear Blimp is also faster and more maneuverable, and it can hold up to twelve passengers plus two crew members, compared with a total of seven in the current blimp.

Global communications chief Paul Fitzhenry called the introduction of the New Goodyear Blimp "the beginning of a new era for our airship program." Among the benefits he outlined are "enhanced aerial television coverage capabilities, increased flight range to cover more events, and an unparalleled passenger experience.”
 
Assembly of the new helium-filled airship began a year ago. Goodyear and Germany’s ZLT Zeppelin Luftschifftechnik worked together to build the new semi-rigid dirigible. The tailfins and gondola were built in Germany and assembled in the Goodyear hangar.

But the big news for the pilots is an upgrade from the manual flight system that has been in use since 1925 to modern computer-controlled avionics. Chief pilot Greg Poppenhouse described how the flight crew has been going to Germany for the past year. He has personally logged more than 200 hours in a Zeppelin airship and is eager to get the new blimp up in the air.

More news: There's a joystick. The electronic controls work in conjunction with an on-board computer to regulate engine thrust, up-and-down movement, and right-and-left movement. Tailfin operation will be controlled by the joystick device. These advancements, Goodyear explained, will result in more precise operation of the airship while in flight, on landing, and on takeoff.

pageElements.text: As soon as permission was granted, I beelined for the gondola and sat right down in one of the twelve seats for passengers, imagining myself looking down over the Big House in Ann Arbor, even though I was definitely in Ohio State territory. The first thing you notice when entering the cabin is an actual restroom, but unlike any I have seen in the sky this one has a window. Previous blimps have a camp-style toilet that is in a closet, nice to have anything when a game goes into extra innings.
The gondola's huge wraparound windows and the open cockpit must make for a party atmosphere wherever the blimp may be cruising.

The interior has been designed to remind you of the company that has made your flight possible. A Goodyear Wingfoot is embroidered on the blue leather seats, a double yellow line down the aisle is a gentle reminder of the road where Goodyear tires roll, and a giant Goodyear logo is sewn into the headliner. The placement of the engines directly on the exterior of the envelope makes the ride much quieter, and passengers no longer need to wear headphones to hear communication from the host. The gondola's huge wraparound windows and the open cockpit must make for a party atmosphere wherever the blimp may be cruising.

The new blimp's top speed of 73 mph is slower than I drove on the highway on my way to Ohio, but that's 23 mph faster than the current fleet. It will significantly reduce the time it takes the pilots to reach their destinations and give the blimp greater range to cover more events. And the configuration for cameras will also allow more passengers during live coverage.

I was not lucky enough to fly in the blimp, but you have a chance to. Goodyear is asking the public to help pick a name for the new blimp. U.S. entrants over age eighteen can enter the contest to supply a name for the new blimp. Contest information is on the Facebook page, too. One name will be chosen from the entries, and the contest winner will get to join the Goodyear Blimp for a day of airship activities. In addition, nine runner-up winners will each receive a set of Goodyear tires. The contest will close on Friday, April 4.

I myself have a new affection for the blimp. I am voraciously reading about the history of blimps and zeppelins and looking forward to seeing the blimp floating over my house. You can become a blimpophile, too, by devouring the Blimp website.

title: R.I.P., Carrozzerie Italiane
subTitle: Why the great coachbuilders of Italy mattered, and why their era is over.
promoTeaserSmall: Why the great coachbuilders of Italy mattered. Why their era is over. With Pininfarina's response.
promoTeaser: Why the great coachbuilders of Italy mattered. Why their era is over. With Pininfarina's response.
metaDescription: R.I.P., Carrozzerie Italiane: Why the great coachbuilders of Italy mattered, and why their era is over. Read the commentary of Automobile Magazine's design editor, Robert Cumberford, on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Robert Cumberford is a designer who became a writer by accident. His race report on the 12 Hours of Sebring was published when he was an eighteen-year-old Art Center student in 1954. Subsequently he has published thousands of articles on cars and airplanes, in American, Asian, English, European, and South American magazines. He contributed to several books, including the entire text of the well-reviewed Auto Legends, now available in five translated editions -- French, German, Spanish, Italian, and Polish in addition to the original English version. In 1985, Automobile Magazine founder David E. Davis, Jr., invited him to be one of two executive editors when Automobile was in the planning stages. Cumberford demurred, saying he knew nothing about magazine production and claims he still doesn’t, except that it’s important to meet deadlines. He contributed features from the beginning and began his popular “By Design” column in the sixth issue, September 1986.

In car design, Cumberford was even more a youthful prodigy. He sketched the body for the first car ever built to his designs when he was a fifteen-year-old Los Angeles high-school student. That car, the Parkinson Jaguar Special, is still active in historic racing sixty years after it was created. Hired directly by General Motors’ legendary Vice President of Design, Harley J. Earl, Cumberford became a professional car designer at nineteen. Leaving Detroit, he returned to California to attend UCLA to study philosophy. He rejoined the automotive world in the early 1960s and has continued to create new automotive shapes since then, always as an independent design consultant. He has lived and worked in six of the fifty United States and in France, Mexico, and Switzerland. The range of his design projects includes both racing and touring cars, trucks, aircraft, boats, hovercraft, and even ecological architecture.

He is known worldwide for strong opinions but is well-respected in the design world because it is known that he is always completely honest in his views, with no agenda other than respect for good design and good designers. “There’s no ad hominem,” he says, “I judge the design, not the designers. There are designers I really like personally who’ve been credited with designs I heartily dislike -- for reasons I always state very clearly -- and designs I love done by people with whom I have absolutely no affinity. Except that we both like their work.”

pageElements.text: Carrozzeria Bertone, the very last of the great Italian coachbuilders who led world car design from 1946 to circa 1986, was forced to close its doors this year, 102 years after its founding in Turin, Italy. The now-unfamiliar term “coachbuilder” applied to enterprises, most of them simply artisanal workshops, that designed and constructed bodywork for automobile chassis. For the first half-century or so of the automobile’s existence, carmakers typically created only the engine and chassis of their products, relying on separate entities to design, build, and mount bodies on those chassis.

Even companies as big and powerful as Ford and General Motors relied on outside body builders up into the Thirties: Briggs and Murray for the former, Fisher Body for the later. Eventually, of course, those firms were absorbed by their clients, but bodies for prestige chassis like Packard, Rolls-Royce, and Isotta-Fraschini were made by outside specialists right up to the outbreak of World War II.

After the war, there was really no need for coachbuilders in the United States, as there were in-house design and body manufacturing groups for all the remaining brands. Most of the prestige makes of the Thirties—Cord, Duesenberg, Marmon, Peerless, Pierce-Arrow—were victims of the Great Depression, and there were simply no clients for firms like California’s Murphy Body, which had built more than half of all Duesenberg bodies. A few coachbuilding houses remained in Britain, but only Rolls-Royce, Bentley and Daimler had need of them.
The decline and fall of the great design and small-volume production houses comes from two principal causes, one industrial, the other sociological.

In France, world center of car design 1919-1939, the postwar Communist government impoverished the few remaining French body design and construction firms, not allowing them to buy metal and other materials they needed. Those same restrictions were applied to the remaining high-quality, low-volume chassis makers, and by the end of the Fifties Delage, Delahaye, Hotchkiss, and Talbot were gone.

So that left Italy, whose strongly left-wing governments were more interested in jobs for coachbuilders’ workers than in punishing their rich customers. That attitude was fortuitous for firms like Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, and Maserati, which could sell extravagant cars to wealthy customers all over the world. Perhaps only one or two cars would go to the Philippines or Argentina, or any of a hundred other countries, but those few sales kept skilled craftsmen employed and their families housed, fed, and healthy.
I remember being fascinated by the shape of cupboard hinges and door handles in my hotel room the morning of my first day in Italy in the Sixties.

Italy has always been a country where beauty and elegance are valued, where presenting “una bella figura” is important across a wide cross-section of society, where the arts mattered as much to people of modest means as to the very wealthy, where mundane objects are often the subject of careful and thoroughly considered design. I remember being fascinated by the shape of cupboard hinges and door handles in my hotel room the morning of my first day in Italy in the Sixties, and then finding endless cases where the American equivalent would be sturdy, well made, and practical but totally devoid of the aesthetic interest manifest in the Italian object.

The Italian concern for individuality carried over even into very cheap cars in a way not seen in other countries. Americans have often embellished their Fords and Chevrolets with add-on accessories, but many Italians in the Fifties would have completely new body panels made for their Fiat 500s, the little cars Italians called “Topolinos.” And when Alfa Romeo, Fiat, and Lancia—then rivals, not part of the same group—embraced unitized body-chassis structures and eliminated chassis frames, they went to the trouble of making coachbuilder platforms so people could go to their neighborhood body shop and have an individual body made.

There were literally thousands of places to have bodies, or parts of them, made by skilled workers. One of the most prolific Italian designers, Giovanni Michelotti, is said to have had more than fifty individual cars on display at the 1953 Turin Motor Show. For about $35, a private client could have a design for his Fiat from the same hand that had created some of the most dramatic one-of-a-kind Ferrari bodies.

There were, of course, a few coachbuilders who stood far above those local shops. Most of the best-known were in Turin: Carrozzeria Ghia, which built many Chrysler show cars (and whose name adorns the Alfa Romeo 6C2500 shown here); Carrozzeria Pinin Farina, set up in 1931 to make a spectacular body for a Cadillac V-16 chassis; and Carrozzeria Bertone, a tiny operation until the Fifties, when “Nuccio” Bertone, son of the founder, took a huge risk and agreed to build 1,000 coupe bodies for Alfa Romeo. There were two famous houses in Milano, Carrozzeria Touring, specialists in aerodynamics and lightweight structures—their slogan was “air is the obstacle, weight the enemy”—and Carrozzeria Zagato, whose founder came from aviation.

Ghia was purchased by Ford in the Sixties, when the American company was involved in racing, special models and making concept cars, but its Turin facilities were closed a long time ago, and the name is just a trim-level badge for ordinary Ford passenger cars. Touring went broke more than forty years ago, and most of its archives were burned as its buildings were cleared out. Zagato exists, making small numbers of special body variants of expensive cars like Aston Martin and Ferrari.

The decline and fall of the great design and small-volume production houses comes from two principal causes, one industrial, the other sociological. The industrial matter is quite simple: all carmakers in the developed world have their own in-house design teams, quite often led by an imported chief designer from a well-established manufacturer. That is true for the Korean group that makes Hyundai and Kia cars. Peter Schreyer, a German with a distinguished past with the Volkswagen Group, was hired first to put some spark into Kia. He was so successful that he was named head of all design for both nameplates in January 2013. Fiat do Brasil has a design team headed by Peter Fassbender, another German who had extended experience in Italy. These successful professionals have taught successive generations of native designers the practices of the most competent car design departments in the world, so there is no longer any advantage for a company to go to Italian firms, as was the case as recently as the 1990s, when Peugeot and Citroën relied on Pininfarina and Bertone, respectively. Today a Frenchman, Jean-Pierre Ploué, heads the design teams for both makes, in a single dedicated facility near Paris completed in this century.

The sociological problems come from the fact that Italy is still organized around families, not corporate entities. Yes, Fiat is the biggest company in the country, but it is essentially the fiefdom of the founding Agnelli family, which has firm control over the holding company that pulls all the strings. And the design houses were dynastic family operations as well, all of them having followed the traditional pattern of such firms: the founder creates something promising, the second generation develops and expands the entity, and the third generation, never having had to struggle or build anything, dissipates the accrued fortunes.

Consider the Pininfarina venture. Battista Farina worked for his older brother’s company, Stablimenti Farina, until 1931, when he set out on his own. Battista was a very small man, perhaps five feet three inches tall, but a giant in talent, a bundle of energy, nicknamed “Pinin” (“Shorty” in English). He became world famous, to the extent that he was granted the right to change his family name to Pininfarina. That may sound distinguished to us, but literally translated, it’s “Shortyflour.” Battista’s two children, a daughter and a son, inherited the firm, but in the typical Italian manner, it was the son, Sergio, and the daughter’s husband, Renzo Carli, who took over from the founder in 1961, the year the family name changed. The two men did a great job in expanding the company, its production capabilities—in addition to classics like the Ferrari 250GT shown here, the house not only designed the body of the Peugeot sports models, it built them—but when they retired, the decline and fall began.

Sergio Pininfarina (pictured here with Enzo Ferrari) had three children, a daughter and two sons. The eldest, Lorenza, was by far the brightest of the three, but because of her gender and Italian machismo, she was relegated to public relations while her less-capable younger brother was accorded control. When he was killed in a scooter accident after putting the company in debt to banks to the tune of a couple of hundred million euros to fund expansion that never came, the youngest—male—child was given the reins. Result, the company still has work, the Pininfarina family interest is less than ten percent of the total capital, and the prospects for the future are bleak.

As they are now for Carrozzeria Bertone. The founder, Giovanni, ran a nice little business; his son Nuccio (diminutive of Giovanni) turned it into a really excellent mid-size business. (He's pictured here with the 1963 Corvair Testudo prototype.)  Nuccio hired only the most talented designers—Mario Revelli de Beaumont, Giovanni Michelotti, Franco Scaglione, Giorgietto Giugiaro, Marcello Gandini—and gave them public credit for their work, unlike most other design houses, where the talent was anonymous and the families took credit. But Nuccio, who died in 1997 at age eighty-three, had only two children, both daughters. So, in the traditional manner, given that the girls had no particular design abilities or interest, their husbands were given direction of the company and proceeded to run it into disaster, losing the production facilities Nuccio had built to Fiat, and his widow, Lilli, took over amid TV-series-level drama. It was too late, and the company that had never had a penny of debt during Nuccio’s lifetime is bankrupt today.

Turin has been known for the metalworking skills of its populace since the Middle Ages, when it made the most elegant and practical of suits of armor, and it grew into the industrial powerhouse of Italy in the twentieth century, because at every street corner there were people who surpassed the abilities of highly regarded specialists in other lands. That is gone today for the most part. There are still large numbers of capable people, but there is little focus for them. Giorgietto Giugiaro, a great designer who did his best work under the tutelage of Nuccio Bertone, founded his own studio, Italdesign Giugiaro, with partner Aldo Mantovani, an engineer of great talent. Giugiaro of course wanted to leave the company to his son, Fabrizio, even though his daughter was more focused on design than the fun-loving young man. In the end, the entire firm was acquired by the Audi division of the Volkswagen Group and is now internal to that huge multi-make company.

There are still plenty of extremely good Italian car designers—Walter de’Silva, who revived Alfa Romeo style some time back, is head of design for the Volkswagen Group, for example, but there is not a single fixed place to go, without reflection, in Italy for car design. The enfeebled firms have found work in China, where literally hundreds of car manufacturing firms were created in Deng Xiaoping’s industrial revolution that followed Mao’s destructive “Cultural Revolution.” But the Chinese have always been quick to learn and to innovate, so they will not long be interested in foreign design input, just as the Japanese, who leaned heavily on Italy in the Sixties, are no longer clients for the moribund Italian design houses.

In a sense, all this is sad, but in truth it is the way of the world. Things change, and those who expect the status quo to persist are always disappointed because it never does. Yes, Italy was vital and central to car design in the second half of the twentieth century, as France was during the two decades between the two world wars, and as the United States was for volume production car design from 1920 to 1955. People will always remember the great works of Pinin Farina, Nuccio Bertone, Luigi Segre of Ghia, and the great creators they employed, but the passion, the drive, the intensity has gone. We can regret, lament, celebrate the past, but there is no foreseeable future for Italian car design.

pageElements.text:
Response from Pininfarina

Dear Mrs. Jennings, We read with great dismay the article “The Death of Italian Coachbuilding” by Robert Cumberford, respected journalist who has been following Pininfarina since decades. This is the reason why, this time, we are very astonished by the many inaccuracies and false statements in his story.
Firstly, we are disappointed by such little respect towards the Pininfarina family. Unfounded personalized criticisms, such as the ones addressed to Mr. Andrea Pininfarina, and statements about Mrs. Lorenza, do not deserve any comments. The role of the third generation has been - and still is - central for the Company.

Under Paolo Pininfarina’s chairmanship, the Company is perpetuating the image of a brand that is still perceived as synonymous with excellence. Pininfarina continues to cooperate with a great number of automakers and has undertaken new collaborations expanding the range of business from automotive to boating, aeronautics, industrial design, interior design and architecture, as evidenced by the many recent successful projects in the United States, Latin America and Asia.

The global crisis occurred in the latest years, in particular to automotive industry, is an undeniable fact. However, the crisis did not hit only companies organized around families, as confirmed by the bankruptcy of giants like GM and Chrysler. Pininfarina has gone through difficult years as many others but continues on its path offering the world its interpretation of creativity, as borne out by the Gran Lusso created with BMW and the acquisition of new customers from among the world's top 10 car manufacturers.

Growth in the engineering sector has been achieved mostly in Germany and Asia, in particular in Japan and India. On the Italian market, important projects underway in collaboration with Ferrari and its Styling Centre are evidence of the strong, long-lasting ties between the two companies.

Besides design, Pininfarina provides all-round support to automotive companies by engaging in a variety of activities: engineering, product development, testing, prototype construction. More generally, we do not share Mr. Cumberford’s opinion when he argues that "there is no longer any advantage for a company to go to Italian firms." Prestigious clients such as Ferrari and BMW continue to rely on Pininfarina’s creativity. The models on display in Geneva this year showcase the role of Pininfarina as the standard bearer for the aesthetic values of Italian design in the world and strengthen the brand, the firm's true distinctive character. The new Ferrari California T, together with the F12 berlinetta, the FF and many other recent projects, are part of a history that has generated the finest cars of all times through an evolution that started over 60 years ago and shows no sign of waning. And the Gran Lusso confirms our mission not only as global designers, but also as makers of exclusive high-quality cars.

Mr. Cumberford is right when he says that the era of coachbuilders as contract manufacturers is over. However, today Pininfarina continues to dedicate resources and talents to the creation of unique pieces, reinterpreting its artisan roots. The dream of the Ferrari Sergio is becoming true for a few collectors thanks to Pininfarina skills and experience. At our style and engineering center in Cambiano we continue, as ever, to conceive, develop and manufacture one-off models and small series.

It's a job that is so noble and so peculiar to the Turin area. It is a return to our origins, to a niche that is fully keeping with our vision, our history. Pininfarina, in essence, is still a strategic partner with which the internal OEM styling centers continue to compete on all the proposed designs. Being considered a reference point in style is testified by the many awards received also in recent times, such as the 2012 Interior Design Award of the Year for the Cambiano, the Best Design Study 2013 for the Sergio, the GOOD DESIGN™ Award 2013 and German Design Award 2014 for the BMW Pininfarina Gran Lusso Coupè.

Despite the “de profundis” sung by Mr. Cumberford, Pininfarina is more alive than ever. We kindly invite your readers to follow us on www.pininfarina.com and www.facebook.com/PininfarinaSpA. There they will see how vital our company is. Thank you very much in advance for publishing this note.

Best regards. Pininfarina Communication Department

Robert Cumberford Responds to Pininfarina:

So the Pininfarina Communications Department is unhappy with me. That was to be expected. Anything less than panegyric enthusiasm always distresses them. Too bad.

I have frequently praised designs carrying Pinin Farina and Pininfarina labels, specifically mentioning the purity, beauty, and classicism of cars made during the past eighty-three years that featured those badges, but that does not change my view of the problems visited upon Pinin’s proud house—or Nuccio Bertone’s—by the founding family’s third generation miring those companies in debt.

It is easy to blame “outside forces” but the bankruptcies of GM and Chrysler cited here by Pininfarina came from the same causes: incompetent management, arrogance, and unwillingness to see the world as it is, not as desired to be by those who made the bad decisions.

I hope Pininfarina SpA will indeed continue to exist and prosper, but as it does so it will be under the direction and control of others, not Battista’s descendants, whatever their titles and roles in the enterprise.
—Robert Cumberford

title: My Stolen Car
subTitle: My parents bought me a car off Craigslist. Here's what happened next. Don't let it happen to you.

pageElements.text: On January 3, 2014, the night of my twenty-second birthday, I was sold a lie. I'm a philosophy major, so I overanalyze just about everything and everyone I come across. Like most, though, I allow my desires to blind my judgment. Especially when the object of my desire is as shiny as a new car.

The 1998 Bonneville I was driving, before the 2004 Jeep Liberty featured in this story, was in shambles.  Both rear struts were broken, making the ride to Wayne State University in Detroit pretty bumpy. I'm a waitress and an undergraduate student, so money is spent on necessities and vices, leaving little room for repairs and new cars. My mother and her husband saved me on this one.

I found a Jeep listed on Craigslist. It was listed for sale by a guy who said his name was Scott Tooth. On the night of my birthday, my mother’s husband and I met him in a parking lot to look at the Jeep. It was a public parking lot that he had selected, and he only let me test drive inside the parking lot, not out on the street. He looked me in the eyes, smiled, wished me a happy birthday, admired my mother’s accent, and so on, all after explaining the story of the car.

According to him: "My sister just wants to get rid of it. She just got a job and moved to Chicago, so she doesn't need it. She's giving me some money to sell it.  It’s a great car. My dad is a mechanic so it's in good shape. I don't want to take it on any main roads because the tags are expired." Everything seemed to make sense, but I wasn't thinking because I wanted that Jeep more than anything at that moment.

He took my deposit, $100, and we purchased the car the next day. Cash.  I was in love with the car and the feeling of security. I had never before been the owner of a nice car, nor the owner of a reliable one.

I drove my new Jeep to the Secretary of State office two days in a row to register the vehicle. Because of weather, both days it was closed, as was my university. I work four to five days a week, and I'm going to school four days a week. My hours and those of the SOS branches are not compatible. In that way, two months went by.
Eventually, on March 5, a class was canceled, I had time, and I went to go make my car legal. After waiting an hour and a half, I was told I had a fake title and a stolen car in my possession.
I puked. Then I drove to the police station and gave up the car that had never been mine.

I cried because I learned that I was driving someone else's car that had been taken at gunpoint. I cried because I lost my only asset. I cried because the money used to buy the car wasn't mine. I cried over the lack of humanity. I felt guilty and sad.
But anger was the dominant emotion. The following three nights, I dreamed of murdering the boy who sold me the Jeep.
Dramatic? Maybe. But I was sold a stolen car by a person who was clearly lacking empathy, and I could not help struggling with questions of morality and existence.
Lying is a two-way street. There is the liar and the believer. Beware of those who do not smile with their eyes.
Lying is a two-way street. There is the liar and the believer. Beware of those who do not smile with their eyes.
To Scott Tooth and the men that took the car at gunpoint: I promise that I will not be the victim the next time we meet.  I hope guilt eats you alive, if it ever finds you.

Upon walking through the first set of Waterford Police Department doors, I was buzzed in to the station where I would have to leave the Jeep. I said to the police officer, "It seems I've bought a stolen car." I told him the story of my encounter at the Secretary of State while he checked details regarding the Jeep. He guessed right away that I had found the car via Craigslist. The two officers guiding us through the process were of good humor. They teased and joked, giving a light touch to the stiff situation to the point where I almost enjoyed it. They could not find any details of the man who had sold me the Jeep. They had us fill out an incident report, asked us questions, and sent the case to a detective, who later answered some questions that the police could not.

The legal owner of the Jeep was a man who had been in the hospital at the time of the jacking. His roommate had been using the Jeep, which had no insurance.  Since the car had been bought on a bank loan and stolen while uninsured, the car technically belongs to the bank, the detective explained.  I have no contact with the legal owner, nor do I have contact with the bank that has the lien on the car.  The investigation is still ongoing, but I have been promised answers once they surface.

My friend Caylan and her husband, expecting parents, were selling one of their cars, a Chevrolet Blazer (the one I'm in at the top of this page). They gave me a wonderful deal on the car and had it to me before spring break ran its course, allowing me to continue my semester without interruption.

So, are you thinking of buying a car from Craigslist? Before any money changes hands, call in the VIN to your local police station. Another suggestion: meet the seller at a Secretary of State branch, not in some random parking lot.

title: Ferrari FF Spa-and-Drive
subTitle: A day with a friend driving Ferrari's four-seater in the moneyed hippie enclave of Ojai, California.
promoTeaserSmall: A day with a friend driving Ferrari's four-seater in the moneyed hippie enclave of Ojai, California.
promoTeaser: A day with a friend driving Ferrari's four-seater in the moneyed hippie enclave of Ojai, California.
metaDescription: Ferrari FF to the Spa: I had the opportunity to go for a little spin in Ferrari's four-seater. My story. Read it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: I'm the auto and motorcycle critic for the Orange County Register. Previously, I  was a staff writer at the Los Angeles Times for fourteen years, writing about motorcycles, cars, green living, and anything else that caught my fancy. Originally from Ann Arbor, Michigan, I currently live in Los Angeles with my ten-year-old son.

pageElements.text: The Ferrari FF is about as counterintuitive as it gets: a two-door four-seater that not only seats four but can rocket them across the asphalt at 208 mph, it’s a super sporty SUV alternative for individuals with an insatiable need for speed and the means to indulge it.

It is, perhaps, Ferrari’s least Ferrari-like sports car. So, when offered the opportunity to drive it for a weekend, I decided to use the $295,000 FF for an equally unlikely purpose: a girls' getaway to Ojai, California. The itinerary: spa treatments and a vegan lunch that wouldn’t quite compensate for the gluttony of a 13-mpg V-12, followed by a thrill ride through the canyons.

I was hoping for a full house—to pack the FF’s four seats with fellow moms equally desperate for a child-free getaway. Alas, there is baseball. I was only able to swap one of my friends' field-side lawn chairs for a leather bucket seat.

But that friend was enormously appreciative. A high-school librarian who is so in love with books that she even brought one along for the trip, she immediately compared the FF’s tactile brown leather to the tomes she shelves daily.
“This is the librarian’s Ferrari,” my friend, Sara, cooed after settling into the low-slung passenger seat and craning her neck to see over the hand-stitched dashboard.
As we headed up Southern California’s Highway 101, en route to the twisty roads that circle the moneyed hippie enclave that is Ojai, that impression was confirmed.

“I thought people would want to race us,” she said, with a hint of disappointment. As the driver of a sensible Mazda 3 hatchback, Sara isn’t one to fawn over exotics, but her deflated expectation was undeniable. “There aren’t even that many people staring.”

It was true. Painted silver and having an elongated hood and overall profile that defies the Ferrari stereotype, the FF is, to the casual observer, an understatement. But pressing pedal to metal, it’s even more responsive than a 458 Italia, its exhaust pipes just as thunderous.

I pitied the women who were relaxing to a chimes-and-chants soundtrack as their flesh was massaged at the Day Spa of Ojai. We could have been cited for disturbing the peace as we pulled in to the parking lot—and back out a few minutes later, since there was no availability. Our fellow patrons at the less-ritzy Bamboo Creek Spa, however, didn’t seem to mind. And the folks passing by the Hip Vegan Cafe, where we dined on raw salads with walnut “burgers” and sipped coconut water, were downright appreciative of the unexpected four-wheeled delight we’d driven into Prius-ville.
“Lots of people have been taking pictures of your car,” said a woman who was holding a bake sale near our parking space. “I didn’t let them touch it too much,” she smiled.
“Ooh, fancy,” a woman in yoga pants commented as we opened the doors to the FF and strapped in for a ride along the Ojai Freeway.

Esteemed as one of the best driving roads in Southern California, its seventy-one miles are a smorgasbord of twists and sweeping vistas that inspire drivers toward idiocy, and I was no exception. The FF was especially adept at indulging my usual character flaw—doubling the posted corner speeds—so much so that I noticed Sara was white-knuckling the grab bar.
“Would you mind slowing down?” she asked. “I don’t mean to be a nerd, but you’re scaring me.”

Truth be told, I was also scaring myself. Ferraris have a habit of outing one’s moron gene, even if it’s ordinarily recessive, so I was happy to oblige and keep my speed to a reasonable 40 mph. Much to my chagrin, and Sara’s relief, I’m sure, the Ojai Freeway was cut short just ten miles north of Ojai due to seasonal road construction, so we doubled back.

Seventy miles later, we were back in the land that is most appreciative of the sports car that got us there: status-conscious L.A., where residents’ ears are tuned to Ferrari’s beautiful racket and the exclusive novelty of its dark horse, the FF.

2014 Ferrari FF

Four-wheel drive four-seater
Base price: $295,000
Engine: 6.3-liter V-12, 651 horsepower, 504 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 11 mpg city/17 mpg highway

For fun in selecting color, trim, and options on an FF (prancing horses embroidered on the headrests? Carbon fiber steering wheel? Daytona-style seats?), visit Ferrari's configurator.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $33,425 base price (including destination), $41,075 as tested (including destination)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 241 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed Steptronic automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/33 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: The turbocharged four-cylinder engine
Option I can’t live without: The entire Ultimate package ($6,150), especially the moonroof and the power front seats
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth connectivity, halogen fog lights, roof rails, leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Cold weather package ($700) includes heated steering wheel and front seats, retractable headlight washers; Ultimate package ($6,150) includes Homelink, keyless entry and ignition, rearview camera, panoramic moonroof, auto-dimming rearview mirror and exterior mirrors, power front seats with lumbar support, front and rear parking assist, navigation, SiriusXM satellite radio and traffic with one-year free subscription, BMW Online, BMW Apps
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Ford Escape, Mini Cooper Countryman, Volkswagen Tiguan

America is smitten with sport-utility vehicles of every size. The Lilliputian BMW X1 was introduced to the U.S. market in 2013 and sold a respectable 26,000 vehicles in its first year. Although it shares a platform with the previous-generation 3-series wagon, BMW calls it a sports activity vehicle (SAV). Some would argue that it is actually a tall sedan with a smidge of extra ground clearance.

Semantics aside, this new niche of ultra-small luxury-utility vehicles is about to get a lot more competitive come 2015, when the Mercedes-Benz GLA, Audi Q3, Lexus NX, and Infiniti Q30 will all be vying for leadership in this segment.

I recently spent time in the 2014 BMW X1 xDrive 28i. The x in xDrive denotes all-wheel drive. As the 1 designation indicates, this BMW is indeed small. To give you an idea of scale, it is slightly larger than the Mini Cooper Countryman and slightly smaller than the Buick Encore. Although it does seat five, I recommend that, for long road trips at least, two of the passengers should be the type of humans who are not tall enough to ride the big roller coasters. And if you do ferry five for vacation, you may want to consider taking advantage of the roof rails to add extra storage.
The hybrid car/SUV look will attract the design-conscious buyer who is averse to bulky SUVs but can appreciate a hatch design.

The X1 is good-looking from every angle. It is especially stunning in this Midnight Blue metallic, which showcases the character lines that give the X1 its BMWness. The hybrid car/SUV look will attract the design-conscious buyer who is averse to bulky SUVs but can appreciate a hatch design. For those who pine for the kidney-bean grille in a sport-utility but want to keep below $40,000, this may be for you. That's especially true if your nest is empty or your birds are still young. Urban buyers will love the smaller footprint that will allow them to squeeze into tight parking spots.

The X1 is available in three variants. The xDrive 28i and the rear-wheel-drive sDrive 28i both have a 241-horsepower turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine with an eight-speed transmission. The xDrive 35i has a 300-hp turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder engine with a six-speed transmission. The smaller engine has a manual mode to up the fun quotient, but there is no true manual transmission offered—which, to many BMW aficionados, is a deal breaker. Living in Michigan, I lean toward the all-wheel drive, but for a good portion of the country it is unnecessary since this vehicle will most likely not be leaving the pavement.

If you are new to BMW, you will need a moment to adjust to the Steptronic transmission. There are three modes; sport, manual, and standard. But for me the odd part is the shifter itself. To select Park, you push a button on the top of the shifter, and to disengage you need to push a button on the left of the shifter. Then you can move between Drive, Reverse, and Neutral. Pushing the shifter to the right at any speed selects sport mode—best used for times when you want a burst of speed. But for the most fun driving, pushing the shifter to the left will put you in the manual mode.

All the variants come standard with Auto Start Stop, which switches off the engine when the vehicle stops temporarily and thus helps fuel economy. Keep in mind that if you opt for the larger, more powerful engine, your mpg will drop from 22 city/33 highway to 18 city/27 highway, and the mileage isn’t impressive in either case.

Once inside the cabin, it is a cozy fit. The additional headroom is welcome and reminds you that you are indeed in a sport-utility vehicle. But since the X1 sits lower than most, the driver’s position is very carlike. BMW has added a removable cupholder—that protrudes rudely into the front passenger's already tight quarters—for cupholder-crazed Americans. We promptly removed it and stored it in the glove compartment. As I mentioned before, the rear seat will be most comfortable for junior passengers, but they will be happy that the seats do recline. But the X1 truly shines when you fold the seats down and treat the cargo area like a true hatch.

The 2014 BMW X1 comes standard with automatic climate control, rain-sensing windshield wipers, an eight-speaker stereo, Bluetooth, HD radio, a USB port, and BMW’s iDrive infotainment system. The interior materials seem more utilitarian than luxurious. Even the infotainment seems a little behind the curve, especially if you don’t add on a package that offers satellite and navigation.

Our X1 had the cold weather package for $700. It included a heated steering wheel and front seats, as well as lovely headlight washers. Most Americans don’t appreciate the beauty of this option, but I do—especially during the sloppy spring we are experiencing this year.

We also opted to go all out and upgrade to the Ultimate package for a whopping $6,150. That is a lot of cheddar, but that cheese buys amenities that most luxury buyers demand, such as keyless entry, a rearview camera, power front seats, a navigation system, voice command, satellite radio, real-time traffic, and a panoramic moonroof, to name a few. The entry fee is worth the price just for the additional light the moonroof adds to the cabin.
The X1 handles very much like its BMW sedan/coupe kin, with enhanced visibility provided by the added height.

If you prefer a more carlike sport-utility vehicle, the X1 is here to please. The X1 handles very much like its BMW sedan/coupe kin, with enhanced visibility provided by the added height. It delivers plenty of power and can provide the punch for easy highway passing, although I did feel a slight lag. The turbo is a bit loud, and it pinged a bit rather than growled when the turbo is spooling up. The steering is tight and responsive and will feel like home to the BMW faithful.

The Verdict:

Once we tweaked our X1, it priced out at $41,075 for the pint-size sport-ute. That is a hefty price tag for a vehicle that doesn’t feel all that luxurious. And if you need a gas sipper, this nugget should fall off your list as well. If you are looking for the ultimate driving machine, you will need to look elsewhere, but first-time BMW owners may be dazzled by the Bimmer roundel. And for those who seek a hot hatch, it is worth a test drive. But I think I would wait a year and take a spin in all the new luxury contenders before I plunk down my hard-earned cash for the X1.

Peanut Gallery:

Scott Allen: My only complaints are minor quality-of-life things. I don't like that the radio stays on even after you get out of the car, until you lock the door from the outside. I thought the cupholder was in the way in the passenger's seat, but I guess they knew that, because it's nice you can remove it. As I said, very minor. I appreciated how easily I could see around the car with no blind spots. When it comes to driving, there is nothing wrong there!

Laura Sky Brown: In my youth, I once spent a few weeks living in a convent (only as a visitor!). My room was a tiny "cell" on the same corridor as the nuns. It had only a plain desk, chair, and narrow single bed that all fit tightly against the walls, and there was only one simple religious painting for decoration. Everything, in short, was set up to provide minimal distraction and maximum focus on the work of religious life.

I mention this because the interior of the BMW X1 is as plain as a nun's cell. Simple black leather and hard black plastic; stiff, narrow seats; nothing to distract you from the driving experience. You might say to yourself, "Why should I get excited about sitting in this unadorned, uninteresting, not really all that comfortable passenger cell?" And then you accelerate to pass, and it all begins to make sense.

Molly pointed out that people buy this car because of the snob value of the BMW badge. I know they do, and in a bit of reverse snobbery, I would hesitate before owning one myself for that reason. But dig a little deeper, and you remember the reason the badge has that kind of clout: it's all about the driving experience. If you want luxury touches and soft surfaces, there are lots of other crossovers and small SUVs to shop for instead.
