contributors.bio:
Sheer serendipity.  That’s how I became a contributor to Jean Knows Cars.  Well into a lovely dinner party, I received a most unlikely suggestion:  “You should write about cars from your perspective – a 4’11” single mother with a ten-year-old minivan who drives around three overactive children and a Bernese Mountain Dog.  Theatre, swimming, hockey, lacrosse, figure skating, field hockey… You love to tell stories. Tell them about cars.”  I suggested that my background possibly lacked necessary expertise – B.A. from Duke in art history and medieval/Renaissance studies; Fellow of the American Academy in Rome; Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in medieval architecture --  nothing about cars there!  My friend persisted, “You may be an art historian, but you are also a hockey mother who can whistle like a trucker, a runner, and a lover of good food, wine and the written word.”

I pondered.  The auto industry and I did have a long, if tangential, history.  I did a stint as an executive secretary to the president of a car dealership and spent fifteen years negotiating a dual identity as an academic and as auto company spouse.  I have always suffered from car envy, particularly acutely when I lived in Europe.  (As envy and lust are amongst the seven deadly sins, I’m in trouble.) Automobiles, functional objects that often shape image, are fundamental elements of today’s society.  This would be another mode of cultural analysis and critique.  Couched in that light, it made perfect sense!

(And, I really can whistle like a trucker, but louder. I may be an art historian, but don’t sit next to me at a hockey rink.)

pageElements.text: When it began the production of the B-24 Bomber in 1941, the Willow Run Bomber Plant, over a mile long, was the largest factory under a single roof. On Saturday, March 29, on a chilly and gray Michigan afternoon, Willow Run witnessed a different record: the most “Rosie the Riveters in One Place.” The former airplane hangar was a sea of red-and-white polka dot bandanas as 778 women came together for the effort to set a Guinness World Record. It was part of the ongoing effort to save a portion of this historic plant to host the Yankee Air Museum.

These women were at all ages and stages of life. Some women were there because of personal connections, searching for personal history. With pictures in hand, they asked the fifteen original Rosies who were there, the women who had worked in Willow Run and other factories during the war, if they by chance had known their mothers, aunts, or grandmothers.

Many were there for inspiration. The youngest “Rosie” was three-month-old Maggie Lee. Her mother, Mary West of Monroe, Michigan, brought her so that she could be part of history in the form of the world record atttempt. Mary works as a technician in the food industry; her mother was a factory worker as well. She wants little Maggie to be inspired by the “original Rosies,” the women who stepped in to do a “man’s job” during World War II and inadvertently changed the face of labor practice, putting women into the manufacturing workforce.

Jasmine Lovett provides an indication of how powerful and how resonant the image of Rosie the Riveter remains for many women, particularly those in manufacturing. A twenty-two-year-old mechanic in Motorworks, one of the few women in the shop, she turned to the Rosie the Riveter icon as a visual reminder that “women can do it” and two months ago had the Rosie image tattooed on her arm.  An instant bond and flow of mutual admiration emerged as Jasmine shared her tattoo with the Original Rosies.

Pat Fisk, Scout Leader of Troop 41602, brought her Girl Scouts to the event for similar reasons: “To them, World War II is ancient history. I wanted them to see these women as a connection to social change that paved paths for them.”

Did they get the world record? It seems inescapable, but there will be a few weeks' wait while the Guinness people go over video, pictures, signed witness statements, and pictures and make it official.

Although this event sought to raise awareness of (and funds for) the Save the Bomber Plant campaign, its fundamental drive was to honor the Original Rosies. Now octo- and nonagenarians, these women remain as sharp as tacks with the cutting wit to match. As they came out to join the Rosie assembly for counting—some walking on their own accord but many in wheelchairs due to their advanced age—they received a standing ovation to chants of “Rosie, Rosie.”

The most moving moment for me was during the National Anthem. With a color guard carrying a flag that had flown over the U.S. Capitol, my daughter, sixteen-year-old Sarah McCurrach, mike in hand, started singing. At first, the crowd was silent as the pure notes of "The Star-Spangled Banner" reverberated through the hangar. Then the Original Rosies joined in, followed by the whole crowd, 1,000 people singing in unison in honor of these remarkable women. There were shivers and quite a few tears and, at the end, raucous applause.

During that moment, I had a palpable sense of being part of a larger collective, part of a larger movement, part of a moment in history.  And we were, as keepers of the past and part of the future, for on Saturday, the governor of Michigan declared the day the “Official Rosie the Riveter Day.”

contributors.bio: I have spent a lot of time on the road. I started touring with a band along with my older brother, Ryan, when I was still in high school, and in all I have put in a little over ten years of touring. Eventually we were in a band named Thunderbirds Are Now! We played many festivals including SXSW, CMJ, and Pitchfork, toured all over the country and all over Europe, went to Australia, were in a lot of magazines, and had an exciting time. We spent thousands of hours inside a 15-passenger red Ford Econoline van we bought that we called Old Magent. That was where we had our down time. We spent more time in the van than we did playing the shows. When we toured outside the country, we had drivers. My strongest memory of that is being picked up in a Mercedes Sprinter van by someone we had never seen before and being driven through deep snow from Germany to Sweden—a 15-hour drive—through the mountains at high speed. Everyone in the band wrote final messages to our families and put them in our pockets just in case. Touring with a band is very scary but also very fun. A lot of weird and new things happened in my life, but they are great memories I'll never forget, and it was time well spent living a dream that came true. But all good things come to an end. You're up every night, and it just gets hard. I was lucky that my father was a musician and built a recording studio in our basement, and he also shot a lot of videos. I have been recording my own music and making stop-animation video since I was a young kid. After leaving the band, I went to Washtenaw Community College to study videography and won a couple of awards—Most Creative two years in a row, and Best in Show. I was doing freelance post-production video editing when I met Jean Jennings, and we instantly clicked. She likes music, I like music, and we just "get" each other. I've had a very, very strange route to where I am now. I'm happy that I can settle in with Jean Knows Cars and live a normal life but still with a creative outlook. Here's an interview with Scott by CBS Detroit in July 2013:

I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: It's finally spring, and this is the perfect time to clear out your car: get rid of the clutter, sweep out the crumbs and road salt, and refresh the interior surfaces.
In this video, JKC's Molly Jean shows you a few simple tips to help you do it quickly and easily. Play along! You'll need:

- a wet/dry vacuum
    - a scrub brush
    - a paintbrush
    - a bucket
    - simple cleaning products: glass cleaner, alcohol-free baby wipes
    - paper towels and a lint-free cloth

Note: You shouldn't use any alcohol-based products on the interior surfaces of your car; buy "alcohol free" baby wipes, and try gentle soap and water before you try anything fancier.

title: 2015 Subaru Outback
subTitle: A new face for the old friend makes its New York Show debut.
promoTeaserSmall: A new face for the old friend makes its New York Show debut.
promoTeaser: A new face for the old friend makes its New York Show debut.
metaDescription: 2015 Subaru Outback: A new face for the old friend makes its New York Show debut. Don't worry, it's not much changed. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: You wouldn’t have to look too far to find a Subaru Outback out on the road that is almost as old as the nameplate. It’s twenty years since the all-wheel-drive specialist came out with this rugged take on the family car, and today at the New York Auto Show, the fifth generation made its debut. Not surprisingly, as you see in these photos, its look is not drastically changed from the capable, maybe a little staid, appearance it has always had.

And that’s just how its devotees like it. The Outback has everything to please the adventurous but unpretentious family: great visibility, pretty good fuel efficiency, and all-weather capability. There’s little doubt this new version of the Outback will be flying out of dealerships, and from there, putt-putting down the Colorado highways and the Iowa City and Madison campus boulevards for years to come.

What’s new for 2015?

Chief among the changes are a standard continuously variable transmission as standard on all models and enhanced active all-wheel drive with X-Mode, which first came out on the 2014 Forester. Subaru says this will improve engine output and increase AWD engagement. Speaking of engines, there’s a standard boxer four-cylinder that makes 175 horsepower, but you could upgrade to a 3.6-liter boxer six-cylinder that makes 256 horsepower. Pretty good for a Subaru. Fuel economy for this all-wheel-drive vehicle is estimated at 33 mpg on the highway for the four-cylinder, up from 30 mpg in the 2014 model. The Limited with the six-cylinder should get 27 mpg highway, up from 25 mpg last year.

New active safety items include a rear vehicle detection system, standard on the Limited model, which includes blind spot monitoring, lane change assist, and rear cross-traffic alert. There’s also new standard Welcome Lighting that turns on the cabin and exterior lights as you approach or leave the Outback, an upscale touch for this wagonish vehicle.

Perhaps most noteworthy is the latest version of Subaru’s EyeSight active safety tech, which includes adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane departure warning. It also features steering-responsive foglamps, which activates the lamps independently while you’re turning. EyeSight is available on Premium and Limited versions of the Outback.

Inside the Outback, the closest to luxury is the top Limited model, which gets perforated leather seating, a ten-way power driver’s seat with two-position memory, dual-mode heated rear seats, and a power rear gate that memorizes your desired height. There’s also an All-Weather package available that adds heated front seats, heated exterior mirrors, and the luxury of a windshield wiper de-icer.

Subarus aren’t known for their useless gewgaws, so the 2015 Outback offers an infotainment system with a modest 6.2-inch touchscreen, although it’s quite up to date with Bluetooth connectivity, Aha, Pandora, and iHeart radio, and Subaru Starlink smartphone integration. The Limited gets an HD radio system with Harman Kardon twelve-speaker audio. A nav system is optional.
The 2015 Outback goes on sale in late summer, with prices to be announced closer to launch. For reference, the 2014 Outback started at $24,320 (including destination charge).

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

title: Toyota Moving to Texas
subTitle: Bye, California! 4000 employees will move to the new location in north Dallas by 2017.
promoTeaserSmall: Bye, California! 4000 employees will move to the new location in north Dallas by 2017.
promoTeaser: Bye, California! 4000 employees will move to the new location in north Dallas by 2017.
metaDescription: Toyota will build a new North American headquarters in Plano, Texas, starting this fall, with nearly 4000 employees set to move within the next three years. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
This story originally appeared on our brother website Automobile Magazine.

Toyota announced today that it will establish new headquarters in Plano, Texas, for its North American operations over the next three years, with the move to be completed by 2017. This new headquarters will unify Toyota’s current model of three separate headquarters for its North American manufacturing, sales and marketing, and corporate operations, which are located in Erlanger, Kentucky; Torrance, California; and New York City, respectively.

Just as when Nissan moved from California to Tennessee in 2006, reasoning behind this move is largely financial. Toyota is sure to pay fewer taxes in Texas compared with California. Automotive News reports Toyota chose the location in part due to "zero state income tax, lower housing costs, and a relatively strong quality-of-life index." This move also means that Toyota’s headquarters will be closer to some of its southern production facilities in San Antonio; Blue Springs, Mississippi; and Huntsville, Alabama.
Toyota will offer relocation packages for impacted employees but expects "some headcount attrition" from employees who don't want to move.

“With our major North American business affiliates and leaders together in one location for the first time, we will be better equipped to speed decision making, share best practices, and leverage the combined strength of our employees,” said Toyota North America chief Jim Lentz in a statement.

Groundbreaking for the new Toyota headquarters in Plano will take place this fall, with construction of a brand-new environmentally sustainable building estimated to take two years or more. Small groups of employees will start moving this summer to a temporary facility in Plano, with the majority of other workers to move when the building is completed in late 2016 or early 2017. The move will affect 4,000 employees total, with 2,000 of those coming from Toyota Motor Sales USA in Torrance, 1,000 coming from Toyota Motor Engineering and Manufacturing North America in Kentucky, and a smaller group coming from Toyota Motor North America in New York. The last group to move, in 2017, will be 1000 employees from Toyota Financial Services in Torrance.

To smooth the transition, Toyota will be making a $10 million philanthropic commitment to the communities in California and Kentucky, which will continue to fund nonprofits and local community organizations for a five-year period starting in 2017. Automotive News reports that Toyota will offer relocation packages for impacted employees but expects "some headcount attrition" from employees who don't want to move.

Along with the big move to Texas, Toyota will also expand the Toyota Technical Center near Ann Arbor, Michigan. Some employees from Toyota’s Kentucky operations will move to the Michigan facility to occupy a new building on the Technical Center campus, which will be accompanied by increased investment in engineering and product development at this location.

pageElements.text: The first Mother's Day gift I ever recall giving my mom was a poem I wrote myself, at age six. It was pretty bad, but she didn't think so. In fact, she held on to that crayon composition for the rest of her life. Nowadays, with four kids of my own, I know a little something about how simple, heartfelt gifts are the ones moms like best.

But this has got to beat all. University of Louisville's star quarterback, Teddy Bridgewater, who's in the NFL draft this week, just got his mom the 2015 Cadillac Escalade you see here. Did his mom, Rose Murphy, like it? What do you think? Watch the video, directed by Spike Lee, and meet this charming mother-and-son pair.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gTe5RnL0bmw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Bridgewater had promised his mom a pink Cadillac when he made it to the NFL. He was in third grade at the time, but she knew it could happen.

According to Mom, Bridgewater had promised her a pink Cadillac when he made it to the NFL. He was in third grade at the time, but she knew it could happen. The National Football League's scouting report on the QB explains why: "Makes few mental errors. Consistently moves the chains and comes through in the clutch. Meticulous in his preparation. Smart, determined and focused. Highly respected, unselfish team leader."
And, perhaps the most prescient of all: "Rises to the occasion on big stages."

image.altText: a pink cadillac escalade for mom

pageElements.text: Yes, this son rose to the occasion, all right. Cadillac called in its color and trim design manager, Erin Crossley, and Escalade ad manager Sean Thornton to help Bridgewater choose just the right shade of pink. Then, knowing a good PR opportunity when it saw one, the GM division helped Bridgewater present the Escalade to his mom at Le Cirque in New York City, followed by an appearance on Good Morning America.

The 2015 Escalade has a 6.2-liter V-8 that puts out 420 horsepower and 460 pound-feet of torque. Its starting price (including destination charge) is $72,690.

So, happy Mother's Day to all you moms out there. We moms know that Rose Murphy would have treasured any token of her boy's affection, but you've got to admit this will look more awesome on the streets of Miami, where she lives, than any old bouquet of flowers would.

pageElements.text:
Have you ever done something embarrassing with your car? Before you answer that question, think of all the things other people do that seem ridiculous...until they happen to you. The website Insurance.com surveyed 2,000 people in April on which of seventeen screw-ups they have had happen, and it made me think: Have I really done all seventeen of these?
Jean: I will admit to committing "only" ten of these sins.
(Averages are shown in the images below.)

1. The most frequent issue for both men and women was forgetting where they'd parked the car, with 44 percent of men and 59 percent of women admitting to it. (The Android users among them ought to check out this app, just released, that will keep track for them.)

Jean: My biggest problem is forgetting which car I'm driving. The old Union 76 gas station used to give away orange Styrofoam antenna balls for a reason.
Here's the breakdown for the other items on the list:
2. Driving over a curb: 51 percent of women and 35 percent of men.

3. Locking the keys in the car: 41 percent of women and 34 percent of men.
Jean: I've done that so many times in the past that I became really handy with a coat hanger back in the day. The most egregious example was dragging all my little brothers to the beach and, in the course of getting them and all their gear out of the car, I not only locked my keys in the car, the engine was still running. Just as beach security got the door open, the car ran out of gas.

4. Driving down a one-way street in the wrong direction: 38 percent of women and 30 percent of men.
Jean: I was pulled over three times in France on one day: once for running a yellow light, the second time for speeding (in which the national police blocked the autoroute to pull me over), then later that afternoon in Toulon, in the south of France, in a driving rainstorm. I made a right turn only to face four lanes of traffic coming right at me. I made a quick U-turn, but not quick enough to avoid the police. Not one of those stops resulted in a ticket.
5. Driving off with something sitting on the top of the car (coffee, a purse?): 34 percent of women and 28 percent of men.

6. Mistakenly attempting to open the door of a car that isn't actually yours: 34 percent of women and 24 percent of men.
Jean: See item 1.
7. Giving up on backing out of a parking spot because other cars or obstacles are too close: 33 percent of women, 21 percent of men.
8. Dropping money or food at the drive-through: 28 percent of women and 23 percent of men.

9. Accidentally triggering the car alarm, then unable to get it shut off quickly: 26 percent of women, 18 percent of men.
Jean: I mistakenly set off a car alarm on a Ford pickup truck while demonstrating the force of an air bag explosion on Good Morning, America.I immediately leapt through the passenger window to try to get the key, an action caught in gory detail by the cameraman. The resulting clip appeared on the hilarious outtake show Talk Soup that week, shown in forward and reverse, so it looked like an early version of an animated GIF. They showed it three times.
10. Losing a toll ticket at the payment booth: 17 percent of women, 18 percent of men.
11. Unable to get out of a traffic circle roundabout and kept going around...and around: 13 percent of women and 12 percent of men (hey, people, see our instructional video on this one).
12. Failing to have license, registration, and/or insurance card when pulled over: A tie! 11 percent of both men and women.

13. Driving away from the gas pump without taking the nozzle out of your tank: 7 percent of women, 14 percent of men.
Jean: The most famous case was a newly hired motor gopher at Automobile Magazine who did this and tore the nozzle right out of the pump. Needless to say, his first day was his last day.
14. Unable to get your key remote to work to open your car door: 8 percent of women, 10 percent of men.
15. Almost hit someone with your car: 9 percent of women, 8 percent of men.

16. Forgetting a passenger and having to go back to get him or her: 6 percent of women, 11 percent of men.
Jean: I didn't own the car and wasn't driving, but I had convinced a cabdriver friend to take my roommate, me, and my golden retriever Odin home to visit our parents. Driving back to Ann Arbor through Detroit on the Interstate, he heard a squeak in his wheel and pulled off into a closed grocery store parking lot at 2 a.m. He proceeded to jack his car up on the sidewalk under the lights, take the wheel off, and repack the wheel bearing while we stood outside in the freezing cold and waited. When he was finally done, we jumped in the car and took off. We realized fifteen minutes later that we'd forgotten the dog. We hustled back and there he was, sitting patiently in front of the grocery store, waiting for us. The horror.

17. Getting into a car and then realizing it wasn't your car: 8 percent of women, 7 percent of men.
Jean: This hasn't happened to me with a car, but it has happened two different times in hotel rooms, both times in Europe, where the tradition is to leave your key at the front desk when you go out. The first time, the guy was in the shower and all his shoes were lined up beside the door so I backed out. The second time, the guy was actually asleep in the bed so I turned around and ran. I now carry a card with my room number written on it.
You might notice that women admitted to more of these than men did, averaging 4.2 mistakes to men's 3.5, while five percent of all respondents admitted they were guilty of ten or more mistakes.

These are all embarrassing and annoying, but at least they are (mostly) harmless. However, Insurance.com notes that 40 percent of those responding said at least one of their gaffes ended up causing damage to the car.

It's refreshing to know that the most feared item on this list is number 15, almost hitting someone, feared most by nearly a quarter of those surveyed. Let's hope that the other three-quarters are confident enough in their driving skills to know this is unlikely to happen to them!
Are you guilty of some (or all) of these mistakes? Or even better ones? Tell us your stories!

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Pink is a powerful mystery. Repaint a dowdy brown Toyota Camry or a gruesome green Honda Accord in pink, the color of femininity, and you’ve created an enigma, one that’s on par with the black monolith in 2001: A Space Odyssey.
Why was this done? What could it mean? The car now has a new power that goes beyond the size of its engine or the length of its wheelbase.

Pink expresses femininity but also outrageousness. The mixture of red and white and a little blue—or yellow—also represents success. Thinking pink hard enough and long enough will lead to one of the cars that Mary Kay sales directors drive.
But sometimes, pink suggests frivolity. A pink hot rod? A pink Lamborghini Murciélago?
Let us consider automotive pink through the ages.

Pink in the Art Deco Era

DuPont introduced Duco lacquer in 1923, and the colorful, quick-drying finish soon replaced the dull varnishes that had predominated in the automobile industry. Even famously black Fords eventually began to wear interesting raiment.

Pink cars weren’t exactly a familiar sight—but then again, as the historian Jo B. Paoletti has explained in her book Pink and Blue, neither was the color pink freighted with the same gender coding we find today. Some department stores recommended pink for boys. After World War II, pink was established in a marketing sense as the color for girls.

So a pink car was merely a flamboyant statement in the 1930s. When the novelist and car collector Clive Cussler was restoring a fabulous 1936 Avions Voisin C28 Ambassade, he decided to spray it pink. Speaking with me in a phone interview, Cussler recalled: “I did some study and found out that the French, there in that Art Deco era, used to paint cars just all kinds of wild colors. I thought I’d just go back to the old days and do it kind of a loud color.”

Displayed in the Cussler Museum, in Arvada, Colorado, the Voisin’s enthusiastic squalling can be heard on the plains of Nebraska and Kansas. Cussler’s book on his collection, Built for Adventure: The Classic Automobiles of Clive Cussler and Dirk Pitt, also showcases a 1936 Ford cabriolet hot rod in approximately the same tone of pink.

Elvis Starts a Pink Thing

Pink Cadillacs started rolling through the verses and choruses of popular songs in the early 1950s. Elvis Presley toured in a custom-painted 1955 Cadillac Series 60 sedan, which remains part of the collection at Graceland. In Baby, Let’s Play House, his first national hit, he mentions the car while imploring his sweetheart to return from college and be with him. In the next few years, as Elvis was conquering the world from a little Memphis recording studio, pink spread through Detroit: it turned up on Fords, Buicks, and Chryslers, among others.

As Modernist architecture and design flourished, the color palette expanded. The Postwar era embraced tones we wouldn’t even consider in our current white-black-silver-red conformism, which gives resale value an unnaturally important position above individual expression. Of course, pink Cadillacs (and their metaphorical work on behalf of sex) went on to accumulate well more than 200,000 miles in the songs of Bruce Springsteen and Aretha Franklin.

Selling to the Ladies

In 1955, Chysler Corporation’s Dodge Division had a nutty idea. The brand’s Custom Royal sedan wasn’t doing much. But the backslapping, cigar-puffing honchos who ran the division had apparently learned that not all cars were driven by men. And maybe some of the fairer sex even conducted their own transactions! For this niche market, why not create a unique car?

So the Custom Royal Lancer La Femme was a midyear offering. “The industry’s first appeal to women,” says the Standard Catalog of American Cars. Heather Rose and Sapphire White paint distinguished the La Femme, and it had floral upholstery. The purchaser received a pink umbrella, cape, boots, and shoulder bag. (Instead of the healthy snacks and cruelty-free emollients the latter would contain today, it was filled with a compact, lipstick, cigarette case, and lighter.) For several years, Chrysler’s top-of-the-line Imperial was offered in Shell Pink and Persian Pink. The 1959 Imperial wasn’t fully loaded until the buyer added the available Elizabeth Arden travel makeup case. Product literature urged, “Slip it into the glove compartment of your Imperial against the inevitable times when ravages demand repair.”
1969 Playmate of the Year Connie Kreski merited some serious horsepower: she received the most potent of all Mustangs, the Shelby GT500—in pink.

From the Playboy Garage

MX 707908 was code for an optional Ford Mustang color known informally as Playboy Pink. The first pink Mustang was a gift from the magazine to Donna Michelle, the 1964 Playmate of the Year, who first posed for Playboy when she was seventeen. Soon, Ford dealers were capitalizing on the availability of pink for special promotions. In Portland, Oregon, Marv Tonkin Ford ordered twenty-five examples and arranged test drives with Playmate Kelly Burke. Ford historian Tony Popish has written that most Playboy Pink Mustangs were not upgraded from the stock six-cylinder engines because “they would be driven by the ladies.” But 1969 Playmate of the Year Connie Kreski merited some serious horsepower: she received the most potent of all Mustangs, the Shelby GT500—in pink. Then again, Kreski was from the downriver Detroit suburb of Wyandotte, Michigan, with the Ford Motor Company’s central operations within a short drive, so she would have known the difference between a potent V-8 and an anemic six.

Pink and Mary Kay, Inc.

You know what you’re seeing even before your eyes rove to the script. A Mary Car “career car” is a singular corporate emblem, always worthy of note and generating immediate admiration for the driver’s gumption and grit. She had to work hard to get that car!

It all started in 1968 when Mary Kay Ash, who had absorbed the pink Cadillac myth, entered a Dallas dealership and ordered a car to match her young cosmetics company’s Mountain Laurel blush. She soon rewarded her five top-selling consultants with pink Coupe de Villes. Since then, General Motors has produced about 100,000 pink Cadillacs. Lesser pink cars like Saturns and Pontiacs have been available to Mary Kay consultants, and the program is global. (One of Jo B. Paoletti’s big points is that pink isn’t uniformly interpreted across cultures.)

At the 2014 Mary Kay Leadership Conference, a surprise announcement brought more than 10,000 women to their feet: a black BMW 320i was presented as the newest addition to the beauty fleet. Indeed, the pink Cadillac was green with envy.

pageElements.text: Are you mesmerized by the Tesla Model S? Who isn't, really? Named 2013 Automobile of the Year by our brother publication Automobile Magazine, and bandied about in tech, automotive, and every other kind of website as the Greatest Thing Since Sliced Bread, the Tesla Model S might be a rare example of the thing that really is as cool as They say.

So, for the same reason people like satire about the president and jokes at the expense of the biggest movie stars, people like to read about the mighty Tesla Model S and maybe chuckle at it a little. Not to say these same people (and I include myself) wouldn't jump at the chance to drive one!
Here are five most amusing and interesting Tesla Model S tales and videos from around the Net, in no particular order.

1. The Comic

Even if you've already seen this, see it again. "What It's Like to Own a Tesla Model S." In detail. Pure brilliance and more than a little worshipfulness for the Model S.

2. The Hack

With great computing power comes great computing responsibility. Somebody figured out how to hack that giant seventeen-inch, multifunction Web browser of a touchscreen in the Model S. Apparently there's a "disguised ethernet port hidden in the dashboard," it says here. Well? It had to happen, as this story says. How does Tesla like that? Not much, according to this story. Owners? Well, they could load various third-party apps of their choice, if they knew how to do it....

3. The Tesla-tastrophe

In which a guy takes a trip in a Tesla Model S, the whole recharging thing does not go well, the car ends up on a flatbed....you had to be there. But you know what? The driver was "a little sad" to say goodbye to the car anyway.

4. The Three Little Girls in the Back Seat

If you want to see pure joy (and, one assumes, pure affluence) on three little faces, check this out.

5. The Two Very Different Ways to Dance with a Tesla Model S

There's the nice, clean factory way:



And then there's this way.

pageElements.text: As his creamy butterscotch leather passenger's seat envelops me and I listen to the inviting metronomic tick of his turn signal, Paul Fisher announces, “It’s a lot nicer to ride a Jaguar than the other way around. I prefer to stick my head in this Jaguar than the other kind.”
What?

Paul, a Florida art dealer, is perhaps the only Jaguar owner in the world to have been attacked by the actual big cat, whose bite is twice as strong as that of a lion, and survived. Paul has always been both a car guy and an animal aficionado, who nurtures two birds, a reptile and four (small) cats at home.

In 1983, Paul was working as a Connecticut park and forest law enforcement officer, protecting wildlife.  A desire for warmer weather took him to Dallas,  where he thought he’d further pursue police employment.  “But I just got lucky and happened to fall into a job selling rare and classic cars," he tells me. "It turns out I was a really good salesman. They had the franchises for Bertone and Pininfarina cars, which were the former Fiat Spider and the former Fiat X1/9.  I became the number-one salesman in America on those two cars.”

When an Aston Martin DB2 Mark II drophead in slate blue came his way,  “Dale Chihuly [the world-renowned glass sculptor], whom I had never heard of, bought the car and wanted me to help him assemble a collection of Aston Martins, every one from postwar to present, and I thought, that’s like a dream come true.  He had the money and the ambition, and I knew how to find the cars. And I had all these ex-cop, Sherlock Holmes reader tricks to finding cars. I would go to the library and look at old magazines and see who was selling what and figure out what got sold and go through old motor vehicle records and advertisements.”

Paul noticed that some classic car collectors were also collecting Chihuly’s artwork, and he began to sell the revolutionary glass sculptures as well as the often elusive automobiles. Paul eventually moved to West Palm Beach, Florida, where, “In 1999, I met Irina [now his wife] and wanted to spend all my time with her.“ Paul became a full-time art dealer, representing numerous artists, including Chihuly, at his eponymous gallery.

He recalls his encounter with the jaguar clearly. “On December 30, 2010, I got mauled by a jaguar at a big cat sanctuary. It was a freak accident where the cat had escaped. I had a moment of warning that the cat was dashing our way, and I put myself between the cat and somebody else because I thought, as I’d been around big cats before, I could handle it better.
The jaguar jumped me, landing on my head, sinking her fangs into my face, and tearing my face apart.

"It turned out I could. Most people who get pounced on by a jaguar die. She jumped me, landing on my head, sinking her fangs into my face, and tearing my face apart. Because I’d been a martial artist my whole life and had done yoga, as soon as she got me I was able to completely calm down and relax. I had turned so she couldn’t land on my neck," he goes on. "In around thirty seconds, they were able to get her off me.” Only a faint scar marks Paul’s left cheek.  “I had a terrific plastic surgeon,” he acknowledges.

The circumstances surrounding his Jaguar car purchase are equally vividly recalled: “A couple months after, I’m on eBay late at night and I see this fabulous car, a dark blue 1998 Jaguar Vanden Plas. I just adored that car but, being an enthusiast, I knew there was one that was better.“

image.altText: pauls2002 jaguar super v8 vanden plas

pageElements.text:
Soon he found the 2002 Jaguar XJ Super V8 (X308), of which he says, “It is the absolute peak of evolution of the Jaguar four-door saloon, which I think is the best looking four-door ever made. Between 1997 and 2003, it was absolute perfection in form. It’s just gorgeous, a silver ocean blue.”

Paul’s car makes 370 horsepower from its supercharged 4.0-liter V-8. It has an extended wheelbase, four headlamps, and Computer Active Technology Suspension (CATS). Paul notes, “In 2002, they had all the performance upgrades they were going to have in later models including the DVD, navigation, better suspension, a warning system; with burled walnut trim, thick carpeting, and a sunroof that tilts and slides. The back seat has so much room, and it has mahogany tables (like elegant airplane trays).
This Jaguar is made so that if I am driving hard and fast and digging into corners, I don’t need to look at anything, I know where everything is.

"Of all the cars I’ve owned, including newer cars, it has probably the best sound system I’ve ever heard. And the clock is always on time, that analog clock with the beautiful Jaguar round face. Every control is beautifully laid out.

image.altText: pauls2002 jaguar super v8 vanden plas

pageElements.text: "This Jaguar is made so that if I am driving hard and fast and digging into corners, I don’t need to look at anything, I know where everything is.  I know exactly where the Sport button is.  It is laid out as well as possibly can be imagined. It’s made in England, and this is the last car that Jaguar as Jaguar completely designed, engineered, and built.”

And he has driven the XJ fast.  “When I first got it, I touched 130 on the way home.  I really wanted the supercharged engine because it was one of the fastest sedans in the world the year it came out, but I don’t really drive it that fast. At 130 it was rock solid, steady, no flow, no lift, no uncertainty or play in the wheel.  I think it’s 5.4 zero to sixty.”
Paul disputes Jag’s former reputation for requiring expensive repairs: “The secret to Jaguar is that it’s like a thoroughbred horse. As long as they are active, they are happy.”

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: “Most of the customers we appeal to are looking for something that not everybody else is driving,” said Doug Murtha, Scion’s vice-president, after posing with the iM Concept at the Los Angeles Auto Show.

From the front, the five-door hatchback sneers. While big-brother Toyota division sucks the air out of the room with its well-focused mass-market cars, the Scion division directs the iM at individualists.

Although nothing specific was said about them at this introduction, the mechanical components aren’t special, but who cares? The most important specifications will be the size of its bass speaker and the price, which Murtha hoped would be under $20,000.

Whatever happens next will still get you to work in time to put on socks. (Yes, socks suck!) Meanwhile, you have a very practical car that’s nevertheless compellingly pocked and speckled in front, elongated in profile, and nearly as daring as Miley Cyrus in the back.

Cloaked in vivid blue with gray trim, the iM looks like lapis in silver. It's energy drink fervor in steel. Seeing it drive through the East Wing, President Obama might choke on his Nicorette gum. On the Harbor Freeway, street-sweeping trucks would bow down on their brushes.
The production iM will arrive at the New York Auto Show in April, and it will be available in dealerships later in 2015.

title: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker
subTitle: Yes, you can improve your parking-lot experience. Here's how.
promoTitle: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker

keywords: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker
metaTitle: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Yes, you can improve your parking-lot experience. Here's how.

pageElements.text: 1. Don't be in a hurry. Easier said than done, but if you are not racing to your destinations, you will not have to stress out about the parking space you get (or don't get).

2. Don't break the rules. I'm talking to you with the flashers on in front of the fire hydrant while you "just run in for a minute." This is neither polite nor safe, and it adds to parking lot stress for yourself and everybody else. Don't park in a handicapped space for any reason, either.

3. Watch what you're doing. The International Parking Institute (yes, there is one) says up to 14 percent of accidents resulting in an insurance claim come from parking lot altercations. Look around you, be careful when you back up, and as always, expect bad driving from others and demand good driving from yourself.

4. Don't be an annoying pedestrian. Get out of drivers' ways in the parking rows, cross at crosswalks, and watch for cars before you step into the aisle. Temporary custody of a shopping cart does not give you 20 minutes' right of way to saunter down the center of a grocery store lane.

5. Be prepared when you get there. Carry change for meters. Also: Figure out where you think you'll be parking before you leave the house. Sometimes you can even use a parking app like SpotHero, which lets you find and reserve spots in crowded city centers around the country, even far in advance if there's a special event. Usually you can prepay and get a discount.

6. Remember where you parked. This is the trifecta: it will stress you out, get you behind on time, and make you an annoying pedestrian if you can't remember where your car is. I like to take a cellphone photo to show me the location: the level number in a parking structure and the surroundings in a surface lot. It helps.

7. Be a good driver. Obvious, but surprisingly rare when it comes to parking skills. Are you a good parallel parker? If you're not, go out and practice sometime when you're not busy. This is the skill that divides the grownup from the wannabe.

pageElements.text: Amid the sea of people and exciting tech announcements at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week, there was an announcement from Toyota that is probably a pretty important moment in automotive history: the Mirai. It's Toyota’s hydrogen fuel cell car, a mid-size sedan that will be available for purchase or lease in October.

Hydrogen is clean and abundant. A car that runs on it emits nothing but water. But skeptics of the idea of hydrogen as an alternative fuel have predicted that hydrogen fuel cell cars are impossible – or at least too difficult.
But here it is 2015, and you will be able to lease one for $499 a month, including all maintenance and fuel, later this year.
This reality is brought to you by twenty years of research and thousands of patents.

“The first 100 years of automobiles were fueled by gasoline,” said Robert Carter, senior vice-president of automotive operations at Toyota. “The next 100 will be fueled by hydrogen.” Carter believes today is the beginning of the next 100 years.

For many people, the idea of hydrogen-fueled cars recalls terrifying, fiery images of the Hindenburg. But that’s merely because hydrogen needs a better public relations team. It was the paint on that famously flammable zeppelin that burned, not so much the hydrogen.
Hydrogen is a gas. It’s flammable, sure. But it dissipates harmlessly if you puncture the container it’s in. Pffft… gone.

That is, if you can puncture the container it’s in. Because one of the real problems (there is a reason for the thousands of patents and decades of research) with hydrogen as a fuel is not that it creates a pool of highly flammable gas around your vehicle in a crash –that’s a problem with gasoline–but that it's hard to contain. Its particles are so small and light that it’s hard to keep it in a container. That’s why hundreds of Toyota’s patents are for the fuel tank in the Mirai.
Another problem with hydrogen, of course, is finding it at the gas pump. But Toyota is working on that, and so are California and other states,

Another problem with hydrogen, of course, is finding it at the gas pump. But Toyota is working on that, and so are California and other states,  “We know we have to invest in the infrastructure to make this happen,” Carter told me. And that’s exactly what the company is doing. So don’t be too surprised if you start to see hydrogen fuel stations cropping up soon, first in California and the Northeast but in other states soon after.

And here is something that your fossil-fuel-burning car can’t do that the Mirai can: When the power in your house goes out in that next hurricane or snowstorm? Just plug your house into the car. The Mirai can power your house for a week as a backup generator. Try that with your current SUV.

subTitle: Powerful full-size truck bravely squares off against formidable competition.

promoTeaser: Powerful full-size truck bravely squares off against formidable competition.
metaDescription: Powerful full-size truck bravely squares off against formidable competition.

pageElements.text: It’s fair to say that for all its virtues—solid construction, plenty of power, plenty of capabilities—Nissan’s Titan has been all but invisible in the full-size pickup derby.
Fifth in a field of five, the Titan’s share of the full-size pickup market hovers around one percent.
But far from giving up, Nissan is renewing its challenge to the pickup establishment with an all-new truck that the company characterizes as the toughest, most rugged-looking of them all.

You’ll make your own decision about cosmetics, but the revitalized Titan will have at least one major bragging point: the only diesel V-8 engine option in its class. It has two more cylinders than the Ram 1500 turbo-diesel V-6 and 5.0 liters versus 3.0.

But with 310 horsepower and a whomping 555 pound-feet of torque (the Ram’s diesel delivers 240 and 420, respectively), the Cummins turbo-diesel V-8 puts the Titan into heavy-duty territory. Nissan claims maximum payload will be in excess of 2,000 pounds, and maximum towing will be 12,000 pounds plus, depending on equipment.

Nissan furnished no EPA numbers for the new engine, other than to say it anticipates a 20 percent fuel economy advantage versus a normally aspirated gasoline V-8 of comparable displacement. The current Titan V-8 is Nissan’s gasoline 5.6-liter, with EPA ratings of 15 mpg city and 19 mpg on the highway.

Although Nissan refrained from details, a gasoline V-8, probably the 5.6-liter, will continue in the Titan lineup, which will also include a V-6 for the first time. But the first new Titans to reach showrooms—late this year—will all be crew cab versions, propelled by the new Cummins diesel. The other engine choices won’t come along until later.

All engines will be paired with an Aisin six-speed automatic transmission, and four-wheel drive will continue to be an option. Nissan is aiming to satisfy buyers who want heavy-duty capability without stepping up to one of the really massive Big Three HDs.
That may sound like a pretty tight marketing window. But, even though it has only a one percent market share, Nissan thinks it's worth a try.

pageElements.text: Super Bowl XLIX, or, as they like to make people call it, the Big Game, happens this Sunday, Feb. 1. A much-anticipated part of the festivities is seeing the over-the-top commercials, with automakers' ads usually high on the list of favorites.

Increasingly, you can see all or part of the ads ahead of time. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles announced on Thursday that it will be running three as yet unspecified ads during the game; will Eminem be featured? we wonder.

As for those that are viewable now, we've conveniently assembled the clips here for you. Which are your favorites? Comment below!

1. Toyota

Toyota Camry’s pre-bowl #OneBoldChoice campaign features NFL players, along with regular Joes, reflecting on the experience of fatherhood. The extended cut is so touching, even the iciest of hearts will feel a little thaw.

Just as moving is the actual ad that will air Sunday under the title “How Great I Am,” featuring Paralympian Amy Purdy. Drums riff in the background as Muhammad Ali boasts: “I have wrestled with an alligator. I done tussled with a whale…” Shots of Purdy in a Toyota Camry are intercut with a progression of training trials and personal triumphs. Linking the reliable everyman’s Camry with the likes of Ali and Purdy, two badass originals in the first degree, is a bold choice.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/PjUfygo5mzw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2. Mercedes-AMG

“The Big Race” campaign by Mercedes has taken an interesting tack in its Super Bowl ad buildup. Four advance spots tout an epic showdown between that fabled pair, the Tortoise and the Hare, along with a viewing party contest, have been creating anticipation for a special advertising event on Super Bowl night. The actual commercial (revealing the race winner) premiered on Ellen DeGeneres's talk show on January 26, undercutting that Super Bowl thunder somewhat.

Here's one of the four Tortoise and Hare advance ads.



The game day commercial itself is a polished piece of animation from Maleficent film director Robert Stromberg, and the race begins just as the old story goes. Then we learn there’s something powerful and mysterious in the woods: the Mercedes-AMG GT S. You can guess which competitor ends up behind the wheel.

3. Nissan

Nissan hasn’t run a Super Bowl commercial since 1997, so the pressure is on to make this reentry memorable. The automaker will run a 90-second ad, only a brief clip of which has been released ahead of time. To generate excitement for its corollary #withdad campaign, focusing on fathers’ struggles to balance work and family, Nissan solicited the help of YouTube videomakers to capture dad moments. Check out the video selections to see what these video dads came up with. Word is the Murano may make an appearance during the game night spot.

4. BMW

Putting the spotlight on the BMW i3, the “Newfangled Idea” commercial might be the most clever use of cultural memory since Volkswagen introduced us to little Darth Vader. To highlight the revolutionary nature of its all-electric vehicle, BMW employs a real clip of NBC Today Show anchors Katie Couric and Bryant Gumbel. filmed circa 1994, in which the anchors are completely bewildered by a new thing they call Internet. This pitch-perfect ad has pros Couric and Gumbel befuddled once again, 20 years later, by another new technological concept.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/U1jwWwJ-Mxc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

5. Lexus

To announce its turbo/hybrid NX, Lexus's “Make Some Noise” piece is energetic and moody at the same time. It blends ambient car sounds (the rev of the engine, the whir of the moonroof, the squeal of the tires) with percussive images of maneuvering Lexuses and dancers. It’s all about the young up and comer vibe in this spot that directs the viewer, “Be seen, be heard.”

6. Kia

Veteran James Bond Pierce Brosnan learns that action-adventure doesn't have to mean explosions or car chases, while he brings class and romance to the 2016 Kia Sorento.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/rSqqCI0LNHs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

7. Volvo

Then there’s Volvo, which isn’t even airing a commercial Sunday night but rather running an online campaign it calls Volvo Interception. Its ad asks viewers watching the Super Bowl to tweet the name of someone worthy to win a XC60, using #VolvoContest, every time they see someone else’s car commercial. To nominate someone you must also explain in your tweet why that person is so deserving of a new SUV. Volvo seems to be thinking that, while other car companies are talking about themselves, Volvo wants you to know who is important: you.

pageElements.text: Somehow, Ford kept the reveal of the exotic GT a secret until show day. We heard whispers, we hoped, we prayed that it was coming. There were no early glimpses of prototypes or drawings to be found anywhere on the Internet. And then out it popped on Monday morning to the collective gasp of the crowd.
Who knew it would be this stunning?
Moray Callum, global head of Ford design, knew. And he was awfully proud.

He and the Ford stand were mobbed during the entire two-day press preview. Sightings around the rotating display included the world’s top designers and CEOs, who had to have been just a wee bit envious.
Moray’s brother Ian has been on quite a roll of late as head of Jaguar design. But this year will be all Moray’s.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Such a travesty that the bold and quirky Santa Cruz concept was parked in the darkest, most remote corner of the Hyundai stand! But we found it, and with it, Chris Chapman, chief designer of Hyundai’s Design Center in Southern California. Chapman has been at his craft for some twenty-five years, making major noise at both Isuzu (his XU-1 concept won Best Concept at the 1993 Tokyo Motor Show) and BMW (X5 Sport Activity Vehicle,  X Coupe concept, and CS1 concept, among others) before joining Hyundai.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/W7kAV0xsb7I" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Santa Cruz, the hippie beach town south of San Francisco, would go crazy for this this truck ute. It’s everything the Subaru Brat was not—solid, taut, whimsical yet thoughtful. There is no doubt that Hyundai is testing the waters for a production Santa Cruz.
Chapman gives us the walking tour.
